div.p: Holy Time: OR, The True Limits of the Lords Day.

I. Proving, That the Lords Day doth begin with the Natural Morning, and that the Morning of the Natural day doth begin at Mid-night; and ≈øo con≈øequently that the Lords Day mu≈øt both begin with the Natural Morning at Mid-night, and end with the Natural Evening at Mid-night.
II. Proving, That the Jews beginning of the Day at the Sun-≈øet Evening was only in relation to the date of the Per≈øon purified from his Levitical uncleanne≈øs.
III. That The Jews them≈øelves did hold, That the Natural day did continue after Sun-≈øet till Mid-night.

Maymony ≈øaith, Grateful is a Command that is done in the hour of the ≈øame; (≈øo ≈øay I, grateful is the ≈øanctifying of the Lords Day in the hour of the ≈øame) In his Treati≈øe of Offering Sacrifice, Chap. 4. Sect. 1.
Part II. By WILLIAM PYNCHON E≈øq

div.head: Grace and Peace to ≈øuch as de≈øire to know when the Lords Day doth begin and end;
div.p: To the end they might ab≈øtain from their own Worldly imployments in the Lords own Sanctified time.
THis point is the more difficult to be explaned, becau≈øe I have not met with any beaten road from other Interpreters.
But I have laboured to make it evident,
1 That the Sanctified and ≈øeparated time of the Lords Day is ju≈øt according to the Natural day.
2 I have laboured to make it evident, That the Natural day begins with the Morning.
3 That the Natural morning begins at Mid-night.
4 That the Natural day, and ≈øo con≈øequently the Lords Day, doth begin with the Natural morning, and doth end with the Natural evening at Mid-night.

And for the want of the knowledge of the≈øe things, I perceive
that many godly per≈øons do the works of their ordinary Callings in ≈øome part of the Lords ≈øanctified and ≈øeparated day, as tho≈øe do that begin and end the Lords Day at the Sun-≈øet Evening, and for their better information I forced my ≈øelf to compo≈øe this Treati≈øe.

I finde that the chief ground of their error do ‚Ä¢ h ari≈øe, Fir≈øt, from a mi≈øtaken interpretation of the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe, to be a full Night of twelve hours; and Secondly, from a mi≈øtaken interpretation of the word Evening, becau≈øe they apprehend it to bee nothing el≈øe but a full Night.

The≈øe and ≈øundry ≈øuch like mi≈øtakes, I conceive I have cleared, I pre≈øum'd therefore that this in≈øuing Treati≈øe will be heartily welcome to every tender Con≈øcience, that doth truly de≈øire to give unto the Lord his own ≈øeparated and ≈øanctified time.

Many godly Chri≈øtians, to my knowledge, have been much exerci≈øed in their Studies, and Meditations, to finde out the true limits of the Lords Day, that ≈øo they might ab≈øtain from the works of their particular Calling, in every part of that ≈øanctified and ≈øeparated time, from the beginning of the day to the full end thereof.

For their ≈øakes al≈øo, and at the ≈øpecial reque≈øt of ≈øome of them, I have laboured in this Treati≈øe, to prove, That all the time of the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe was comprehended in the word Morning at la≈øt, and that it took its beginning from the Mid-night at la≈øt, namely, as ≈øoon as all the ≈øeveral parts of the Natural day were ≈øhaped and ≈øet into their order.

And therefore the beginning of the Morning from the time of Mid-night mu≈øt not be a≈øcribed to the Romans, as the fir≈øt Authors of it (as many unadvi≈øedly do,) nor yet to any other Nation; but it is the mo≈øt ancient Scripture-Computation
from the very fir≈øt created day; and ≈øo con≈øequently it mu≈øt needs be the true beginning of the Jews Sabbath.

This Tenent may happily ≈øeem ≈øtrange at the fir≈øt, to ≈øuch as have long held, both in their judgement and practi≈øe, That the Jews Sabbath (and ≈øo con≈øequently the Lords Day) did properly begin at the Sun-≈øet evening; and of this judgement and practice are mo≈øt of the Churches in New England, and in that re≈øpect many Profe≈ø≈øors among them do without ≈øcruple take liberty in the Sun-≈øet Evening of the Lords Day, to do the ≈øervile works of their particular Callings, and others take liberty to u≈øe Recreations.

But it is worthy to be taken notice of, that whole Churches do many times erre, both in their judgement and practice, or el≈øe how could ≈øo much Corruption, Super≈øtition, Idolatry, and Prophanene≈ø≈øe creep in to ≈øeveral reformed Churches, as there hath done from time to time in ≈øundry ages?

Being therefore intreated by ≈øome godly per≈øons in New England, and being al≈øo moved thereunto by the fear of God, I have taken this difficult Task in hand, le≈øt, to confute this corrupt judgement and practice, it ≈øhould ≈øpread like Leaven, to the corrupting of Po≈øterity; and ≈øo I re≈øt,

div.head: HOLY TIME.
CHAP. I. Proving that the Fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe in Gen. 1. 5. was not a compleat Night. By three Rea≈øons.
Rea≈øon I.
div.p: BEcau≈øe the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe wanted a Twilight going before it, which is a proper adjunct, and a true part, of a true created night; and therefore the fir≈øt created night was not without it; and our owne experience doth witne≈ø≈øe that every compleat night hath a Twilight going before it in the evening as a true part thereof as well as a Twilight in the end of it in the morning: But the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe, though it had a Twilight in the end of it immediately before the light ≈øhined out, yet it wanted a Twilight in the beginning of it; therefore it was not a full night: it was no more but a Synecdoche Membri, a part of the fir≈øt night.

And indeed there could not be a compleat night at fir≈øt, not untill the Artificial day was fir≈øt compleatly formed by the ≈øhining out of the light twelve houres together, and then at the end of the ≈øaid twelve houres the light went out of that horizon, and then there ≈øucceeded another darkne≈ø≈øe of twelve Houres which began with a Twilight. The fir≈øt halfe of this darkne≈ø≈øe made up the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe to be a compleat night
of twelve houres; and the other halfe went on towards the beginning of the ≈øecond natural day.

And thus, after this order and manner the fir≈øt night was created, ≈øhaped and limited, with a double Twilight, and by this means it became a true pattern and ≈øampler to all the other Creation nights.
Mr. Thomas Wil≈øon in his My≈øtical Ca≈øes, in Aenigmate 35. propounds this nece≈ø≈øary Que≈øtion:

p.hi: How can there be Darkne≈ø≈øe, where there is no Night?

div.p: Th ‚Ä¢ An≈øwer hereunto (≈øaith he) mu≈øt be referred to the fir≈øt Creation onely.
By this An≈øwer of his, it is evident that h ‚Ä¢ did not hold the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe to be a true night, as mo≈øt Interpreters doe, though much ami≈ø≈øe in ≈øo doing.
The ≈øumme of what I have ≈øaid, may be drawn up into this Syllogi≈øm.
No Darkne≈ø≈øe that wants the true ≈øhape and form of a compleat night, can be called a compleat night.

But the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe wanted the true ≈øhape and form of a compleat night, becau≈øe it wanted a Twilight in the begining of it, which is an in≈øeparable adjunct to the true ≈øhape and form of a compleat night.
Therefore the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe cannot in proper ≈øpeech be called a compleat night.
The Propo≈øition is ≈øo clear that I need not prove it, becau≈øe no man I thinke will deny it.

The A≈ø≈øumption is thus proved, God made the Stars to rule in the night, Gen. 1. 17. And the Stars were ≈øet fir≈øt into their dominion in the Twilight Evening of the fourth day, Gen. 1. 17. in re≈øpect whereof Job doth call them the Stars of the Twilight, Job 3. 9. But the Seventy Tran≈ølators call them the Stars of the night, becau≈øe they held Jobs Twilight to be a true part of the night; And Solomon doth likewi≈øe make the Twilight of the Evening to be a terme ≈øynonimous with Darkne≈ø≈øe, and with the night, Prov. 7. 9. And Aben Ezra on Exod. 12. ≈øaith there is the evening of the Sun, and the evening of the Night, when the ≈øhining of the Sun is gone from off the Earth.
For the further proof of this, I refer you to Chapter 4. To my An≈øwer to the ≈øecond Objection.
But I will hereunto adde the de≈øcription of a compleat night, which may further enlighten this truth. A compleat night is the ab≈øence of the Suns ≈øhining for the ≈øpace of twelve hours.

A compleat night is the ab≈øence of the Suns ≈øhining from off the face of the earth for the ≈øpace of twelve houres, when the Sun is in the Equinoctial, as the dayes were in the fir≈øt Creation: This de≈øcription of the Night agrees with the te≈øtimony of Aben Ezra, immediately cited.

Object. Why doe you ≈øet out the ≈øhape and form of the fir≈øt Artificial day by the ≈øhining of the Sunne, and of the Night by the ab≈øence of the Suns ≈øhining? Seeing the Sunne was not created till the fourth day; It is likely that the light that was created the fir≈øt day did not then rule the day after the ≈øame manner as the Sun did on the fourth day.

An≈ø. Though there was no Sun-≈øhine in the fir≈øt day, yet doubtle≈ø≈øe in≈øtead thereof the God of Nature, and the God of Order, did cau≈øe a certaine light to ≈øhine out of darkne≈ø≈øe, from the Element of Fire, in the ≈øelfe ≈øame manner and order, as he cau≈øed the Light to doe on the Fourth Day.

At the fir≈øt, the general matter of the Globe, called Earth, was without form, Gen. 1. 2. becau≈øe it was voyd of all ornaments for a time; in like ≈øort the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe was at the fir≈øt a confu≈øed thing, and without any ≈øhape or form of a night, for a time; but after the ≈øpace of five or ≈øix houres God ≈øaid, Let there be light, and there was light, Gen. 1. 3. It were too gro≈ø≈øe blindne≈ø≈øe, to think that God did cau≈øe this Light to breake out of darkne≈ø≈øe all on a ≈øudden, like a fla≈øh of Lightning; no, God was now framing the Fir≈øt Day, to be a Patterne, and Sampler to all the re≈øt; and therefore the God of Nature, and the God of Order, did cau≈øe the Light to breake out of Darkne≈ø≈øe by degrees, in the ≈øame order and manner as he cau≈øed the Sunne to doe on the Fourth Day, and ≈øo by this meanes the God of Nature did fir≈øt create a Twilight to the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe, before he cau≈øed the light to ≈øhine out upon the face of the Earth, as he did by the Sunne on the Fourth day; then al≈øo he cau≈øed the Light to a≈øcend by degrees, until it came to its height at mid-day, and then he cau≈øed it to decline by degrees,
until it went off from that Horizon, as the Sunne doth now; and ≈øo by this meanes the Artificial Day was compleatly ≈øhaped, and formed, before the whole Night could be ≈øhaped and formed.

But ≈øecondly, When the Artificial Day was thus formed, by the ≈øhining of the Light twelve houres, then there ≈øucceeded another Twilight, and twelve houres Darkne≈ø≈øe more then the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe; the fir≈øt halfe of that twelve houres darkne≈ø≈øe made up the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe a compleat night of twelve houres, with a double Twilight, and ≈øo it became a true patterne and ≈øampler to all other Creation Nights, and then the la≈øt halfe of the ≈øaid twelve houres darkne≈ø≈øe went on towards the beginning of the Second Day.
And except this order be ob≈øerved, there cannot be found out a double Twilight to make the fir≈øt Night a compleat patterne for all the other Creation nights.

div.head: Rea≈øon II.
div.p: It is evident that the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe was not a compleat night by the order of that Dominion which God e≈øtabli≈øhed for the ruling of the Artificial Day by the Sun, before he gave Dominion to the Moon, and to the Starres, to rule the night.

But if the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe had been a full night before the Artificial day had received its ≈øhape and form, then the Moon and Stars ≈øhould have had their dominion before the Sun, for doubtle≈ø≈øe the God of order would place them in their dominion in the day of their creation, according to that priority of order which the day had of the night, or the night had of the day. Gen. 1. 14. 19.

If the night of the fourth day had been fir≈øt in order before the Artificial day, then the Moon and the Stars ≈øhould have had the priority of their dominion to rule the night of the fourth day, before the Sun could have had its dominion to rule the artificial day; and ≈øo by this account the Sun ≈øhall borrow its light from the Moon as the chiefe≈øt in the dominion of the fourth day: Is not this to make the God of order to be the God of confu≈øion, in ≈øetting the Cart before
the Hor≈øe, by giving the fir≈øt dominion to the Moon, and the la≈øt dominion to the Sun; as they do that make the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe to be a compleat night.

Or el≈øe if you think to avoid this Rock, by ≈øaying that the Sun only was created on the fourth day to rule the artificiall day, and that the Moon and the Stars were not created, and ≈øet into their rule and dominion till the fifth night, is not this to run again≈øt the plain Text. For my part I ≈øhall think him a good Logician (that holds the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe to be a compleat night) that can fairly get out of this Dilemma.

div.head: Rea≈øon III.
div.p: If the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe had been formed into a compleat night before the light was formed into a compleat artificiall day; Then doubtle≈ø≈øe Mo≈øes would have called it Night (as the proper name of its perfect ≈øhape and form) before he called the light Day: for it was Gods u≈øuall cu≈øtome to give names to things in the ≈øame priority of order, as they had priority of form and ≈øhape: As for example, As ≈øoon as he had made man of the earth, he called him Adam, and as ≈øoon as he had made woman of his Rib, he bid Adam name her; and as ≈øoon as he had formed other creatures, he brought them to Adam, & bid him name them with names, defining their natures; & ≈øo doubtle≈øs if the fir≈øt darknes, had been fir≈øt form'd into a compleat night, he would have named it night in the fir≈øt place; but he called it nothing el≈øe but Darkne≈ø≈øe at fir≈øt, ≈øaying the darkne≈ø≈øe was, namely it was a mi≈ø-≈øhapen and uncreated thing: But as ≈øoon as he had put a ≈øhape, and limited it by a double Twilight, he called it night, as the name of its perfect form and ≈øhape: But it could not receive this ≈øhape and form untill the light was fir≈øt ≈øhaped and formed into an artificial day by its orderly ≈øhining upon the face of the earth for twelve hours together, and then he called it day, as the proper name of its perfect ≈øhape and form.

Hence we may cleerly perceive, That Mo≈øes in Gen. 1. 5. doth name all the parts of the fir≈øt natural day in their true priority of order as they were ≈øhaped and formed, 1 Day, 2 Night, 3 Evening, 4 Morning. And ≈øecondly, hence it follows that
the fir≈øt formed part of the naturall day, was the artificiall day, and not the night.

div.head: CHAP. II. Proving that Mo≈øes by the terme Evening in Gen. 1. 5. doth not me an the whole night; But the latter halfe of the artificial day, and the fir≈øt halfe of the night.
div.p: LEarned Mr. Richard≈øon ≈øaith, That the≈øe two words Evening and Morning do ≈øet our Divines to School to finde out what is meant by them in the fir≈øt Creation.

Mo≈øt Interpreters ≈øay that the two Hebrew words, Gnereb and Boker, which we tran≈ølate Evening and Morning, in Gen. 1. 5. doe mean nothing el≈øe but night and day. But I mu≈øt crave leave to differ from them in judgement, for the≈øe two Rea≈øons.

div.head: Rea≈øon I.
div.p: If Mo≈øes had called the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe Evening, and the artificiall day Morning, Then in rea≈øon he would have placed the ≈øaid termes in the ≈øame methodicall order in the end of the ver≈øe, as he had done in the beginning of the ≈øaid ver≈øe; but he doth place them in a contrary order, for in the beginning of the ver≈øe he names the Day before the Night, but in the end of the ver≈øe he names the Evening before the Morning; and what el≈øe doth this argue but that he did thereby intend that Gods people ≈øhould take notice that the Evening and the morning were a differing divi≈øion of the natural day from the divi≈øion of Day and Night?

div.head: Rea≈øon II.
div.p: If Mo≈øes had intended to call the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe Evening as ≈øynonimous to the terme Night, then doubtle≈ø≈øe ≈øome Scripture or other would have ≈øhewed them to be ≈øynonima, ≈øeeing the ≈øaid termes are ≈øo often repeated in the Bible.

But though I have made diligent ≈øearch, yet I cannot finde where the term Morning is made ≈øynonimous to the ful artificial
day, nor where the term Evening is made ≈øynonimous to the whole night, in a proper ≈øen≈øe.
Therefore ≈øeeing they are no where ≈øynonima, it is altogether unlike that Mo≈øes doth make them ≈øynonima in Gen. 1. 5. and no where el≈øe?

Object. Why might not the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe be a full Evening, and ≈øo a full night of twelve houres, though it wanted a Twilight in the beginning of it? might not God di≈øpen≈øe with the Twilight in the fir≈øt night?

An≈ø. Why do you go about to make the mo≈øt wi≈øe Creator and Governour of all things, to be an imperfect Arti≈øt in his fir≈øt pattern? for if you make the fir≈øt Night to want a Twilight in the beginning of it, do you not thereby make him an imperfect Arti≈øt in his fir≈øt pattern to the other creation dayes? for it is manife≈øt, that the ≈øhape and form of the fir≈øt creation day was a true pattern by which the re≈øt were ≈øhaped and formed; for as the text expre≈ø≈øeth it in ver≈øe 5. ≈øo was the Morning, and ≈øo was the Evening the fir≈øt day; ≈øo in like ≈øort it is ≈øaid of the ≈øecond day in ver≈øe 8. and ≈øo it is ≈øaid of the third day in ver≈øe 13. and ≈øo it is ≈øaid of the fourth day in ver≈øe 19. and ≈øo it is ≈øaid of the fifth and ≈øixth days, all the≈øe dayes were ≈øhaped and formed ju≈øt according to the pattern of the fir≈øt day.

The addition of the Sun in the fourth day made no new part of Light more then the fir≈øt day had, as I have noted it already, and therefore the manner how the Light did break out of Darkne≈ø≈øe on the fir≈øt day, was in the ≈øame manner and order as we ≈øee the Sun doth in the Equinoctial.

1 The Light a≈øcended out of darkne≈ø≈øe by degrees, as the Sun doth now, Gen. 32. 24. By means whereof it did fir≈øt make a Twilight in the morning, ≈øo the Hebrew phra≈øe calleth it in P≈øal. 119. 147.
2 Then after a while it began to ≈øhine upon the face of the earth, Gen. 19. 23.
3 Then it a≈øcended higher till it came to its height at midday, as E≈ø. 16. 3. Act. 22. 6. Act. 26. 13.
4 Then it cea≈øed to a≈øcend, and made a little ≈øtand for about halfe an hour.
5 Then it began to decline or go down by degrees till it went out of the Horizon.
6 Then it made a Twilight, called the Twilight of the Evening, Prov. 7. 9.
7 Then ≈øucceeded twelve hours darkne≈ø≈øe, the fir≈øt half whereof made up the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe a full night.
8 Then the la≈øt halfe of the ≈øaid twelve hours darkne≈ø≈øe went on towards the beginning of the ≈øecond day.
In this admirable order did the God of nature ≈øet together all the parts of the fir≈øt naturall day: But I have again ≈øet it out more fully in Section 4.
Object. 2. Some learned men ≈øay, That Mo≈øes by the terme Evening and Morning in Gen. 1. 5. meant Night and Day, no otherwi≈øe, but by the figure Synecdoche onely.

They ≈øay that the Night is called Evening no otherwi≈øe, but becau≈øe it is begun of the Evening, and that the artificial day is called Morning no otherwi≈øe, but becau≈øe it is begun of the Morning, and ≈øo by this Expo≈øition they make no other part of time to be called Evening; but a little point of time onely at the beginning of the night, all the re≈øt of the night is called Evening (≈øay they) but by the figure Synecdoche only. In like manner they make no other part of the artificial Day to be called Morning; but a little point of time in the beginning of the artificial day onely, and this Expo≈øition they borrow from Tremelius Annotation on Gen. 1. 5. or rather from Junius, for it is ea≈øie to make it appear, that Tremelius was of another judgement.
An≈ø. A man had need of more patience then ordinary that ≈øhall ≈øpend his time to an≈øwer ≈øuch fanta≈øtical conceits as this. But in brief, I think I have fully confounded this Objection.

1 By proving that Mo≈øes in Gen. 1. 5. divided the fir≈øt natural day into two equall parts two ≈øeveral wayes, as I have exemplified it by the lines of longitude and latitude on a Compa≈ø≈øe Diall in Sect. 4. and ≈øee al≈øo the gradations to the morning in Chap. 3. Sect. 2. at Sixthly.

2 I an≈øwer by proving that Gnereb the Evening is a connexion of the latter halfe of the artificial day to the fir≈øt halfe of the Night, and ≈øo making it to be an equall part of time to Boker the Morning. But the be≈øt way to an≈øwer this, and many
other Objections, is to lay downe the true interpretation of Gnereb, the Evening, in the various u≈øe of it in the Scripture.

I am not ignorant that Gnereb is u≈øually interpreted to ≈øignifie The Hebrew word Gnereb, which is tran≈ølated Evening, in Gen. 1. 5. explained. a mixing, or mingling of things together; but I di≈ølike this interpretation, becau≈øe it is not po≈ø≈øible by this interpretation to find out the true form, & ≈øhape of the Natural Evening, I have therefore made diligent ≈øearch into the various u≈øe of this word, and I finde that Gnereb doth ≈øignifie (not a confu≈øed mixing and mingling of things together, but) a connexing, conjoyning, or coupling of two or more di≈øtinct things together, without confounding their ≈øeverall ≈øpecies, or natures, and therefore Wine and Water mixed together cannot be called Gnereb, neither can the confu≈øed mingling of Light and Darkne≈ø≈øe together (as it is in the Twilight) be called Gnereb, and yet that ≈øhort time of Twilight is comprehended within the large limits of Gnereb, becau≈øe it is the partition of (Gnarbaiim) the two Evenings; but the Twilight it ≈øelfe is ever expre≈ø≈øed by two other ≈øeverall Hebrew words, and never by Gnereb.

The thing I ayme at in this Di≈øcour≈øe is only to clear the true ≈øignification of Gnereb, from a confu≈øed mixing or mingling of things together, and to make it clear and evident, that it only ≈øignifies a conjunction of two or more di≈øtinct things together, and therefore that Gnereb in Gen. 1. 5. mu≈øt ≈øignifie the conjunction of the la≈øt halfe of the Artificiall day to the fir≈øt halfe of the Night, and that the≈øe two di≈øtinct parts connexed are an even and equal portion of time to Boker, the morning.

2. I wil explaine the true meaning of this phra≈øe in Gen. 1. 5. ≈øo was the Evening, and ≈øo was the Morning. Fir≈øt mark the dependence; in the former part of the Ver≈øe, it is ≈øaid, God called the light Day, and the darkne≈ø≈øe he called Night; and then it follows, ≈øo was the Evening; but how was that? was it framed out of the darkne≈ø≈øe only? No, it was framed and formed both out of the ≈øaid Light called Day, and out of the ≈øaid Darkne≈ø≈øe called Night, Conjunctim, and not Divi≈øim, namely, the Evening was framed by conjoyning the latter halfe of the Artificiall
day to the fir≈øt halfe of the Night; and ≈øo was the Morning, namely, it was in like ≈øort framed out of the Darkne≈ø≈øe called Night, and out of the Light called Day, by conjoyning the la≈øt halfe of the Night to the fir≈øt halfe of the Artificiall day: and it is mo≈øt evident that this was the true meaning of Mo≈øes; becau≈øe he doth afterwards explaine Gnereb the ≈øingle Evening, by Gnarbaiim the two Evenings eleaven times over, and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the ful Natural evening hath two parts; namely the fir≈øt halfe is Day, and the latter halfe is Night, as I ≈øhal open the matter more at large, both in this Chapter by and by, and in Chapter the fift.
And from this interpretation of Gnereb, in Gen. 1. 5. the≈øe three Conclu≈øions do follow.

list.item: 1 That the Fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe is not, nor cannot be called Gnereb the Evening.
2 That the whole Night is not, nor cannot be called Gnereb the Evening, in a proper ≈øen≈øe.
3 That the Twilight cannot be called Gnereb the Evening.

div.p: And the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe none of the≈øe three have any di≈øtinct conjunction of ≈øpecies to make them Gnereb; and from this interpretation of Gnereb I frame this Argument.

The fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe by it ≈øelfe con≈øidered cannot be called Gnereb the Evening, neither can the confu≈øed mixture of the Twilight be called Gnereb the Evening, becau≈øe Gnereb doth ≈øignifie (not ≈øuch a mixture as is confu≈øed, but) a connexing, or conjoyning of two or more things together, without confounding their di≈øtinct ≈øpecies; and there are no other di≈øtinct ≈øpecies in Gen. 1. 5. to be conjoyned together, but the Light called Day, and the Darkne≈ø≈øe called Night.

But the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe was pure darkne≈ø≈øe, and no other thing was connexed to it til the Light was created, and that connexion though at the fir≈øt it might have been called Gnereb, yet now it mu≈øt not be called Gnereb, becau≈øe it plea≈øed God to call it Boker, the morning.
Therefore the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe by it ≈øelfe con≈øidered, cannot be called Gnereb the Evening, neither was it framed into any part of the Evening at all.
The A≈ø≈øumption wil not be denied.
The Propo≈øition I prove ≈øeverall wayes.
But fir≈øt I wil begin it by a particular examination of the various u≈øe of the Hebrew word Gnereb thorow out the Scripture.

1 Gnereb is put for the conjunction of two per≈øons together in a contract of Marriage, Ezra 9. 2. P≈øal. 106. 35. it is al≈øo put for the connexion of Iron and Clay in the feet of Nebuchadnezzars Image, Dan. 2. 41. 43. which connexion is expounded to be the joyning together of the Seleucida and the Lagida by Marriages, in Dan. 11. 16, 17. in like ≈øort that Phra≈øe of going in to another by way of Marriage, 1 King. 11. 1, 2. is called Gnereb in the Chalde, and the going in to the Nations, Jo≈øh. 23. 7. is called Gnereb in the Chalde.
The≈øe in≈øtances doe prove that Gnereb is a connexion of two di≈øtinct Per≈øons or Species together, without confounding the Species.

2 Gnereb is put for Merchandi≈øe, becau≈øe of the connexion of ≈øundry ≈øorts of Wares the Merchants u≈øe to joyne together, when they carry them to Faires or Markets to ≈øell, Eze. 27. 17. 19. 25. 27, 31. 34. Gnereb is al≈øo put for Merchants by the Figure Metonymia, either becau≈øe of the ≈øaid connexion of ≈øundry ≈øorts of Wares, or el≈øe becau≈øe of their manifold contracts with other per≈øons, which contracts are u≈øually made by connexing their hands together, Eze. 27. 13.

3 Gnereb is put for things that are ≈øweet, or plea≈øant, by the Figure Synecdoche; it is put for a ≈øweet or plea≈øant voyce, Cant. 2. 14. and for ≈øweet ≈øleep, Prov. 3. 24. Jer. 31. 26. and for other ≈øweet and plea≈øant things, Prov. 13. 19. P≈øal. 104. 34 Jer. 6. 20. Ho≈ø. 9. 4, Mal. 3. 4. but none of the≈øe things can be ≈øaid to be ≈øweet or plea≈øant until they be connexed to ≈øome of the five Sen≈øes, or to ≈øome of the affections of the Soule; as for example, P≈øal. 104. 34. my meditation of him ≈øhal bee ≈øweet, or my meditation ≈øhal be connexed to him, namely, with delightful thoughts.

4 Gnereb is put for a league of amity, or of confederation between two parties, for offence or defence. Eze. 20. 5. Jer. 25. 20, 24. Jer. 50. 37. and in this manner tho≈øe Aegyptians
that joyned them≈øelves to the I≈øraelites at their departure are called Gnereb, Exod. 12. 38. and yet they might ≈øtill be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the I≈øraelites; in like manner after their returne from their Captivity in Babylon, Nehemiah charged the Jewes to ≈øeparate the Heathen people from them, which they had joyned to them in way of Marriage, and they are called Gnereb, Neh. 13. 3.

5 Gnereb is put for the connexion of two parties in a contract of Suerty≈øhip, Gen. 43. 9. Gen. 44. 32. Prov. 11. 15. and in this re≈øpect Gnereb is al≈øo put for an≈øwering to another; namely, as a Surety with another, Prov. 6. 1. and ≈øo Gnarbaiim in the duall number is likewi≈øe put for a contract between two Per≈øons, namely, when two per≈øons doe joyne their hands together in token of a contract, Prov. 22. 26.

And in this re≈øpect al≈øo Gnereb is put for a pledge by a Metonymia of the ≈øigne for the thing ≈øignified, becau≈øe a pledge is given to binde the Covenant or Contract between two Parties, Gen. 38. 17, 18, 20.

Gnereb is al≈øo put for Ho≈øtages, by the Figure Metonymia, becau≈øe Ho≈øtages are given to binde the Covenant, or Contract that is made between two Parties, 2 King. 14. 14. 2 Chro. 25. 24. Gnereb is al≈øo put for a Morgage, by the Figure Metonymia, becau≈øe the thing Morgaged is given to binde the Contract between two parties, Neh. 5. 3.

Al≈øo a derivative of Gnereb is put for wicked per≈øons, that joyne together in a Con≈øpiracy again≈øt lawfull Authority, Prov. 24. 25. My ≈øonne, meddle not with them that are given to change; but it may be better read, Meddle not (by way of a≈ø≈øociation) with them that are Con≈øpirators, for that is a dangerous conjunction.

Gnereb is al≈øo put for any ingagement by way of Covenant, Promi≈øe, or Contract, and in this ≈øen≈øe it is put for the conjunction of Chri≈øts heart, in a ≈øweet Covenant to doe his Fathers wil, for Mans redemption, Jer. 30. 21. Who is this that hath ingaged his heart to approach unto me ≈øaith the Lord, or that hath connexed his heart, namely in a ≈øweet Covenant, to approach unto me ≈øaith the Lord? and in the former clau≈øe Chri≈øt draweth neere unto God for all his ≈øeed.
See Ain≈øw. in P≈øal. 148. 14. Loe I come (≈øaith Chri≈øt) to doe thy will O God, thy Law is in my heart, P≈øal. 40. 8. Heb. 10. 7.

6 Gnereb is put for the woofe of any Cloth, becau≈øe it is connexed to the warp, Lev. 13. 48, 49. 51. 53. 56, 57. 59. but this connexion may ea≈øily be cleared from being a confu≈øed mixture, becau≈øe the plague of Lepro≈øie might be in the Woofe di≈øtinctly, and not in the Warp. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 13. 48.

7 Gnereb is put for a conjunction of ≈øeverall ≈øwarmes of noy≈øome Creatures, which were miraculou≈øly combined together with one con≈øent, to plague the Aegyptians, Exod. 8. 21, 22. 24. 29. 31. P≈øal. 77. 44. P≈øal. 105. 31. Interpretors cannot finde out the ≈øeverall kindes of the≈øe Swarmes, becau≈øe they are not ≈øpecified in the text; but in generall, there were ≈øwarmes of venemous Flies that did plague them in their hou≈øes, and there were ≈øwarmes of venemous Creatures, and ≈øwarmes of ravenous Creatures that did plague them without doores in the Fields, for the twenty fourth ver≈øe doth tell us, that they were plagued in all the parts of the Land; but this conjunction of the≈øe ≈øeverall ≈øorts of ≈øwarmes may ea≈øily bee cleared from confounding their kindes, for out of doubt every kinde of Swarme did keep it ≈øelfe di≈øtinct from confu≈øed mixture with other kindes; Swarmes of Flyes kept by them≈øelves, ≈øwarmes of Serpents by them≈øelves, ≈øwarmes of Wolves, and ≈øwarmes of Lions by them≈øelves, yet all the≈øe Swarmes were connexed together in their endeavours to plague the Aegyptians. By this interpretation there was no confu≈øed mixture among the≈øe Swarmes, as ≈øome doe very unadvi≈øedly expound the word Gnereb in this place to ≈øignifie.
8 Gnereb is put for a De≈øart, or a Wilderne≈ø≈øe, E≈ø. 41. 19. for a thir≈øty land, E≈ø. 35. 7. for a dry land, Jer. 50. 12. Ier. 51. 43. or for an unknown land, Ier. 2. 6.

All the≈øe tran≈ølated termes are Figurative, the continent is put for the connexion of the ≈øeverall things that are contained in it; and our Saviour doth teach us how we mu≈øt connex and couple the things of the Wilderne≈ø≈øe together, in Luke 3. 5. compared with E≈ø. 40. 3‚ñ™ 4. where the things of Gnereb are thus connexed; Mountaines and Hils are connexed to vallies, rough places are connexed to Plaines, or ≈ømooth
ground, and there are divers other connexions in Gnereb the Wilderne≈ø≈øe, for there are divers kindes of wilde Creatures that are connexed together in a Neighbourly cohabitation, without confounding any of their di≈øtinct kindes, as Deut. 8. 15. Mar. 1. 13.

And there are al≈øo ≈øundry ≈øorts of Trees growing in a plea≈øant Neighbour-hood together, in their ≈øeverall borders, E≈ø. 41. 19. and therefore Willow trees are called Gnereb, and Gnarbaiim in the duall number, either becau≈øe of the twyparty coloured leafe, or el≈øe becau≈øe they doe u≈øually grow on both ≈øides of the Brookes in a plea≈øant Neighbour-hood together, E≈ø. 15. 7. Lev. 23. 40.
In Gnereb the De≈øart al≈øo, there is a connexion of many mi≈øeries which doe often fall together on poore Travellours, Ier. 2. 6. with Deut. 8. 15.

And by the Figure Synecdoche any particular thing of the De≈øart may be called Gnereb; as for example, the VVolfe is called the VVolfe of Gnereb, and the VVolfe of Gnaraboth, in the plurall number, Ier. 5. 6. becau≈øe all VVilderne≈ø≈øes are inhabited with VVolfes.

In this regard I cannot but wonder why ≈øome Tran≈ølators doe tran≈ølate, Hab. 1. 8. & Zeph. 3. 3. the VVolfe of the Evening, ≈øeeing Gnereb hath relation to any connexture, either of places, or of per≈øons, or of things, as well as of the two parts of time in the Naturall day, and therefore Gnereb ought not to be tran≈ølated the Evening in any place of the Bible, but in tho≈øe places only that have relation to time, namely to the Evening of the Naturall day; but the VVolfe is not, nor ought not to be called Gnereb in relation to the time of the Evening of the Naturall day, for the VVolfe doth not hunt after his prey more in the Evening than in the Morning, nay he doth rather ≈øeek his prey more in the Morning than in the Evening, as Iacob doth tell us in his allu≈øive Prophe≈øie, Gen. 49. 27. it is fitter therefore to interpret the VVolfe of Gnereb, with relation to the place of his abode, namely to Gnereb the VVilderne≈ø≈øe, rather than to Gnereb the Evening, and in that re≈øpect the ≈øeventy Interpreters, in Hab. 1. 8. and in Zeph. 3. 3. doe call them the VVolves of Arabia, becau≈øe
of the manifold companies, and confederacie that is among them in the De≈øarts of Arabia.

9 Gnereb is put for the Continent it ≈øelfe of Arabia, 2 Chro. 9. 14. becau≈øe in that Continent there were divers ≈øorts of people that had Kings over them that were connexed, combined, and confederated together in leagues offen≈øive, and defen≈øive, and in that re≈øpect they are called the Kings of Gnereb, or the Kings of Arabia, the continent being put for the con≈øederates therein contained, for Arab, in 2 Chron. 9. 14. is written Aereb, in 1 King. 10. 15. which doth properly ≈øignifie a connexed multitude. See Ain≈øw. in Gen. 10. 7. and the Aethiopians in 2 King. 19. 9. and in 2 Chron. 14. 9. 12. are called Cu≈øhites of Arabia, by Sir Wal. Rawley, p. 151. 154.

10 Gnereb is al≈øo put for ≈øeverall ≈øorts of people, that lived in neere cohabitation together in Arabia, E≈ø. 13. 20. and in that re≈øpect the Midianites (becau≈øe they were inhabitants in ≈øome part of Arabia) are called Arabians. See Tremelius in Hab. 3. 7. & in that re≈øpect Mo≈øes his Midianiti≈øh Wife is called an Aethiopian, in Num. 12. 1. and becau≈øe in that continent there lived divers other ≈øorts of people in cohabitation, therefore they are called Gnereb, for there lived the Po≈øterity of Saba and Havilah, of Sab ‚Ä¢ ah, Regmah, and Sabteca, and many others, all which are called Gnereb (or Arabians) that is to ≈øay, a connexed people by a neighbourly cohabitation. See Ain≈øw. in Gen. 10. 7. and in Gen. 37. 25.

11 The Raven al≈øo, and all ≈øorts of Crows are called Gnereb, becau≈øe all the kindes of them are oftentimes connexed together in flocks, and al≈øo becau≈øe ≈øome of their kindes are party-coloured; I have ≈øeen ≈øundry ≈øorts of Crowes together in flocks, and ≈øome of them were party-coloured, namely, white and black like Pyes, and Pyes are a ≈øort of Crowes. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 11. 15.

The≈øe ≈øeverall in≈øtances doe plainly evidence, that Gnereb mu≈øt not be taken for a confu≈øed mixing, or mingling of things together, whereby the di≈øtinct ≈øpecies may be confounded, as wine and water mixed together are, but it mu≈øt be taken for ≈øuch a mixing as is no other but a connexion of di≈øtinct ≈øpecies.

This explanation of Gnereb doth lead us by the hand to the right under≈øtanding of Gnereb in Gen. 1. 5. namely, that it ≈øignifies the connexion of the latter halfe of the Artificiall day with the fir≈øt halfe of the Night; this part of the Naturall day our Ance≈øtors did mo≈øt fitly call the Evening; Fir≈øt, becau≈øe Our Ance≈øtors held Gnereb the Evening to be at all times of the yeare an even and equal part of time to Boker the morning. it was the even or equal part to Boker the morning. And Secondly, our Ance≈øtors held the Evening to be a di≈øtinct and differing portion of time from the time called Night; and indeed experience doth tell us, that the Night is not alwayes an Even part of time to the Artificiall day, that it is many times longer, and many times ≈øhorter than the day; but the Evening as it is taken from mid-day to midnight, is alwayes an even or equal part of time to Boker the Morning, Summer and Winter, all the world over, and therefore our Ance≈øtors could not ≈øo fitly have called the whole night an Evening, in relation to the Artificiall day, as mo≈øt would have them ≈øpeak, though upon better advice they wil now think otherwi≈øe.

Obj. 3. What need is there to make Gnereb comprehend ≈øuch a large portion of time, as is the connexion of the latter halfe of the Artificiall day, to the fir≈øt halfe of the Night; will not that little peece of light which remains after Sun-≈øet, and which is connexed to the Night, ≈øufficiently ≈øerve to make up the true compo≈øition of Gnereb the Evening?

An≈øw. Our di≈øpute did ari≈øe at fir≈øt about the fir≈øt Darkne≈ø≈øe, whether Mo≈øes, in Gen. 1. 5. did call it Gnereb the Evening or no? I told you no, becau≈øe it was pure darkne≈ø≈øe without any connexion of light at the beginning of it, and Gnereb the Evening is often put by the Figure Synecdoche for that halfe of the Evening, called the latter Evening, which doth alwayes begin at Sun-≈øet. when God created the Light to ≈øhine out of Darkne≈ø≈øe, God called that Light (when it had run the cour≈øe of twelve hours) Day, and the fir≈øt halfe of it, with the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe, he did at la≈øt call it Boker the Morning (namely after the whole time of the Naturall day had run its cour≈øe, and after the Darkne≈ø≈øe was formed into a Night.) Hence it followes, that the compo≈øition of Gnereb was formed fir≈øt from the latter halfe of the Artificiall day, and from the fir≈øt halfe of the Night; but that little peece of light that remaines after Sun-≈øet is no part of the Artificiall day (which is due to Gnereb) but it is a true part of the Night, and it is pre≈øently confounded with darkne≈ø≈øe, and it is therefore called Twilight, and therefore it cannot fitly be called Gnereb.
2 I an≈øwer; That ≈øeeing Gnereb is halfe Day and halfe Gnereb the Evening is often by the Figure Synecdoche put for the Sun-≈øet evening, ≈øo it is al≈øo put by the Figure Metonymia for the We≈øt. Night, it often comes to pa≈ø≈øe that any one of the≈øe parts is called Gnereb the Evening, by the Figure Synecdoche, and both parts together is often called the two Evenings; the fir≈øt Evening takes its beginning at mid-day, and the latter Evening begins at Sun-≈øet, which doth alwayes ≈øet due We≈øt when the dayes are in the Equinoctial, and in that re≈øpect our Engli≈øh Tran≈ølators doe put the We≈øt for Gnereb, in Dan. 8. 5. but Tremelius doth there put Sun-≈øet for Gnereb, and the ≈øeventy in that place doe put the South-we≈øt Wind for Gnereb, (and that Wind is one of the foure Winds of Heaven, into which the Kingdome of Alexander was divided after his death, as Daniel prophe≈øied, Dan. 8. 8.) And truly, ≈øeeing the South-we≈øt Wind proceeds indifferently both from the South, and from the We≈øt conjoyned, it doth mo≈øt fitly an≈øwer to the conjunction or connexion of Gnereb; but it is evident that Gnereb is often put for the We≈øt by the Figure Metonymia, 1 Chron. 7. 28. 1 Chron. 12. 15. 1 Chron. 26. 16. 18. 30. and often el≈øewhere, and in this re≈øpect the Twilight is contained within that portion of time which is called Gnereb, but yet the Twilight by it ≈øelfe is never called Gnereb, but two other Hebrew words are u≈øed to expre≈øs the time of Twilight, as I noted afore.

3 Gnereb is Figuratively put by Tran≈ølators for the plaines of Moab, neere Jericho, Num. 33. 48, 49, 50. Numb. 36. 13. Deut. 1. 1. Deut. 11. 30. becau≈øe they lye We≈øt at the ≈øetting of the Sun, where the latter Evening doth begin, but the ≈øeventy in all the ≈øaid places doe put the We≈øt for Gnereb, becau≈øe the ≈øituation of the plaines of Moab lay in the We≈øt part of Canaan, at the going downe of the Sun; from whence the latter evening doth begin; but ≈øee more of this latter evening in chap. 4. in the an≈øwer to Obj. 2.

4 Gnereb the Evening is Figuratively put for the la≈øt times, Gnereb the Evening is often put for the la≈øt dayes, and for the la≈øt end of a thing. Gen. 49. 27. becau≈øe the time of Gnereb the Evening doth follow after the time called Boker the Morning. See more in Chap. 3. in An≈ø. to Obj. 1.

5 Gnereb is Figuratively put for the la≈øt dayes, even for the dayes of the Go≈øpel, called in Zach. 14. 7. the Evening time,
In the Evening time it ≈øhall be light; the allu≈øion is mo≈øt fit and proper to the fir≈øt Evening, which doth alwaies begin at Mid-day, at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun, and then the Sun is in its greate≈øt ≈øtrength both for light and heat; and then Chri≈øt Je≈øus appeared to Paul for his conver≈øion, that he might ≈øend him among the Gentiles that ≈øate in darkne≈ø≈øe, to open their eyes, and to turn them from darkne≈ø≈øe to light, and from the power of Satan to God, Act. 22. 6, 14. Act. 26. 13, 18. and he made the word of God to abound through a great part of the world, even from Jeru≈øalem to Illiricum, Rom. 15. 19. In this evening time of the world, the Go≈øpel did ≈øhine in its ful ≈øtrength, for now Chri≈øt and his twelve Apo≈øtles, and ≈øeventy Di≈øciples, and divers other Prophets and Teachers, did confirme their doctrine with ≈øigns and wonders, to the conver≈øion of many ten thou≈øand ≈øoules that formerly ≈øate in darkne≈ø≈øe under the power of Satan.

6 Gnereb is put for the la≈øt end of a thing, as in I≈øa. 24. 11. The mirth of the land is (Gnereb, that is to ≈øay) cea≈øed or ended; And in this ≈øen≈øe Matthew puts the evening of the Sabbaths (in the plurall number) for the end of the weeke, Mat. 28. 1. for the Jews u≈øed to date all the days of the week from the Sabbath day, in this order, the fir≈øt of the Sabbath, the ≈øecond of the Sabbath, and ≈øo on till the week ended with the Sabbath it ≈øelfe. In like ≈øort they did ≈øometimes call the whole week the Sabbath, and the ≈øeven weekes to Pentico≈øt they called ≈øeven Sabbaths, Levit. 23. 15. and the Phari≈øee ≈øaid, I fa≈øt twice in the Sabbath, Luk. 18. 12. or, twice in the week; now if the Evening had been the beginning of the Natural day, then all the≈øe allu≈øions from Gnereb to the la≈øt times, or to the la≈øt end of a thing, had been very improper and very ab≈øurd.

7 Gnereb, by the figure Synecdoche, is often put for any particular hour in the afternoon, or in the beginning of the night, for the Jews were to tran≈øact many Civil and many Religious actions in the ≈øeverall houres of Gnereb, the Evening, and in that re≈øpect any of tho≈øe houres may be called Gnereb, the Evening: But at fir≈øt when Mo≈øes did conjoyn and ≈øet together all the parts and parcels of the fir≈øt natural day, No que≈øtion but he did u≈øe Gnereb in its full and proper ≈øen≈øe for the conjunction
of the latter half of the Artificial day, with the fir≈øt half of the night, as the even and equal part of time to Boker the morning; and that is the thing which I mainly aime at in all my di≈øcour≈øe upon Gnereb.

div.head: SECT. 2. It is further evident that Gnereb mu≈øt be taken for ≈øuch a connexion of things, as doth ≈øtill pre≈øerve the Species di≈øtinct, becau≈øe Gnarbaiim in the duall number is put for the connexion of any two things without confounding their ≈øpecies; But e≈øpecially it is Eleven times over put for the two parts of the Naturall Evening.
div.p: I Find upon ≈øearch, that Gnereb, the Evening, is eleven times over called Gnarbaiim in the duall number, becau≈øe the God of Nature had from the fir≈øt day divided the natural Evening into two parts, which are rightly called the two Evenings by many Tran≈ølators.

The≈øe two Evenings were famou≈øly known to all the Jewes in Egypt; for when Mo≈øes commanded them to kill the Pa≈ø≈øeover between the two Evenings, Exod. 12. 6. he did not explain what he meant by the two Evenings, he did not make any circum≈øtantiall de≈øcription of them, which had been nece≈ø≈øary if they had not been familiarly acquainted with the ≈øeveral limits of them; but he doth onely barely name them as a thing that was familiarly known to them.

Five times over the Lord commanded them to ≈øacrifi≈øe all their Pa≈ø≈øeovers between the two Evenings, Exod. 12. 6. Levit. 23. 5. Numb. 9. 3, 5, 11. and four times over the Lord commanded them to ≈øacrifi≈øe the daily Evening ≈øacrifice between the two Evenings, Exod. 29. 39, 41. Num. 28. 4, 8.

Solomon Jarchi de≈øcribes the two Evenings thus, from the ≈øixt hour (which is at Mid-day and upwards) it is called between the two Evenings, for that the Sun declineth towards his going down, &c. between the Evening of the Day and the Evening of the Night; The Evening of the Day is from the beginning of the ≈øeventh houre, and the Evening of the Night, is when the night begins, See Ain≈ø. in Num. 9. 3.

And Aben Ezra on Exod. 12. ≈øaith, There is the Evening of the
Sun, and the Evening of the Night, when the ≈øhining of the Sun is gone from off the Earth.
And Rab. David in Perek A ‚Ä¢ oth ch. 5. ≈øaith, There is the Evening of the Suns declining, and the Evening of the Suns ≈øetting.

His meaning is according to other Hebrew Doctors, namely, that the Evening of the Suns declining, begins at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun at Mid-day, and that the Evening of the Suns ≈øetting doth begin then.

And Buxtorfius in his Hebrew Lexicon upon the word Gnarbaiim doth cite other Hebrew Canons to this very purpo≈øe; But I ≈øhall refer you to Chap. 5. for a further de≈øcription of the two Evenings, where I explaine the Pa≈ø≈øeover Evening.

I have already cited nine places of Scripture, where the term of two Evenings is cited in the Hebrew text, and now I will cite two places more: The Prie≈øts were commanded to light up their Lamps between the two Evenings, Exod. 30. 8. and the Quailes came between the two Evenings, Exod. 16. 12. Al≈øo I find one clear example of the two Evenings in the New Te≈øtament, in one and the ≈øame day; It is ≈øaid in Matth. 14. 15. When it was evening the Di≈øciples came to him and ≈øaid, the time is now pa≈øt (that is to ≈øay, it is now pa≈øt dinner time) ≈øend the multitude away; But Chri≈øt did not ≈øend them away untill he had fir≈øt made them dine, and after they had well dined, then he ≈øent them away: After this Evening Chri≈øt went up into a mountain to pray, and then it is ≈øaid againe, When the Evening was come, hee was there alone, ver. 23. This Evening in ver. 23. is another Evening be≈øides that in ver≈ø. 15. and between the≈øe two Evenings Chri≈øt did a long action, for he fed many thou≈øands plentifully; And thus I have proved by a Jury of twelve Witne≈ø≈øes that the naturall Evening is divided into two Evenings, and I have ≈øet out the limits of the fir≈øt Evening by the te≈øtimony of the Hebrew Doctors from Mid-day till Sun-≈øet, and the latter Evening begins at Sun-≈øet, and ends at mid-night, and both the≈øe Evenings are called Gnarbaiim in the duall number; that is ≈øay, the Twy-party Evening; for ≈øo Gnarbaiim in the duall number mu≈øt be under≈øtood, as it appears by the like form of ≈øpeech, where the Scripture ≈øetteth out the twy-party connexture of other things, as for example, Ramath in mount Ephraim, 1 Sam. 1. 19.
is called Ramothaim in the dual number, 1 Sam. 1. 1. ≈øome Tran≈ølators render it the two Ramaths in mount Ephraim, but indeed they are deceived, for there is but one Ramath in Mount Ephraim, and that Ramath is called Ramothaim in the dual number, becau≈øe it had two parts, and ≈øo Jeru≈øalem is u≈øually called Jeru≈øalaim in the duall number, 2 Sam 5. 6, 7. P≈øal. 51. 18. not becau≈øe there were two Jeru≈øalems, but becau≈øe the City Jeru≈øalem had two principal parts; for fir≈øt, There was the City of the people on the one part; and ≈øecondly, There was the City of David and mount Zion on the other part; but neither of the≈øe parts alone could properly be called the City of Jeru≈øalem, but both parts mu≈øt be put together to make up the full City Jeru≈øalem; and in this re≈øpect it might well be called the double Jeru≈øalem, or the twy-party Jeru≈øalem; the like may be ≈øaid of Ramothaim, for there was but one City in Mount Ephraim that was called Ramath, as ver≈ø. 19. tels us, But this City was called Ramothaim in the duall number, becau≈øe it had two principall parts. Fir≈øt, There was the City of the people on the one part; And ≈øecondly, There was Naioth in Ramath on the other part where the High place was, and where Samuel dwelt, and kept a Prophets School, 2 Sam. 19. 18, 19. But neither of the≈øe parts could properly be called the full City Ramath, but both of them together did make up the full City Ramath. So al≈øo Diblath, Ezek. 6. 14. is Diblathaim, Jerm. 48. 22. And ≈øo Gnereb the Evening is ≈øometimes called Gnarbaiim the two Evenings, but neither of tho≈øe two Evenings taken a part can properly be called Gnereb the full naturall Evening, as it is meant in Gen. 1. 5. but both of them put together do make up the full natural Evening; and in this re≈øpect Gnarbaiim may be tran≈ølated the twofold evening or the twy-party evening, as well as the two Evenings, becau≈øe indeed there is but one naturall Evening, which is divided by the time of Sun≈øet into two principall parts. It is therefore but a woodden ≈øhift of ≈øome Scholars to call the fir≈øt Evening an improper Evening, and to call the latter Evening onely the full naturall Evening: The like woodden ≈øhift it is to make no other part of time to be called Gnereb properly, but the very beginning of the Night, or of the later Evening onely, as ≈øome do interpret Junius Annotation on Gen. 1. 5. to ≈øpeak.

2. If the Holy Spirit had framed Gnarbaiim, to ≈øet out both a
proper and an improper Evening with one and the ≈øame voice and breath, then doubtle≈ø≈øe the ≈øeventy Tran≈ølators being Hebrew The ≈øeventy Interpreters do make the two Evenings to be but one proper Evening. Doctors would have found it out, and then they would have de≈øcribed the various acceptation of the word, by ≈øome marke of di≈øtinction or other, e≈øpecially con≈øidering they took liberty to vary the terme of their tran≈ølation from Gnarbaiim, for they do never fully expre≈ø≈øe the term Gnarbaiim the two Evenings in any place, but nine times over they tran≈ølate it by the ≈øingle term Evening, and therefore if they had accounted the fir≈øt part of it to have been an improper Evening, and the latter part onely proper, then doubtle≈ø≈øe they would ≈øomewhere or other have given ≈øome mark of di≈øtinction whereby to know them a≈øunder, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing they take liberty to alter the phra≈øe; But it ≈øeems to me they accounted both the parts of Gnarbaiim to be but one proper naturall Evening, becau≈øe they do nine times over tran≈ølate Gnarbaiim by the ≈øingle term Evening. I confe≈ø≈øe they doe once after a ≈øort ≈øet out the two parts of Gnarbaiim in Lev. 23. 5. for there the Seventy read the Text thus. In the fourteenth day of the month, between the middle of tho≈øe things that belong to the Evening; in this tran≈ølation they doe not fully name the two Evenings, but yet after a ≈øort they doe name the two Evenings, becau≈øe they ≈øay between the middle of tho≈øe things that belong to the Evening; their meaning mu≈øt be this, In the beginning of the Pa≈ø≈øeover Evening, they in the fir≈øt place did offer the daily evening Sacrifice, burne Incen≈øe, trim the Lamps, &c. Secondly, As ≈øoon as the latter evening was come (which did, alwaies begin at Sun-≈øet) they began to fea≈øt upon the fle≈øh of their Pa≈ø≈øeovers, and of their Peace-offerings, in a ≈øolemn religious manner: Now between, or in the middle of the≈øe things all their Pa≈ø≈øeovers were ≈øacrificed. And thus by this Interpretation it appears evidently that the ≈øeventy Tran≈ølators held Gnarbaiim to be but one proper naturall evening divided into two princiall parts, becau≈øe they called that which was done between the two evenings, the middle of the evening in the ≈øingular number. Therefore I may well conclude, that their di≈øtinction is ab≈øurd, that make the fir≈øt part of Gnarbaiim to be no more but an improper evening, and that make the latter part onely proper. I think no man that is well advi≈øed can find any harmony in the Scripture by this Interpretation.

3. It is al≈øo evident that Gnereb the Evening, is as large in length of time as Gnarbaiim the two Evenings is; for not onely The Hebrew text doth make the two Evenings to be but one proper Evening. the Seventy do tran≈ølate Gnarbaiim, by the ≈øingle term Evening; but the Hebrew Text it ≈øelfe doth often put Gnereb for Gnarbaiim interchangeably, as for example, four places of Scripture doe command them to offer the daily evening Sacrifice between the two evenings, but many more places ≈øay it ≈øhould be done or ≈øacrificed in Gnereb the evening; five places command all the Pa≈ø≈øeovers to be ≈øacrificed between the two evenings, but more places ≈øay it ≈øhall be done or ≈øacrificed in Gnereb the evening; one place ≈øaith, that the Prie≈øts mu≈øt cau≈øe the Lamps to burne between the two evenings, but other places ≈øay in the evening; one place ≈øaith the Quailes came between the two evenings, but other places ≈øay they came in Gnereb the evening: Therefore Gnereb and Gnarbaiim is but one proper evening; Gnereb is as large in time as Gnarbaiim is, both parts together make up the true and proper naturall evening called Gnereb.

Hence I conclude, that the Hebrew word Gnereb doth not The two parts of Gnereb exemplified. ≈øignifie ≈øuch a confu≈øed mixture as is between light and darkne≈ø≈øe in the Twilight; but it ≈øignifies ≈øuch a di≈øtinct connexion of Day and Night together, as may be called Gnarbaiim, the two evenings, and ≈øuch a connexion as may be di≈øtingui≈øhed or ≈øevered from each other into two di≈øtinct parts: as I may exemplifie the matter by a party-coloured coat, one half is white and the other halfe is black; ≈øo is Gnereb the evening, the fir≈øt halfe is white called day, and the other halfe is black called night, and the time of Twilight that couples the≈øe two evenings together, may be likened to the ≈øeam that couples the white and black peeces together for the compleating of the party-coloured coat. Or thus, the two parts of Gnereb may be exemplified by the cloud that ≈øtood between the I≈øraelites and the Egyptians; the one halfe of the cloud was light towards the I≈øraelites, and the other halfe was dark towards the Egyptians, Exod. 14. 20. So is Gnereb, the natural evening, the fir≈øt halfe is light called day, and the other half is dark called night.

div.head: SECT. III. Proving by ≈øeven demon≈øtrative grounds, that the Naturall Evening begins at Mid-day at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun.
div.p: THe fir≈øt Scripture by which I prove that the Natural Evening doth begin at Mid-day, at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun, is from Jeremy, who≈øe ≈øpeech is both plain and elegant, Jeremy ≈øpeaks thus in the per≈øon of the Babylonian Souldiers, Ari≈øe, let us go up at noon; woe unto us, for the day declineth, and the ≈øhadowes of the evening are ≈øtretched out, Jer. 6. 4. The≈øe words are ≈øpoken by way of allu≈øion; but yet two phra≈øes are remarkable in this Text. 1. The day declineth. 2. The ≈øhadowes of the evening are ≈øtretched out; both the≈øe termes are Synonima, and mean the ≈øame time of the day; for as ≈øoon as the day begins to decline, the ≈øhadowes of the evening begin to be ≈øtretched out. Hence then it follows, 1. That the evening doth begin as ≈øoon as the day begins to decline. 2. That the ≈øhadowes of the evening do begin to ≈øtretch them≈øelves as ≈øoon as the ≈øun which rules the day, doth begin fir≈øt to decline.

Jeremy ≈øpeaks the≈øe words in the per≈øon of the Babylonian Souldiers who made ha≈øte to de≈øtroy the Jewes by the Noon-tide, but when they were upon their march they ≈øaw they were like to come ≈øhort of the appointed time, and therefore they cry out in an angry pa≈ø≈øion, Woe unto us, for the day declineth, and the ≈øhadowes of the evening are ≈øtretched out. The Prophet ≈øpeaks this
by way of Pro≈øopopeia; yet there mu≈øt be a reall truth in the allu≈øion.

Secondly, I prove that the natural Evening begins at Mid-day, at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun, by Matth. 14. 15. When the Evening was come; Luke expounds this evening to be come, when the day began to go down or decline, Luk. 9. 12. So Mr. Broughton renders the Text: And when el≈øe doth the day fir≈øt begin to go down or decline, but when the Sun that rules the Day doth fir≈øt begin to go down or decline? as is above ob≈øerved from Jer. 6. 4. And experience doth tell us, that the Sun doth fir≈øt begin to decline at mid-day, and that it continues declining till Sun-≈øet; So then, from the term Evening in Matthew de≈øcribed by this adjunct in Luke, when the day begins to go down or decline, it may truly be gathered by nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence, that the natural evening doth begin at mid-day, at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun; and this evening hath two parts, the fir≈øt part begins at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun, as I have already expounded, v. 15. and another evening doth begin at Sun-≈øet, in v. 23.

Thirdly, I prove that the full natural evening begins at mid-day, at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun, by Deut. 16. 6. Thou ≈øhalt ≈øacrifice the Pa≈ø≈øeover at Evening, at the going down of the Sun, at the ≈øea≈øon thou came≈øt out of Egypt. This Text is very pregnant to prove the point in que≈øtion; but becau≈øe I have occa≈øion to expound this Text at large in chap. 5. Therefore I refer the Reader thither.

Fourthly, I prove that the full natural Evening begins at mid-day by 1 Sam. 20. 5. David doth there intreat Jonathan to meet him on the third day at Even, and it appears that Jonathan was very careful to ob≈øerve the punctual beginning of this appointed evening, becau≈øe it was a matter of weight, and becau≈øe David depended upon his punctual ob≈øervation of the preci≈øe time, therefore Jonathan did confirm his promi≈øe by an oath, ver. 13. be≈øides, David did over and above all this charge Jonathan to come to him quickly or diligently, that is to ≈øay, to be exact, and to keep the appointed time diligently or punctually, and accordingly Jonathan did manife≈øt his diligence to ob≈øerve the punctual time, as it is evident, becau≈øe he went out into the field on the third day in the Morning, which (≈øaith the Text) was at the time appointed with David, v. 35.

Object, 4. How can you make Jonathans Morning to be the appointed time with David, ≈øeeing David did not appoint Jonathan to meet him on the third day in the morning, but on the third day at even, as v. 5. te≈øtifieth?

An≈øw. Jonathans morning was the appointed time with David, becau≈øe Jonathans morning did end at mid-day, and Davids evening did begin at mid-day, at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun: now Jonathan could not have come quickly, diligently, exactly and punctually to the place appointed at the beginning of the evening, unle≈ø≈øe he went out on the third day morning, that is to ≈øay, a little before the evening began; but by his diligence in taking in a little peece of the morning at the beginning of his Journey, he might well be at the place appointed according to the punctuall time of the appointed Evening; and thus Jonathans Morning and Davids Evening do meet together at Mid-day, and no other re≈øolution can be given, as I conceive, to make Jonathans morning and Davids evening to agree together at one and the ≈øame appointed time but this.

Object. 5. Why may not the appointed evening be under≈øtood of the night-evening, and the appointed place be a great way off, and in that re≈øpect Jonathan might begin his journey in the morning, that ≈øo he might come to the place appointed at the time of the Sun-≈øet evening?

An≈øw. I perceive that men are loath to have any other evening, but the night-evening, and therefore they are willing to rai≈øe what Objections they can again≈øt the mid-day evening: But I will give you divers Rea≈øons why the appointed evening cannot be meant of the Sun-≈øet evening.

Fir≈øt, If the place of meeting had been ≈øo far off as to cau≈øe Jonathan to ≈øpend ≈øo much time in going thither as from morning till Sun-≈øet, then Jonathan could not have had time enough left to return back again into the City in the ≈øame day. But the Text in ver. 23. doth tell us that Jonathan did return the ≈øame day into the City; therefore the appointed evening cannot be under≈øtood of the ≈øun-≈øet evening.

Secondly, Jonathan returned alone without any company with him, for he had ≈øent his Boy back into the City before, which in rea≈øon he would not have done, if the place of meeting had been ≈øo far off as you make it.

Thirdly, Jonathan knew that Saul was jealous of his familiarity with David, and he knew al≈øo that Saul was much inraged again≈øt David at this time; Therefore in wi≈ødom Jonathan would not be ≈øo long ab≈øent from Saul as from morning till Sun-≈øet; nay, it would have been Mid-night ere he could have returned, if the place appointed to meet at had been ≈øo far off as you would make it, and then Soul might well have ≈øu≈øpected that Jonathan might have had ≈øome other errand into the field be≈øides ≈øhooting at a mark, by his long and late ab≈øence; but Ionathan pretended no other errand but to ≈øhoot at a mark, and therefore he took his Boy with him to witne≈ø≈øe ≈øo much if need ≈øhould be.

1. Hence it followes, that the place of meeting was but a little way without the City; for what need had a man goe farre to ≈øhoot at a Mark? and ≈øo it asked but a little time to goe to it, and to return from it.

2 Hence it followes, that the appointed Evening mu≈øt be under≈øtood of the Mid-day Evening, and not of the Sun-≈øet Evening: And thus Jonathans Morning and Davids Evening did fitly agree to the ≈øame appointed hour at Mid-day.

In like ≈øort one Evangeli≈øt ≈øaith that Chri≈øt was crucified at the third houre, Mark. 15. 25. But John ≈øaith he was crucified at the ≈øixt hour, Joh. 19. 14. this differing relation of time, may ≈øeem to have as great a difference as is between Jonathans Morning and Davids Evening, and yet there is no difference at all when things come to be rightly expounded: For the Jewes divided the Artificiall Day into four great Hours, ju≈øt as they divided the Night into four great Watches, Mark. The Jews divided the day into four great hours, as they divided the night into four watches. 13. 35. every great hour contained in it three ≈ømall houres; The fir≈øt great hour they called by the name of the third hour, becau≈øe it ended with the third ≈ømall hour, which we call nine a clock; and their ≈øecond great hour they called their ≈øixt, becau≈øe it ended with the ≈øixt ≈ømall hour, which we call twelve a clock; and thus as ≈øoon as the fir≈øt great hour ended with our nine a clock, the ≈øecond great hour began with our ten a clock: And thus Peter Martyr in the Judges, Mr. Godwin, and Mr. Weames, do accord the≈øe great hours with our ≈ømall hours, and ju≈øt after this ≈øort the end of Jonathans Morning in v. 35. and the beginnings of Davids Evening in v. 5. do fitly clo≈øe and meet together at Mid-day.

Fifthly, I prove that the naturall Evening doth begin at Mid-day, by Jo≈øh. 7. 6. There Jo≈øhua and the Elders fell down upon the Earth before the Ark of the Lord till Even-tide, that is to ≈øay until Evening began.
Object. 6. This Even-tide mu≈øt be under≈øtood of the Sun-≈øet Evening.

An≈øw. I an≈øwer no, it cannot be under≈øtood of the Sun-≈øet Evening, for Jo≈øhua had much bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to doe after this, which mu≈øt be done before the time of Sun≈øet, for the Lord commanded Jo≈øhua to ≈øanctifie the people again≈øt the morrow, Ver≈ø. 13, 14. But Jo≈øhua could not ≈øanctifie them at the Sun-≈øet Evening, for then the day of their cleanne≈ø≈øe mu≈øt begin, by the order of the Leviticall Law; they mu≈øt therefore be wa≈øhed from their defilements in the afternoon, or el≈øe they could not begin the day of their cleanne≈ø≈øe at their Sun-≈øet Evening; and in ca≈øe they did not begin the new day of their cleanne≈ø≈øe at Sun-≈øet, they might not come before the Lords Arke on the morrow to beg Attonement for Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors, as I have opened the matter more at large in Chap. 4.

Now Jo≈øhua could not have ≈øanctified the people in a fit manner to come before the Lords Ark on the morrow, if he had lain ≈øtill upon the earth till the Even-tide at Sun-≈øet; for Jo≈øhua mu≈øt have a large time to inform all the people by a Proclamation through all the Camp, what was the cau≈øe of the Lords anger, and what they mu≈øt do by way of preparation before they could obtain the Lords favour: The thing they mu≈øt do by way of preparation was to ≈øanctifie them≈øelves from their Ceremonial defilements, by wa≈øhing their Bodies and their Cloaths according to the Ceremonial cu≈øtoms, as they are ≈øet down in Exod. 19. 10. Gen. 35. 2. and this mu≈øt be done in the ≈øame Even-tide wherein the Lord ≈øpake to Jo≈øhua and to the Elders, ≈øaying, ∆≤p, and ≈øanctifie the people, and ≈øay, ≈øanctifie your ≈øelves again≈øt to morrow, Ver≈ø. 13. Now then con≈øider the time that mu≈øt be taken up for this Proclamation throughout all the Camp, and con≈øider the time they mu≈øt have for the wa≈øhing of all their Bodies and their Cloaths before Sun-≈øet, and then it will nece≈ø≈øarily force us to under≈øtand this Even-tide of the Noon-tide Evening, and not of the Sun-≈øet Evening.

Sixthly, I prove, That the full naturall Evening begins at Mid-day when the Afternoon begins, becau≈øe the Evening in Scripture is often put for the Afternoon, as the morning is put for the Forenoon: In the morning ≈øow thy ≈øeed, and in the Evening let not thy hand re≈øt, Eccle≈ø. 11. 6. Solomons meaning is, that men ≈øhould be as diligent in doing good at all times, as the Husbandman is in ≈øeed-time; he will not re≈øt from ≈øowing his ≈øeed neither Forenoon nor afternoon, becau≈øe he knows not which will prove be≈øt. A wi≈øe and diligent Husband-man will go out to ≈øow his ≈øeed in the afternoon Evening, and not defer it till the Sun-≈øet Evening; therefore by Solomons account the Evening begins with the Afternoon at Mid-day.

2. It is ≈øaid P≈øal. 90. 6. In the morning the gra≈ø≈øe flouri≈øheth and groweth up, but in the evening it is cut down and withereth: The Hu≈øbandman doth not u≈øe to go out to mow his gra≈ø≈øe in the evening after Sun-≈øet, or if he ≈øometimes do ≈øo, yet it doth not wither in the evening after Sun-≈øet; But Husbandmen u≈øe to take the opportunity to mow their gra≈ø≈øe in the afternoon, and then it withereth, therefore the Evening begins with the afternoon.

3. It is ≈øaid in 1 Sam. 17. 16. that Goliah drew near Morning and Evening forty days together: But Souldiers doe not u≈øe to call for a Pitched Battle in the evening after Sun-≈øet, but either in the Forenoon or in the Afternoon Evening.

4. It is ≈øaid 1 King 17. 6. That the Ravens brought bread and fle≈øh to Elijah morning and evening: but the Ravens do not u≈øe to carry meat in the evening after Sun-≈øet, for then they u≈øe to flie to their Roo≈øt, and ≈øo to continue there all night; Therefore the Ravens carried meat to Elijah in the Afternoon Evening.

Seventhly, Paul ≈øent for the Jews in Rome to come to his Iodging that he might te≈øtifie unto them the things of the Kingdome of God, and that he might per≈øwade them concerning Je≈øus, and they came at the day appointed, and then Paul preached unto them from morning till evening, Act. 28. 23. But I think no deliberate man will ≈øay that Paul continued his Sermon to that mixed multitude from the morning light, till the evening at Sun-≈øet: The hungry bellies and captious ≈øpirits of mo≈øt of the≈øe Jewes would not indure it; neither would Pauls wi≈ødom nor
his ≈øtrength ≈øuffer him to offer it, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing the Jewes of this Synagogue had before-hand manife≈øted to Paul their di≈ølike of this Sect, ver≈ø. 22.

The≈øe circum≈øtances con≈øidered, this phra≈øe from morning till evening mu≈øt be under≈øtood of a convenient portion of time for one Sermon. It is like they came to Pauls lodging at the ordinary houre wherein they u≈øed to re≈øort to their Synagogues, about nine a clock in the morning, and it is like al≈øo that Paul continued his Sermon to them till the Noon-tide evening, a little more or le≈ø≈øe, as in wi≈ødom he thought it convenient, all circum≈øtances con≈øidered, and in likelihood the Jews would not appoint to meet at Pauls lodging before the ordinary hour of morning prayer, nor be contented to ≈øtay longer than Dinner-time, when the Evening begins, at Mid-day; therefore it may be gathered by probable conjecture, that the evening began at Mid-day in Rome as well as in Iudea.
The fir≈øt Naturall Day is divided two ≈øeveral ways by Mo≈øes in Gen. 1. 5.
1 Into Day and Night by the Line of Longitude.
2 Into Evening and Morning by the Line of Latitude.

figure.p: The midle of the night the midle of the day. E≈øa 16.3

div.p: The Hebrew word Gnereb in Gen. 1. 5. was well tran≈ølated the Evening by our Ance≈øtors, becau≈øe it is a connexture of ≈øo much Day and Night together as makes up an even and equal part of time to Boker the morning. And ≈øecondly, Becau≈øe the Natural Evening is half Day and half Night, therefore Mo≈øes doth eleven times over call it the two Evenings, as it is noted in Chap. 2. Sect. 2.

div.head: SECT. 4. Bring a De≈øcription of the twofold Divi≈øion of the fir≈øt Naturall Day, how and in what order every part of it was ≈øhaped, named and framed together.
div.p: THe fir≈øt Natural day in Gen. 1. 5, was twice divided by Mo≈øes, ju≈øt according to the Lines of Longitude and Latitude in the Globe, and it was ≈øhaped and framed together in this order.
Take a peece of paper and pourtray upon it the ≈øhape or image of a compa≈ø≈øe Dial. Then fir≈øt ≈øhadow out upon it the fir≈øt darkne≈øs from the North point almo≈øt to the Ea≈øt point.
2. Then ≈øhadow out a little peece of Twilight to fill it up to the Ea≈øt point, as a ≈øign that the light did thence break out of darkne≈ø≈øe by degrees.
3. Then ≈øhadow out a peece of light of ≈øix hours long, for the a≈øcending of the ≈øhining light from the Ea≈øt point to the South point.
4. Then make a mark of di≈øtinction at the South point for the ≈øtanding ≈øtill of the light for a little while at Mid-day.
5. Then ≈øhadow out another peece of light of ≈øix hours long for the declining of the light from the South point to the We≈øt point.

6 Then write upon all this ≈øhining light from the Ea≈øt point to the We≈øt point, the name Day, as the proper name of his perfect ≈øhape and limit; and in this order was the fir≈øt Artificiall Day ≈øhaped out, limited, and named.
7. Then ≈øhadow out a little peece of Twilight, at the departure of the light out of that Horizon, on the in≈øide of the We≈øt point.
8. Then take twelve hours darkne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øhadow out the fir≈øt half of that Darkne≈ø≈øe from the We≈øt point untill it meet with the place of the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe at the North point.

9. Then write upon all that Darkne≈ø≈øe from the We≈øt point to the Ea≈øt point, the name Night, as the proper name of its perfect ≈øhape and limit, and in this order was the night la≈øt ≈øhaped out, limited and named. Then let the other half of the la≈øt twelve hours Darkne≈ø≈øe be ≈øet upon the out-≈øide of the ≈øame Compa≈ø≈øe Diall, from the North point to the Ea≈øt point, for the beginning of the ≈øecond Day.

10. Hence we may ob≈øerve the Rea≈øon why the fir≈øt Darknes could not be called Night at fir≈øt, namely, becau≈øe it wanted the form and limits of a Night, for it wanted the ≈øhape of a twilight going before it, and therefore until it had obtained that, it was called nothing el≈øe but confu≈øed darknes, and it could not have this form til the la≈øt period of time belonging to the night was fini≈øhed; and it could not have that period till the fir≈øt half of that twelve houres darkne≈ø≈øe ≈øucceeding the Artificial Day had met with the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe at the North point, and that conjunction occa≈øioned a mark of di≈øtinction in the middle of the night.
11. By the≈øe marks of di≈øtinction, the true Form and Figure of the two Lines of Longitude and Latitude, from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, and from North to South, were clearly marked out.

12. By this Line of divi≈øion from Mid-day to Mid-night the Natural Day was again divided into two equal parts (in a differing manner from the divi≈øion of the Day from the Night) the fir≈øt half from Mid-day to Mid-night was called Gnereb, the Evening, and the other half from Mid-night to Mid-day was called Boker, the Morning,
13. After this ≈øort hath the God of Nature halfed and quartered the Natural day by the Lines of Longitude and Latitude.

14 By this method the God of Nature hath not only made the natural day to be a twiparty day, con≈øi≈øting of light, and darkne≈øs; But al≈øo Secondly, He hath made the Artificial Day to be a twiparty day, becau≈øe he hath made the one half of it to belong unto the Morning, and the other half of it to belong unto the Evening. Thirdly, He hath al≈øo made the Night to be a twiparty Night, becau≈øe he hath made the one half of it to belong unto the Evening, and the other half of it to belong unto the morning. And in this regard the night is ≈øometimes called nights in the plural number, P≈øal. 134. 1. P≈øal. 92. 2. Fourthly, He hath al≈øo made the Natural Evening to be a twiparty evening, becau≈øe it is a connexion of the latter half of the Day, to the fir≈øt half of the Night; and in this re≈øpect it is called Gnereb, a connexion, and ≈øometimes it is called Gnarbaiim, the two Evenings, becau≈øe of the two parts of it. Fifthly, He hath al≈øo made the Natural Morning to be a twiparty Morning, becau≈øe it is a connexion of the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe, or of the latter half of the night, with the fir≈øt half of the Artificial day, and in this re≈øpect it is often called Mornings in the
plural number, P≈øal. 73. 14. P≈øal. 101. 8. Job 7. 18. Lam. 3. 23. I≈ø. 33. 2.

15. The Rea≈øon why the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe could not be called either Boker the Morning, or Gnereb the Evening, at fir≈øt, was, becau≈øe the≈øe names are names of the perfect ≈øhape and limits given unto the≈øe two parts of the Natural day; and the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe was a confu≈øed mi≈ø-≈øhapen thing at fir≈øt, therefore it could not belong either unto the Morning or unto the Evening, until it was fir≈øt ≈øhaped and limited into a night; for Boker the Morning is con≈øtituted of a part of the ≈øhaped Night, as well as of a part of the ≈øhaped Artificial Day; and the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe could not be ≈øhaped into a Night until it had twelve houres darkne≈ø≈øe ≈øucceeding the Artificial Day, by means whereof the fir≈øt half had a Twilight going before it, and then as ≈øoon as it met with the fir≈øt darkne≈ø≈øe at the North point, it Fir≈øt gave perfection of ≈øhape to the Night. And Secondly, It gave perfection of ≈øhape to the Evening. And thirdly, It gave perfection of ≈øhape to Boker the Morning.

And accordingly, every part of this day had its name as ≈øoon as it had its perfect ≈øhape; as for example, when the ≈øhining light had fini≈øhed its la≈øt period at the We≈øt point, it was called Day; in like ≈øort, when the darkne≈ø≈øe had fini≈øhed its la≈øt period at the North point, it was called Night: And then al≈øo the Evening and the Morning was the Fir≈øt Day.

Pharez and Zara were Twins, and when they came to their Birth, Zara thru≈øt out his hand fir≈øt, thereupon the Midwi≈øe ≈øaid this is fir≈øt, and ≈øhe did mark it out for the fir≈øt by a red thred; yet notwith≈øtanding Pharez did fini≈øh his Birth fir≈øt, and therupon he was fir≈øt named Pharez, and Zara was la≈øt named though he begun his Birth fir≈øt: Even ≈øo, the time called Morning began its birth fir≈øt, but yet notwith≈øtanding the time called Evening was fir≈øt perfected in its ≈øhape and limits, and thereupon it was fir≈øt called Gnereb.

p.hi: O the wonderfull variety of Gods wi≈ødom in contriving and ≈øetting together all the parts and parcels of this fir≈øt Natural Day!

div.head: CHAP. III. Proving that the time of the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs was called Morning at la≈øt, namely as ≈øoon as that Darkne≈øs was formed into a Night.
div.p: Mo≈øes doth tell us, Gen. 1. 1, 2. That in the beginning God created the Heaven and the Earth, and that darkne≈øs was upon the face of the deep, namely for the ≈øpace of ≈øix hours, before the light was created.
The Que≈øton is, Whether this fir≈øt Darkne≈øs was called Morning or Evening.
The An≈øwer ≈øhall be framed into three Heads or Sections.

list.item: I. I will prove that the Creation began in that part of time which at la≈øt was called Boker, the Morning.
II. That the Morning begins in the dark Night.
III. That the Morning doth begin at Mid-night.

div.head: SECT. I. Proving that the time of the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs was called Boker, the Morning, at la≈øt.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, It appears to me that the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs was called Boker,
Boker the morning doth ≈øignifie early. the Morning, at la≈øt; namely, as ≈øoon as all the parts of the Natural Day were formed: Becau≈øe Boker, (the Morning) doth ≈øignifie Early, See Ain≈ø. in P≈øal. 5. 4. and in this ≈øen≈øe the Morning is put for the fir≈øt opportunity of time for any bu≈øine≈øs, as in ≈øeeking unto God early by prayer, and in this ≈øen≈øe David ≈øaith in P≈øa. 5. 3. Jehovah, in the morning (or early) I will direct my prayer unto thee, and will look out (or e≈øpie) as he that keepeth watch and ward expecting what God will an≈øwer; and the godly do often profe≈ø≈øe, that they will look out early after God (by the term Morning) as in P≈øal. 90. 14. and P≈øal. 143. 8. and truly I conceive, that the onely Rea≈øon why Buls and Cows, And all the Herds of that kind are called Baker (from whence Boker is derived) is from their early ≈øeeking out for their meat from God, ≈øooner than other Cattle u≈øe to do: for in the Evening or in the beginning
of the Night they u≈øe to ≈øit down and chew their Cud, but in the early Night-morning, they u≈øually ri≈øe up and ≈øeek out for food before other ≈øorts of Cattle.

Object. 1. Boker, the Morning, is put for the beginning of the Artificiall Day, becau≈øe that is the fitte≈øt ≈øea≈øon to ≈øeek out or (earth after things that be lo≈øt, or after things that are to be ≈øought after; men do not u≈øually ≈øeek after things in the dark, but as ≈øoon as the morning light appears, then they begin to look and ≈øearch after lo≈øt things, and hence the beginning of the Artificiall Day is called Boker, the Morning.

An≈øw.
