I ≈øee no Rea≈øon to re≈øtrain the ≈øignification of Boker to mans ≈øeeking by the ≈øight of his eyes, in the time of the Artificial Morning onely, but con≈øidering that Boker, the Morning, is placed among the works of Gods Creation before man was created, it may be con≈øidered as Gods fir≈øt early time in ordering the Creation in the be≈øt manner; for God may be ≈øaid to ≈øeek early (after the manner of men) not for want of knowledge in particulars, but to ≈øet out his Wi≈ødom and Prudence, and Fatherly care, and the like, in the fir≈øt Creation, as the≈øe Scriptures do te≈øtifie, Exod. 14. 24. 27. Ezek. 34. 11, 12, 16. P≈øa. 30. 6. P≈øa. 90. 14. I≈øa. 17. 14. P≈øal. 119. 176. Zach. 12. 9.

For by Wi≈ødom the Lord founded the Earth, and by ∆≤nder≈øtanding he e≈øtabli≈øhed the Heavens, Prov. 3. 19. and ≈øo by Wi≈ødom and Under≈øtanding he formed all the parts of the Fir≈øt Day, in ≈øuch an exqui≈øite Order, that ≈øo it might be for an exemplary pattern to all the other Natural daies to the end of the world. Secondly, Early ≈øeeking may be done by advice, coun≈øel, and meditation, as well in the time of darkne≈ø≈øe, as in the morning light. Thirdly, When it plea≈øed the Lord to uncreat Judah by his de≈øtroying Judgements (namely, by wars from the Enemy) how did God order it to be done? but by his early looking out and ≈øearching into things; For thus ≈øaith the Lord, I looked upon the Earth, and loe it was without form and void, and to the Heavens, and they had no light, Jer. 4. 23. for by their wicked confu≈øed Government they had provoked the Lord by wars to turn all their Commonwealth into a Chaos again. This form of ≈øpeech (by contraries) declares that God by his wi≈øe Providence did ≈øearch out in the time of the fir≈øt darkne≈øs how to adorn the earth with light, and how to order all the parts of the fir≈øt day in the be≈øt manner, and in this re≈øpect Gods early Providence is often ≈øet out by the term Morning, both in
regard of his early Judgements upon a people, and al≈øo in regard Boker, the Morning, is put for Gods early ≈øeeking either to puni≈øh the wicked or protect the godly. of his early Pre≈øervation of his own people.

1. His early and ≈øpeedy Judgements upon the wicked are ≈øet out by the term Morning, in Num. 16. 5. Zeph. 3. 5. P≈øal. 73. 14 Ezek. 7. 7, 10. and ≈øo in Ho≈ø. 10. 15. In the morning ≈øhal the King of I≈ørael be de≈øtroyed; and in this ≈øen≈øe I ≈øhall pre≈øently expound I≈øa. 47. 11.
2. The term Morning doth often denote Gods early care and Providence in looking out for the Protection of his people, Exod. 14. 24. P≈øal. 46. 7.

Hence I infer, that ≈øeeing the word Morning doth ≈øignifie early ≈øeeking, or early looking out, it may well denote unto us, that the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs was not comprehended under the term Evening, but under the term Morning, for Gnereb, the Evening, is never put for early or fir≈øt, but it is always put for late or la≈øt, becau≈øe it was the latter part of the Day, as I have ≈øhewed in my An≈øwer to the third Objection of the former Chapter, and more by and by.

Secondly, It is further evident that the Morning time was fir≈øt, As Gnereb the Evening is put for la≈øt time: So Boker the Morning is put for the fir≈øt time, or for the beginning of a thing. and the Evening la≈øt, by Gen. 49. 27. Benjamin ≈øhall ravine like a Woolf, in the Morning he ≈øhall devour the prey, and in the Evening he ≈øhall divide the ≈øpoile; The Seventy render it, The early Morning; and truly, ≈øeeing the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs had the priority of time before the Artificial Morning, it is not proper to put the Artificial Morning for fir≈øt in preheminence of time before the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs, and therefore in rea≈øon, the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs mu≈øt belong to the early Morning, as well as the fir≈øt half of the Artificial Day doth, or el≈øe Jacob did not make a proper Allu≈øion to the Morning and to the Evening, if the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs had been Evening, for then the evening had been fir≈øt in order of time; ≈øearch into the ≈øtory of Events, and ≈øee how Jacobs Prophecie doth relate to the term Morning and Evening; the event of his P ‚Ä¢ ophecie lyes thus.

1. Ehud of Benjamin was rai≈øed up by God like a Woolf in the early morning to devour the Moabites, and to deliver I≈ørael, Judge. 3. 15. Then God did al≈øo rai≈øe up He≈øter and M ‚Ä¢ rdecai of Benjamin like a Woolf as it were in the Artificial Morning, to deliver the Jews, and to devour Ha ‚Ä¢ an and all his Confederates in a hundred twenty ≈øeven Provinces, H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. 8. and He≈øt. 9.

2. In the Evening-time of the world God rai≈øed up Paul of Benjamin to divide the ≈øpoil with the other Apo≈øtles, by the preaching of the Go≈øpel, for Paul is ≈øaid to make the Word of God to abound from Jeru≈øalem to Illyricum, Rom. 15. 19. and it is further evident that the daies of the Go≈øpel are called the Evening, by Zeph. 2. 7. the Prophet doth there foretel that there ≈øhall be a remnant of the Jews (namely of the di≈øper≈øed Jews dwelling in ≈øeveral Countries) that ≈øhall be called to re≈øt or lie down in the Evening, and to this remnant of di≈øper≈øed Jewes did Peter and James write in the Evening-time of the Go≈øpel to exhort them to re≈øt and repo≈øe their Souls in Chri≈øt for Life and Salvation.

Zachary al≈øo doth u≈øe the term Evening for the la≈øt times, namely, for the daies of the Go≈øpel, and in that re≈øpect the time of the Go≈øpel is often called the la≈øt dayes, I≈øa. 2. 2. Jer. 30. 24. Heb. 1. 2. 1 Pet. 1. 5. 20. Zacharies phra≈øe runs thus, In the Evening time it ≈øhall be light, Zach. 14. 7. It is very ≈øuitable to compare the la≈øt daies of the Go≈øpel to the Evening, becau≈øe it is the la≈øt half of the Natural Day; and it is mo≈øt ≈øuitable al≈øo to compare the light of the Go≈øpel to the light of the Evening, for the Evening begins at Mid-day at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun, and then the day is mo≈øt clear and bright, and ≈øo it continues till almo≈øt Sun-≈øet; and in the la≈øt days, when the Apo≈øtles had a Commi≈ø≈øion to preach the Go≈øpel in all the world, the Go≈øpel gave a light mo≈øt clear to many ≈øouls that ≈øat in darkne≈øs: But if the Evening had been no other time but the dark Night, as the mo≈øt would have it, then Zacharies Allu≈øion to the light of that Evening, had been but a poor compari≈øon to ≈øet forth the light of the Go≈øpel, for in ≈øuch an Evening there is no other light but Star-light, or Moon-light at the be≈øt, and that is but a poor light to illu≈øtrate the light of the Go≈øpel by, in the days of the Apo≈øtles.
Thirdly, As the Evening is often put for la≈øt, ≈øo the Morning is put for fir≈øt, in Dan. 9. 21. The man Gabriel whom I had ≈øeen in a vi≈øion at Fir≈øt, or in the Morning, ≈øo the Hebrew ≈øpeaks.

Fourthly, It is evident by another Allu≈øion that the Morning is before the Evening, becau≈øe the term Morning is put for the very fir≈øt beginning of a thing; and in this ≈øen≈øe I≈øaiah is mo≈øt elegant, I≈øa. 47. 11. Evill ≈øhall come upon thee (O Babylon) and thou ≈øhalt not know the morning thereof (or the beginning thereof.) The Hebrew word ≈øignifies the early Morning; but the
Geneva doth render it the Beginning; and by this phra≈øe the Holy Gho≈øt did (by a Periphra≈øis) de≈øcribe the beginning of Babylons ruin by the early Morning.
Object. 2. Good Divines do take the term Morning here for the beginning of the Artificial Day, and the word Morning in that ≈øen≈øe doth not hinder, but that the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs was Evening.

An≈øw. I have already an≈øwered this Objection immediately before. I told you there, that if the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs had been called Evening, then doubtle≈øs the Evening would have been put for the fir≈øt beginning of any thing, and the Morning for la≈øt, but becau≈øe the Morning is put for the fir≈øt beginning of a thing, therefore it is out of all doubt to me, that the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs did belong to the Morning and not to the Evening.

2. I an≈øwer further, that the Morning of Babylons fall cannot be ≈øo conveniently compared to the Morning of the Artificial day, as to the dark early morning; becau≈øe the Artificial Morning is apparent and per≈øpicuous to all men: But the ruin of Babylon was not per≈øpicuous at fir≈øt, but it was carryed on in a ≈øpeedy and ob≈øcure manner by the Per≈øians, ≈øo that the Babylonians had no ≈øu≈øpition or di≈øcerning of their fall as yet; therefore the Morning of the Artificial Day was not ≈øo ≈øuitable to exemplifie the manner of their ≈øpeedy ruin, as the early dark Morning was, for it was done ≈øpeedily ere they were aware, Jer. 50. 24. as it appears by the≈øe two con≈øiderations.

list.item: 1. I≈øay did foretel that Babylon ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed in the Night, I≈øa. 21. 4.

div.p: Put both the≈øe Prophetical allu≈øions together, and then they wil amount to thus much, that Babylon ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed in that Morning, that begins in the Night; and the Hi≈øtory of Events doth tell us, not onely that Bel≈øhazzer was ≈ølain in the Night, Dan. 5. 30. but al≈øo it is apparent by the circum≈øtances of time that mu≈øt be ≈øpent at that drunken fea≈øt before that Daniel could be ≈øought out and brought in, to interpret the vi≈øion, that it was in the latter part of the Night, after the Morning was begun.

Take the early Morning of Babylons fall either in the former figurative ≈øen≈øe, or in the la≈øt proper ≈øen≈øe (either way or both wayes) and it doth ≈øufficiently prove, that the time called Morning

Fifthly, Boker, the morning, is put for the fir≈øt beginning of a Fifthly, Boker, the morning, is put for the Sun-≈øet Evening, becau≈øe the time of Sun-≈øet is the fir≈øt beginning of the Jews day of eleanne≈øles. thing, becau≈øe it is put for the fir≈øt beginning of the Jews Ceremonial day (or for the Sun-≈øet Evening) as the Hebrew Doctors do witne≈øs. See Ain≈ø. in Deut. 16. 4. This I have further opened in another place; and ≈øo in like ≈øort Macar, the morrow, is put for the fir≈øt beginning of the Jews Ceremonial day (or for the Sun-≈øet Evening) in 1 Sam. 30. 17. and in Lev. 23. 15. as it is further opened in chap. 4.

Sixthly, It is evident that the morning was before the time called Evening by the title that Job gives to the Angels, he cals them Morning-Stars, Job 38. 6, 7. The≈øe Morning-Stars cannot be meant of the Stars in the Firmament, for they were not created till the fourth day, Gen. 1. 14. But the≈øe Morning-Stars are ≈øaid to ≈øhout and ≈øing when the foundation of the earth was laid; Hence it follows, that the Angels are called Morning-Stars, either becau≈øe of the time wherein they ≈øhouted at the fir≈øt laying of the foundations of the earth, which was done in the time of the fir≈øt darkne≈øs, or el≈øe in relation to the time of their Creation, which was al≈øo done in the time of the fir≈øt darkne≈øs, as many learned do accord.

Object. 3. The Angels are called Morning-Stars, not in relation to the time of their Creation, but by way of allu≈øion to the excellency of their Nature, and this is more ≈øuitable to be expre≈ø≈øed by the light of the Artificial morning, than by the fir≈øt darkne≈øs.

An≈øw. If the Circum≈øtances of Gods di≈øcour≈øe with Job, and of Gods Interrogations be well marked, there is no ground to ≈øay that God did onely intend to ≈øet out the excellent nature of the Angels by comparing them to the morning of the Artificiall day.

For the main thing that God aimed at by his Interrogations to Job, was, to make him ≈øee his folly in de≈øiring to di≈øpute the cau≈øe of his afflictions with God, God ≈øhews him that he is not able to

The Text doth plainly call them Morning Stars, not ≈øo much in regard of the excellency of their Nature, but in regard of the time wherein they were created, or wherein they ≈øhouted at the excellency of Gods Workman≈øhip when the foundation of the earth was laid, either way or both waies do a≈ø≈øure us that the time of the fir≈øt darkne≈øs was called Morning and not Evening. And that is the thing that I aim at in this fir≈øt Section of this Chapter.

div.head: SECT. 2. Proving that the Morning doth begin in the dark Night.
div.p: FIr≈øt, No man can deny but that the Morning is begun when the morning Watch is begun, for the text doth affirm it, Exod. 14. 24. 1 Sam. 11. 11. And it is a known thing, that among the Jews they did alwaies begin it ju≈øt three hours after Midnight, not onely in the Summer time but al≈øo in the Winter time: Hence it follows, that their morning Watch in the time of Winter mu≈øt needs begin in the dark night, not onely in Judea, but al≈øo in all the habitable parts of the world.

2. Hence it follows, that ≈øeeing the morning Watch did begin at three hours after Mid-night, then it will follow, that it mu≈øt end ju≈øt three hours after Mid-day; for in common rea≈øon the morning mu≈øt be as long as the evening, namely, twelve hours long, or el≈øe the Evening may better be called an Unevening, then an Evening to the Morning; but none that have their ≈øen≈øes will ≈øay that the morning doth continue till three hours after Midday.

3 Hence it follows, that it is more agreeable to Scripture and to common rea≈øon to begin the natural morning at the marked time of Mid-night, rather than three hours after, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing it is then as dark all the winter long as it is at Mid-night, and
therefore ≈øeeing the morning is begun with darkne≈øs, why not with darkne≈øs at mid-night, as well as at three hours after midnight, ≈øeeing the world was created in the Equinoctial, and the Morning is then as dark at three hours after Mid-night, as it is at Mid-night?

Secondly, Ruth lay at the feet of Boaz until the Morning, Ruth. 3. 14. and yet ≈øhe aro≈øe before one could know another. Hence it is evident that it was Morning in the time of Barly Harve≈øt, whiles it was yet dark; it may be it was now in the end of our March, or in the beginning of our April; and though ≈øome ≈øay that the Morning Watch was not ≈øo called from the fir≈øt hour of it, but from the la≈øt hour of it when it begun to be day light; yet this place of Ruth cals it Morning whiles it was yet dark, and before one could know another.

Thirdly, It is ≈øaid that Chri≈øt aro≈øe in the Morning a great while before Day (or greatly in the Night) ≈øo the Greek ≈øpeaks, Mar. 1. 35. Hence it is manife≈øt that it was Morning, whiles it was greatly or much in the night.

Fourthly, None can deny but that the morning is begun at the time of day-break in all the Inhabited Countries of the world. Hence it follows, that then it is morning in ≈øome Countries near unto mid-night, e≈øpecially when the daies are at the longe≈øt; and known experience doth tell us that in the North parts of England the day doth ≈øometimes begin to break near unto mid-night; and indeed the day-light (when the daies are at the longe≈øt) is ≈øcar≈øe ever out of the Sky in tho≈øe parts, except a little while about mid-night; Hence it follows, that ≈øeeing it is day-break ≈øometimes near unto Mid-night, then why may not the morning begin at mid-night all the year long as well in one Country as in another, ≈øeeing the God of Nature hath ≈øet ≈øuch an eminent mark upon mid-night, and upon mid-day, which doubtle≈øs was to ≈øet out the bounds and limits of the Natural morning, and of the evening?

Fifthly, Both Scripture and experience doth tell us that there is a certain Star called the Morning Star, which at ≈øome time of the year is ≈øeen to ari≈øe not long after Mid-night, and all men call it morning as ≈øoon as that Star is ri≈øen, and in ≈øome parts when the daies are at the longe≈øt it ri≈øeth near unto Mid-night, but it alwaies ri≈øeth before it is day break.

Sixthly, It is evident that the morning begins in the dark night, by this phra≈øe in P≈øal. 110. 3. The womb of the early Morning; I purpo≈øe not to meddle with the my≈øtical ≈øen≈øe of the≈øe words, becau≈øe it concerns not the Argument in hand; but I will onely meddle with the phra≈øe, for the phra≈øe ≈øake onely; for this phra≈øe mu≈øt have ≈øome proper allu≈øion to ≈øome natural truth: Mib≈øchar, we tran≈ølate Morning, but ≈øaith Mr. Ain≈øworth the letter M is a Prepo≈øition, ≈øignifying [From or Before] and in that re≈øpect ≈øome tran≈ølators do render the text thus, Before the womb of the early Morning; this phra≈øe mu≈øt have an allu≈øion to ≈øome proper truth, and I can find nothing that may ≈øo fitly be called the womb of the early Morning, as the fir≈øt darkne≈øs was, for out of this darkne≈øs God created the morning light, and in this re≈øpect the Morning may well be divided into ≈øeveral degrees of time.
1 The fir≈øt Darkne≈øs was the womb of the Morning light.

And certain it is that the morning Sacrifice was not onely ≈ølain, but al≈øo offered before Sun-ri≈øing, (becau≈øe the Meat Offering which was alwaies offered after the Burnt Offering) was offered before Sun ri≈øing, as it appears by 2 King. 3. 20, 22. and the Burnt Offering was alwaies fir≈øt, Lev. 1. and then the Meat Offering, Lev. 2. now though the Morning Sacrifice was offered before Sun-ri≈øing, yet the Evening Sacrifices of all ≈øorts mu≈øt be offered before Sun≈øet. For the Hebrew Doctors ≈øay, that after Sun-≈øet the blood of all Sacrifices became unlawful, See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 1. 6‚ñ™ 9.
5. Then follows the morning of the Artificiall day at Sun-ri≈øing, P≈øal. 104. 22, 23. for God did appoint the Sun to rule and limit the Artificiall day, Gen. 1.
6. Then followed the time of morning Prayer at the third hour of the day, namely at our nine a clock.

Fir≈øt, By the≈øe gradations to the morning we may ≈øee the vanity of their opinion that hold no other time to be called the morning
properly, but a point of time onely, at the beginning of the Artificial day, all the re≈øt they ≈øay is called the morning improperly.
Secondly, By the≈øe gradations to the morning it is evident that the fir≈øt darkne≈øs was the root or womb of the morning, and therefore at la≈øt it was called Morning.

div.head: SECT. 3. Proving that the Morning in all likelihood doth begin at mid-night, be≈øides the former certain grounds from the exact beginning and ending of the Evening.
div.p: FIr≈øt, I will endeavor to prove that the morning doth begin at mid-night by an argument drawn from Job 26. 7. compared with Gen. 1. 2. Job ≈øaith, That God ≈øtretcheth out the North upon the empty; and ≈øaith Mo≈øes, The Earth was empty and void, namely, as long as darkne≈øs was upon the face of the deep; But as ≈øoon as the light was created, the earth could not be ≈øaid to be empty and void any longer, for then the deep was adorned with the light as with a mo≈øt glorious ornament.

Object. 4. The fir≈øt Darkne≈øs did continue twelve hours upon the face of the deep, after the general matter called Earth was created: Or thus, how long was the Earth empty and void before the light was created?

An≈øw. The an≈øwer is from Job, That the Earth was empty and void all the ≈øpace of time that the North point is ≈øtretched out upon a Compa≈øs Dial, namely, the ≈øpace of ≈øix hours, for the North point on a Compa≈øs Dial doth ≈øtretch it ≈øelf out untill it meet with the beginning of the Ea≈øt point, the four ends of the two Lines of Longitude and Latitude do make the four Cardinal Points of the Compa≈øs, North, Ea≈øt, South, and We≈øt: Hence it follows, that the North point is ≈øtretched out to the Ea≈øt point, and that is ju≈øt ≈øix hours by the Compa≈øs Dyal, and ≈øo long ≈øaith Job the Globe was empty; but as ≈øoon as God created Light out of Darkne≈øs, which began to appear by degrees, fir≈øt, By a Twilight, and then ≈øhined forth at the Ea≈øt point, then the Earth was no longer empty and void, but it was adorued with the light.
If any man can give a better Interpretation, for the ≈øtretching out the North upon the Empty, I ≈øhall bee glad to ≈øee it.

But if the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs had been twelve hours long, then Job ≈øhould have ≈øaid, that God ≈øtretched out the We≈øt point, as well as the North point upon the Empty: but Job doth not ≈øay ≈øo, but only that he ≈øtretched out the North upon the Empty, and therefore it follows,
1 That the fir≈øt Darkne≈øs was not twelve hours, but only ≈øix hours long upon the face of the deep, before the light was created.

2 Hence it follows, that the fir≈øt half of that twelve hours Darkne≈øs that ≈øucceeded the Artificial Day, did make up the fir≈øt darkne≈øs to be a ju≈øt Night of twelve hours, and after this manner both the≈øe parts of Darkne≈øs did meet together at the North point, as I have exemplified the matter upon a Compa≈øs Dyal, and the North Land in Jer. 23. 8. may according to the Hebrew be read from the Land of darkne≈øs.

And why el≈øe doth the Prophet in P≈øal. 89. 12. begin the time of the fir≈øt Creation in order from the North point, but to remember us, where, and how long the darkne≈øs did continue upon the face of the deep after the Earth was created, before the light was created?

And ≈øo likewi≈øe for this Rea≈øon, Job doth teach us in what order we mu≈øt place the four ends of the two Lines of Latitude and Longitude (now called the foure Cardinall Points of the Compa≈øs) by placing a man in this order to view the Globe.

div.p: So then, He that de≈øires to behold the Globe in a right order, how the God of Nature did divide it and quarter it, mu≈øt place the North point of the Globe at his left hand, the Ea≈øt before, the South at his right hand, and the We≈øt behind. See Ain≈ø. in P≈øal. 89. 13. and in Numb. 2. 3, 29.
2 The holy Scriptures do often direct us to ob≈øerve the foure ends of the two Lines of Latitude and Longitude.

And in this re≈øpect the four quarters of the Earth are ≈øometimes
called the four wings, or the four corners of the Earth, Revel. 7. 1. Numb. 24. 17. I≈øa. 11. 12. Ezek. 7. 2. Job 37. 3. and 38. 13.

2 The Heavens are divided into four quarters, and in this re≈øpect the four Winds are ≈øaid to come from the four quarters of Heaven, Jer. 49. 36. Ezek. 37. 9. Dan. 7. 2. and 8. 2. Zach. 2. 6. Mat. 24. 31.

And when the Lines of Latitude and Longitude are drawn upon a Compa≈øs Dyal or upon a Globe, then they make the four winds in the four quarters of Heaven to lie thus, and to be called thus, North-Ea≈øt, South-Ea≈øt, South-we≈øt, North-we≈øt.

And thus the Holy Scripture doth force us to ob≈øerve the various u≈øe of the≈øe two Lines of Longitude and Latitude; and therefore doubtle≈øs Job was not ignorant, but ≈øpake as a man of knowledge, when he ≈øaid that God ≈øtretched out the North upon the Empty. Fir≈øt, He was not ignorant of the North point. Nor ≈øecondly, How far it ≈øtretched. Nor thirdly, of the time of the Globes emptine≈øs.

3 Ezekiel doth direct us to take notice of the North point as the fir≈øt in order of the ≈øour Cardinal points, becau≈øe he doth fir≈øt begin the divi≈øion of the Land of Canaan from the North quarter, and ≈øo he ends it with the We≈øt quarter, read Ezek. 47. from ver. 15. to the end of the Chapter; and in this order al≈øo the Lord was plea≈øed to let Mo≈øes take a view of the land, he ≈øtood in the Land of Gilead, and from thence in the fir≈øt place he viewed Dan which was the furthe≈øt Northward and Northally in Galilee, which lay al≈øo Northward. Secondly, Then he viewed the land of Ephraim and half Mana≈ø≈øeh which lay Ea≈øtward from him in the middle of the Land. Thirdly, Then he viewed the Land of Judah to the South. And fourthly, Then he viewed the Land of Jerico which lay in the We≈øt of Canaan. See Ain≈ø. in Deut. 34. 1, 2, 3.

Secondly, I will indeavor to prove that the Morning began with the fir≈øt darkne≈øs, and that the fir≈øt darkne≈øs mu≈øt be placed at the North point by another phra≈øe of Job, for Job doth tell us that when the winds have purged the Air, and made it clear from clouds and vapours, that then out of the North a golden light doth ≈øhew it ≈øelf, Job 37. 22. Our eie-≈øight may witne≈øs the truth of this point, for in a clear Morning before Sun-ri≈øing we may often ≈øee a golden li≈øt of light ≈øtretching it ≈øelf from the
North point to the Ea≈øt; and again after Sun-≈øet we may often ≈øee a golden li≈øt of light ≈øtretching it ≈øelf from the We≈øt point to the North point. This Ob≈øervation, Fir≈øt, Of the golden li≈øt from North to Ea≈øt, may teach us that the root of the Morning comes from the North point, where the Midnight begins by the Compa≈øs-Dyall. And Secondly, The golden li≈øt in the Evening after Sun-≈øet from We≈øt to North, may teach us that the Evening doth reach unto Mid-night, or to the North point.
Thirdly, I prove that the Natural Morning doth being at Mid-night, becau≈øe the morning of the fifteenth day of Ni≈øhan began at Mid-night.

I collect it thus, Mo≈øes at the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øeover in Egypt gave a very ≈øtrict charge to all the I≈øraelites, that no man ≈øhould go out of the door of his hou≈øe untill the Morning, Exod. 12. 22. namely, not untill the morning of the fifteenth day was come; this was Mo≈øes expre≈øs charge. Hence I rea≈øon thus, if any man of I≈ørael had gone out of the door of his hou≈øe before the morning of the fifteenth day was truely come, contrary to this charge (as tho≈øe did that went out of the door of their hou≈øes to gather Manna on the Sabbath-day morning) they would have been condemned as Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors for it (as they were that gathered Manna on the Sabbath day morning, Exod. 16. 27. 28.)

But all the people of I≈ørael went out of the doors of their hou≈øes either at Mid-night or pre≈øently after, as it appears by ver. 33. and 39. and yet none of them were condemned as tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors for it: But on the contrary, their exact obedience to all Mo≈øes commands is twice over te≈øtified in ver. 28. and twice over again in ver. 50. The Text ≈øaith, they did all things as God commanded Mo≈øes and Aaron, ≈øo did they, Even as exactly as Noah did in making the Arke, Gen. 6. 22. or as Mo≈øes did in making the Tabernacle, Exod. 40. 16. for their obedience is alike ≈øet out by the ≈øame double expre≈ø≈øion.

Therefore ≈øeeing all the people were thus exact in their obedience to all Mo≈øes commands; it follows, that they did not go out of the doors of their hou≈øes untill the morning of the fifteenth day was come, and yet they went out of the doors of their hou≈øes at Mid-night, or pre≈øently after, becau≈øe they knew that the morning of the fifteenth day was begun at Mid-night.

Yea, It is evident that Mo≈øes intended they ≈øhould all go out of their doors in the Morning pre≈øently after Mid-night, becau≈øe he had foretold them, that all the fir≈øt-born of Egypt ≈øhould be ≈ølain at Mid-night, Exod. 11. 4, 5. And ≈øecondly, He had foretold them that the Egyptians would thru≈øt them out of Egypt, v. 1. and that the Nobles would come and bow down to Mo≈øes ≈øaying, Go thou out and all the people at thy feet, Exod. 11. 8. Yea, Mo≈øes did prepare them for a ≈øudden departing from their hou≈øes, becau≈øe he commanded to eat the Pa≈ø≈øeover with their loyns girded, with their ≈øhooes on their feet, and with their ≈øtaves in their hands, and to eat it in ha≈øte, Exod. 12. 11. all the≈øe things do te≈øtifie that Mo≈øes intended they ≈øhould go out of the doors of their hou≈øes as ≈øoon as ever the morning of the fifteenth day was come, and he meant it was come as ≈øoon as Midnight was come.

Object. 5. I grant that all I≈ørael departed out of Egypt on the fifteenth day of Ni≈øhan, Numb. 33. 3. But how prove you that they began their journey at Midnight, or that the fifteenth day began at Mid-night?

An≈øw. The circum≈øtances of the Text do prove it plain enough; for as ≈øoon as the Egyptiaus ≈øaw all their fir≈øt-born ≈ølain at Mid-night, they feared le≈øt they ≈øhould be all ≈ølain, and therefore they did urge the I≈øraelites in all ha≈øte to depart, and the I≈øraelites knew all this before-hand, and accordingly they prepared for their ≈øpeedy departure, and becau≈øe of this their preparation they are ≈øaid to depart out of Egypt in the night, Deut. 16. 1. compared with Exod. 12. 29, 31, 42. The Egyptians therefore as ≈øoon as their fir≈øtborn were ≈ølain at Midnight, urged the I≈øraelites in ha≈øte to depart, and then al≈øo the I≈øraelites did depart out of the doors of their hou≈øes, becau≈øe the morning of the fifteenth day was come, but yet they could not fully depart out of Egypt untill the body of the ≈øelf ≈øame day was come, namely, not till it was Mid-day. See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 12. 41. they had many bu≈øine≈ø≈øes to do after they went out of the doors of their hou≈øes before they could fully depart; for they mu≈øt a≈ø≈øemble together 600000 men befides women and children, and many connexed people and cattle, and before all this could be put into a fit po≈øture for their orderly marching away, it was Mid-day, and yet they made extraordinary ha≈øte to bring things thus ≈øoon to pa≈ø≈øe, and through their great ha≈øte they took their Dough as it was unleavened, and carried it upon their ≈øhoulders, ver. 34. and thenceforth the fifteenth
of Ni≈øhan was commanded to be remembred, and to be ob≈øerved, as a Fe≈øtivall Sabbath for ever, and as the fir≈øt day of the Fea≈øt of unleavened bread, Exod. 13. 3. Lev. 23. 7. Deut. 16. 3.

Their Journey in the night began in this order, as ≈øoon as the fir≈øt-born of Pharaoh and the Nobles were ≈ølain at Mid-night, then in their perplexed fear they did ha≈øtily call up Mo≈øes and Aaron to depart, and then they gave the Alarm to the re≈øt, and as the fir≈øt of them marched through the land of Go≈øhen, the re≈øt fell in by Troops, but before they could be all mar≈øhalled to depart in fit order, it was Mid-day, and in this ≈øort their march began at Mid-night, and was compleated by Mid-day, according to Numb. 33. 3.

div.head: Conclu≈øion.
div.p: From all the premi≈øes (which I have laid down under three Heads or Sections) it follows, That the time of the fir≈øt darkne≈øs (after the Creation of the Earth) was Morning (and not Evening.) And ≈øecondly, That it began at that time which the God of Nature made Mid-night at la≈øt, namely, as ≈øoon as all the parts of the Naturall day were formed and framed together.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Proving, That the Jewes Cu≈øtom in beginning their weekly Sabbath at the Sun-≈øet Evening, was occa≈øioned by their Ceremonial Cu≈øtom, namely, Becau≈øe the per≈øons that were ceremonially purified from their ceremonial Defilements, were commanded to begin their new day of cleanne≈øs then; and hence it follows, fir≈øt, That that accidental beginning of the Day mu≈øt not be accounted for the true beginning of the Natural Day; And Secondly, Hence it follows, That it is not the right time for us Chri≈øtians to begin our Lords Day at the Sun-≈øet Evening, as the Jews did by their ceremonial Cu≈øtom onely.
SECT. 1.
div.p: THe Jews were often guilty of ≈øundry degrees of ≈øins of uncleanne≈øs again≈øt the Ceremonial Law (be≈øides their ≈øins again≈øt the Moral Law) as you may find them noted and di≈øtingui≈øhed by Mr. Ain≈øworth in Lev. 11. 24, 25, 32. and in Lev. 12. 6. and in Lev. 22. 7. compared with Numb. 9. 10. and with Lev. 13. 6. and ≈øee al≈øo Lev. 14. 9, 17. and Num. 5. 2, 3. and Numb. 19. 2, 7, 11.

Secondly, An≈øwerable thereunto, the Ceremonial Law did ordain ≈øeveral degrees of purification, from the≈øe ≈øeveral degrees of ceremonial uncleanne≈øs; as you may find them noted al≈øo by Ain≈øworth, in Lev. 5. 2. Lev. 14. 9, 15. Lev. 15. 14. Num. 5. 7. Num. 19. 18. Gen. 35. 2. and in Exod. 19.
Thirdly, Not onely the manner how, but al≈øo the time when they mu≈øt clean≈øe them≈øelves, was ordained and appointed by the Ceremonial Law.

Some kind of defilements might be clen≈øed in one day, but the greate≈øt degrees of their Ceremonial defilements required not only one, but many dayes for their clean≈øing; but all were commanded to begin their clean≈øing in the Evening in two degrees of time, according to the two parts of the Evening, for the natural
Evening hath two equal parts (as I have ≈øhewed in Chap. 2. and ≈øhall further ≈øhew it in the next Chapter.)

In the fir≈øt Evening (which doth always begin at Mid-day) they mu≈øt baptize or wa≈øh them≈øelves. The Jews were clean≈øed from their ceremonial defilements, 1. By wa≈øhing in the afternoon; And 2. By the Suns ≈øetting upon them after their baptizing.
In the ≈øecond Evening (which doth alwaies begin at Sun-≈øet) they did begin to date the day of their cleanne≈øs.

For by the ≈øetting of the Sun upon them, after their wa≈øhing, two things were effected; Fir≈øt, Their cleanne≈øs by their former wa≈øhing was confirmed or made perfect; And ≈øecondly, As ≈øoon as their cleanne≈øs was made perfect, they began the day of their cleanne≈øs.
Object. 1. Might not the unclean per≈øon baptize him≈øelf from his Ceremonial defilements in the latter evening after Sun-≈øet, as well as in the time of the fir≈øt Evening before Sun-≈øet?

An≈ø. He might not, becau≈øe God had appointed the time of the two Evenings for two di≈øtinct degrees of their clean≈øing: The fir≈øt Evening from Mid-day to Sun-≈øet was allotted to them for the wa≈øhing or baptizing them≈øelves from their ceremonial ≈øins, and this was onely as a preparation to the day of their cleanne≈øs, And this I will labor to make evident ≈øeveral waies.

1. Mo≈øes in Deut. 23. 11. doth command the unclean per≈øon to bath him≈øelf in water, at the looking forth of the Evening. So the Hebrew phra≈øe is, but it may be demanded, what time is that, that is meant by the looking forth of the Evening?

An≈øw. I have ≈øhewed you in chap. 2. and in chap. 5. that the Evening doth fir≈øt begin at the fir≈øt declining of the Sun at Mid-day, and that it looks forth towards his ≈øetting in the we≈øt from the very fir≈øt declining of the Sun from Mid-day untill it depart from that Horizon, and to this ≈øen≈øe I have expounded the ≈øhadows of the Evening to look forth, in Jer. 6, 4. See Chap. 2.

In like ≈øort it is ≈øaid of I≈øaack, that he went out into the fields to meditate at the looking forth of the Evening, Gen. 24. 63. In tho≈øe daies they had no private upper Rooms to meditate in, becau≈øe they lived in Tents, and therefore they u≈øed to ≈øeque≈øter them≈øelves by going out into the fields to meditate, where they had Groves of Trees for ≈øhade and refre≈øhing, and thither the godly u≈øed to go to meditate or to ≈øtudy divine my≈øteries in the heat of the day, at the fir≈øt looking forth of the Evening. See Ain≈ø. in P≈øa. 55. 18.

In like ≈øort, they u≈øed to bathe or baptize them≈øelves from their Ceremonial defilements at the looking forth of the Evening, and then al≈øo the water was well warmed by the Sun, and ≈øo made the more fit for bathing. I grant al≈øo, that it was lawfull for them to bathe them≈øelves from their Ceremonial defilements all the time that the Sun looked forth by his ≈øhadowes towards the We≈øt, till it was ready to depart out of that Horizon. But this is to be marked, that none were commanded to baptize them≈øelves in any part of the morning (onely the Prie≈øts were commanded to wa≈øh their hands and their feet every morning, although they were clean before. See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 30. 19, 20.) neither were they commanded to baptize them≈øelves after Sun-≈øet, for except they were baptized before Sun-≈øet, they could not begin the day of their cleanne≈ø≈øe at Sun-≈øet, according to command.
2 It is evident, that the appointed ≈øea≈øon for baptizing them≈øelves from all their Ceremonial defilements was in the time of the fir≈øt Evening, by the Example of Bath≈øhebaes baptizing her≈øelf.

The Text ≈øaith, it was in the Evening when David aro≈øe from his bed and walked upon the Roof of the Kings hou≈øe, then he ≈øaw a woman wa≈øhing her ≈øelf, and the woman was very beautiful to look upon, 2 Sam. 11. 2. This Evening when David aro≈øe from his bed, cannot be under≈øtood of the latter Sun-≈øet Evening, for then for want of Sun-light he could not have di≈øcerned her beauty from the Roof of his hou≈øe, but it mu≈øt be under≈øtood of the afternoon Evening; for in tho≈øe hot Countries they u≈øed to ≈øleep in the afternoon upon ≈øome Bed or Pallat, as I≈øhbo≈øheth did, 2 Sam. 4. 5. from whence he aro≈øe and walked upon the flat Roof of his hou≈øe, and thence he beheld the beauty of Bath≈øheba as ≈øhe was baptizing her ≈øelf; hence it may be gathered, that the unclean per≈øons did u≈øe to baptize them≈øelves from their Ceremonial defilements in the afternoon Evening.

3 It is al≈øo evident, that they baptized them≈øelves in the after-noon Evening from their Ceremonial defilements by a famous example in Jo≈øh. 7. for when the Lords wrath was gone out again≈øt them, in that the men of Ai ≈ølew about thirty ≈øix of I≈ørael, becau≈øe that Achan had ≈øtoln the excommunicate thing; then ≈øaid the Lord to Jo≈øhua at the Even-tide, ∆≤p, and ≈øanctifie the people, and
≈øay, Sanctifie your ≈øelves again≈øt to morrow, Jo≈øh. 7. 6, 13, 14, 15. and how el≈øe mu≈øt they ≈øanctifie them≈øelves for the Lords pre≈øence at his Ark on the morrow, but by wa≈øhing them≈øelves from their Ceremonial defilements, for there were ≈øcar≈øe any but they were defiled by one accident or other, and none might come before the Lords Ark in their Ceremonial defilements upon pain of being cut off; and before Jo≈øhua could make proclamation through the Camp for their purification, and for their ≈øolemn meeting to ≈øeek the Lord for mercy on the morrow, it would require a good ≈øpace of time, therefore this Evening cannot be under≈øtood of the Sun-≈øet Evening, but of the noon-tide Evening, as I have explained the matter more at large in Chap. 2.

4 All I≈ørael were warned when ever they came before the Lords pre≈øence in his Tabernacle, to be clean≈øed from their Ceremonial defilements, e≈øpecially at their three ≈øolemn fea≈øts; but they were not tyed to the ob≈øervation of their Ceremonial baptizing when they re≈øorted to their Synagogues on their weekly Sabbath daies, for in tho≈øe places both the clean and the unclean might meet together in Gods wor≈øhip, as I have opened the matter in my di≈øcour≈øe of the Jews Synagogues Di≈øcipline.

But under pain of the Lords di≈øplea≈øure none might approach to the Lords Sanctuary without their legal purificatiÃÑons, as it is manife≈øt by the example of Gods di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt ≈øome of Ephraim & Mana≈ø≈øes when they came to the Pa≈ø≈øeover in the daies of Hezekiah with out their purifications; but as ≈øoon as Hezekiah perceived their error (which doubtle≈øs the con≈øciences of the vi≈øited per≈øons made them to acknowledge) he prayed to the Lord for them, & the Lord was intreated, and healed the people, 2 Chron. 30. 19, 20. and for the better avoiding of this error afterwards, it was ob≈øerved as a cu≈øtom among the Jews, to go out of the Country up to Jeru≈øalem before the Fea≈øt of Pa≈ø≈øeover, to purifie them≈øelves, Joh. 7. 55. which purification was effected by two degrees of cleanne≈øs: Fir≈øt, By baptizing them≈øelves in the fir≈øt Evening; And ≈øecondly, By the Sun-≈øetting upon them after their baptizing (as I have formerly proved the matter) for none might approach the Sanctuary until they could declare their purification to the Prie≈øts that were the Porters, 2 Chron. 23. 19. as Paul did, Act. 21. 26.

And the Lord did ≈øo much approve of their Ceremonial purity, both by their actual baptizing and by their ab≈øtinence from
unclean meats, and from all other things el≈øe that might defile them: That for that very obedience he doth cal the whole Nation, All I≈ørael are called men of Holine≈øs in regard of their ceremonial purity. Men of holine≈øs, Exod. 22. 31. for all the Nation in general were very careful to maintain this kind of holine≈øs. And the Hebrew Doctors ≈øay, that if any man of the common people did but ≈øay, I am clean to keep the ≈øin-water, he was to be tru≈øted, for there is no man of I≈ørael too vild for it, See Ain≈ø. in Num. 19. 9. that is to ≈øay, no man of I≈ørael was too vild for it, if he were but Ceremonially clean; and in this ≈øen≈øe all I≈ørael were holy, namely, to the purifying of their fle≈øh; for the Law is not of Faith, Gal. 3. 12. a man might keep the Law to the purifying of his fle≈øh, though they wanted ≈øaving-Faith to apply the blood of Chri≈øt for the clean≈øing of their con≈øciences from the guilt of ≈øin.
And thus much touching the fir≈øt degree of time in which they mu≈øt perform the fir≈øt degree of their Ceremonial cleanne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: SECT. 2.
div.p: I Come now to ≈øpeak of the ≈øecond degree of time wherein their Ceremonial cleanne≈øs was perfected, and that was as ≈øoon as the Sun was ≈øet upon them after their Ceremonial baptizing, and from that time al≈øo they began to date the new day of their cleanne≈øs.

Fir≈øt, I prove that God ordained the Sun-≈øet Evening to be the time of perfecting the cleanne≈øs of the baptized per≈øon, ere he None were compleatly purified by being baptized til the Sun was ≈øet upon them. could begin the day of his cleanne≈øs, by Deut. 23. 10, 11. There Mo≈øes ≈øaith thus to all I≈ørael, If there be in thee a man that is not clean by rea≈øon of an accident in the night, then he ≈øhall go out of the Camp; and he ≈øhall hath him≈øelf in water at the looking forth of the Evening (and what then, was he now made clean as ≈øoon as ever he had bathed him≈øelf in water? The an≈øwer is, no, hee mu≈øt yet ≈øtay a while longer without the Camp till his Sun be ≈øet,) and then when the Sun is gon down he ≈øhall come into the Camp.
Hence it is evident that his Ceremoniall purity was not compleat until his Sun was ≈øet, but then it was compleat, and therefore he did then begin to date the day of his cleanne≈øs.

Hence al≈øo I gather, that their Ceremonial baptizing might be done in any part of the afternoon, provided it were done before
Sun-≈øet, becau≈øe the Sun did look forth towards the place of his going down by his ≈øhadow, from Mid-day, til it went out of that Horizon, as I have formerly explained the matter.

But if any were defiled by any accident in the night after his Sun was ≈øet upon him, he mu≈øt remain in that uncleanne≈øs untill a new baptizing in the next afternoon, and till a new Sun-≈øet Evening,

Secondly, It is evident, that none were compleatly purified till Sun-≈øet, by Levit. 22. 5, 6, 7. Mo≈øes ≈øaith thus, If any man (whether Prie≈øt or I≈øraelite) be made unclean by touching a dead creeping thing, (or the like unclean thing;) Then (in ver. 6.) he ≈øhall be unclean untill the Evening, he ≈øhall not eat of the holy things. But fir≈øt, He ≈øhall bath him≈øelf in water. And then Secondly (≈øaith ver. 7.) when the Sun is gon down he ≈øhall be clean.

By this Text it is al≈øo evident, that he did not attain to a perfect ceremonial cleanne≈øs by baptizing him≈øelf in water, untill the Sun was gon down upon him after his bathing: But as ≈øoon as his Sun was ≈øet, then he was compleatly purified, and then al≈øo he began to date the day of his cleanne≈øs, and then al≈øo he might eat of the holy things.

Thirdly, The Hebrew Doctors do abundantly te≈øtifie that no baptized per≈øon did begin the day of his cleanne≈øs untill his Sun was ≈øet; for this is their common and peculiar phra≈øe, They ≈øhall be unclean untill their Sun be ≈øet: But the common phra≈øe of the Ceremonial Law ≈øaith thus, They ≈øhall be unclean untill the Evening. The unclean (≈øaith Maymony) may not eat of the Heave-Offering untill their Sun be ≈øet. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 22. 9, 10. And hence it is evident, that they held the baptized per≈øons to have ≈øome degree of uncleanne≈øs upon them, untill their Sun was ≈øet: And therefore Maymony ≈øaith thus; He that is baptized is the ≈øecond in uncleanne≈øs, untill his Sun be ≈øet; And he that is ≈øo baptized (if his Sun bee not ≈øet) may not eat or drink of the Trumah (or holy offerings) nor of any meat or drink that is holy. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 11. 32. and in Lev. 7. 20, 21. and in Numb. 19. 19, 20, 21. This phra≈øe in the Law, He ≈øhall be unclean untill the Evening, is eight times over repeated in Lev. 11. and fourteen times over in Lev. 15. and often el≈øewhere: But the Hebrew Doctors do u≈øually expre≈øs it, He ≈øhall be unclean till his Sun be ≈øet; they accounted the term Sun≈øet and the term Evening to be all one time. Hence then it follows,
that the date of their new day of cleanne≈øs did alwaies begin at the Sun-≈øet Evening.

Fourthly, It is evident, that the Jews began the date of their new day of cleanne≈øs at the Sun-≈øet Evening; becau≈øe the Sun-≈øet The Jews morrow began at Sun-≈øet in Ceremonial re≈øpects. Evening is called [Their morning] 1 Sam. 30. 17. David and his men are ≈øaid to pur≈øue after the Amalekites, From the twilight unto the Evening of Their Morrow; that is to ≈øay, from the Twilight in the Morning until their Morrow, which began at the Sun-≈øet Evening; it was a cu≈øtom that was proper and peculiar unto them, & differing from other Nations, to date the new day of their cleanne≈øs from the Sun-≈øet Evening; and therefore the Hebrew Text doth apply the word Their unto David and his men in ≈øpecial, calling it their morrow; Dr. Willet doth explain the word Morrow to be the next day after David & his men were ≈øet forth to pur≈øue the Amalekites; But the text doth not ≈øay ≈øo, but that David and his men fell upon the Amalekites and pur≈øued their victory, from the Twilight (in the morning) untill the Evening of their morrow, that is, till the Sun-≈øet Evening, for at that Evening began their Morrow, or their new day to the per≈øon purified.
2. It is evident that the Sun-≈øet Evening was the Jews morrow, from the time of their reckoning of the ≈øeven weeks to the day of Pentico≈øt.

They are commanded to begin that reckoning from the morrow of the Sabbath; meaning by the Sabbath, the fir≈øt day of the fea≈øt of unleavened bread, which God commanded them to ob≈øerve as a Sabbath, Lev. 23. 15. And by the Morrow of the Sabbath, is meant the ≈øecond day of the Fea≈øt of unleavened bread, which began at the Sun-≈øet Evening, at the end of the fir≈øt day, that Evening is called the Morrow, (but this is ob≈øervable al≈øo, that the ≈øeventh day of the Fea≈øt of unleavened bread did not end at Sun-≈øet; but the holy fea≈øt of that day continued in the night time after Sun-≈øet) and in this ≈øen≈øe the word Morrow mu≈øt be under≈øtood in ver. 11. and 16.

The Hebrew Doctors ≈øay, they begin this reckoning from the beginning of the day (not from the beginning of the Artificial day as mo≈øt are apt to mi≈øtake their meaning, but) from the night of the ≈øixteenth of Ni≈øhan. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 15. and it is a known thing (as I have explained the matter) that they did account the night to begin at the Sun-≈øet Evening according to the date of the per≈øon purified.
And in this ≈øen≈øe the phra≈øe of The next day in Matth. 27. 62. mu≈øt be under≈øtood; then, the next day that followed the preparation, mu≈øt be under≈øtood of the Sun-≈øet Evening.

3. As Boker, the Morning, is put for the beginning of the day, namely, for the beginning of the Natural day, and for the beginning of the Artificial day; ≈øo al≈øo, it is once put for the beginning of the Jews Ceremonial day, or for the Sun-≈øet Evening, in Deut. 16. 4. as I have opened the matter more at large in Chap. 5.
The≈øe places do plainly evidence that the Jews had a double Morning, and a double Morrow (as they had a double year) an≈øwerable to the Natural Day and to their Ceremonial Day.

Object. 2. Though I am willing to grant that all purified per≈øons did It is di≈øputed by ≈øome that the Sun-≈øet Evening is not fully come until it be full Twilight, or ≈øomewhat pa≈øt, or el≈øe they confe≈øs it cannot be proved that Chri≈øt lay three daies in his grave. begin the date of their new Day at the Sun-≈øet Evening, yet learned men do affirm, that the Sun is not ≈øet as ≈øoon as the Body of the Sun is gone out of our ≈øight; They ≈øay that as long as there doth remain any light in the Skie the Sun is the cau≈øe of it, and hence they a≈ø≈øert, That the Sun is not ≈øet untill the Darkne≈øs in the Skie is more than the Light in the Skie; they ≈øay the Sun is not ≈øet untill it is full Twilight or ≈øomewhat pa≈øt: and by this expo≈øition of the Sun-≈øet Evening, they ≈øay it may be proved that Chri≈øt lay three daies in his Grave, or el≈øe they confe≈ø≈øe it cannot be proved.
An≈øw. If this grand Objection (which is very great in ≈øome mens eyes) be fully an≈øwered, then all the Conclu≈øions that are built upon it mu≈øt needs fall to the ground with it.

I confe≈øs I cannot but wonder that any learned men ≈øhould make the time of Sun-≈øet and the time of Twilight to be all one, for if this be true, then all A≈øtronomers mu≈øt go to School again to learn better how to ≈øet the Minutes of the Suns ri≈øing and of the Suns ≈øetting. But ≈øee what I ≈øay further in an≈øwer to this Objection, in Chap. 7.

And ≈øuppo≈øe a man that holds thus, ≈øhould hire a laborer to That the time of Sun-≈øet is fully come as ≈øoon as the body of the Sun is gon out of ≈øight, and before it be Twilight. work in his Garden from Sun-ri≈øing till Sun-≈øet, and ≈øuppo≈øe this Laborer do contract with him to continue at his labor until the preci≈øe time of Sun-≈øet, and accordingly he continues at his labor untill the Body of the Sun is gon out of ≈øight, and then he leaves off and takes witne≈øs of it, and pre≈øently goes to his Ma≈øter for wages according to Contract; his Ma≈øter refu≈øeth to pay him becau≈øe he did not continue at his labor until the preci≈øe
time of Sun-≈øet; he tels him, that the Sun is not yet ≈øet, becau≈øe the Light in the Sky is more in quantity than the Darkne≈øs; for ≈øaith he, the Sun is the cau≈øe of that light, and therefore it is not yet ≈øet, and he takes witne≈øs, and ≈øo they part in di≈øcontent; and becau≈øe they could not agree about the preci≈øe time of Sun-≈øet, they refer this controver≈øie to be determined by competent Judges.

And fir≈øt let Mo≈øes ≈øhew his Judgement, what he means by the time of Sun-≈øet, or by the Suns going down, for he doth ≈øhew his judgement by a familiar example; He directed the Jews how to find out Mount Gerezim on the other ≈øide Jordan, It lies (≈øaith hee) behind the way, at the going down of the Sun, Deut. 11. 30. In the≈øe words Mo≈øes doth give them a twofold mark of direction.

1. It lies behind, 2. It lies at the going down of the Sun, and I have ≈øhewed you in expounding Job 23. 8, 9. that this phra≈øe behind is often put for the We≈øt. And in this ≈øen≈øe al≈øo ≈øee Ain≈ø. in Gen. 14. 15.

2. Mo≈øes ≈øaith, It lies at the going down of the Sun; if you ≈øay this going down of the Sun is not meant of the place where the body of the Sun goes out of ≈øight, but of the place of Twilight, then whither might the Jews wander by that mark of direction to ≈øeek out Mount Gerezim? For when the darkne≈øs in the Skie is ≈øomewhat more than the light in the Sky, the Jews might wander into the North or into the South as well as into the We≈øt, for the time and place of Twilight is but an uncertain mark to ≈øteer their cour≈øe by to Mount Gerezim.

But to place the time of Sun-≈øet where the body of the Sun goes out of ≈øight, is a per≈øpicuous mark for the We≈øt (when the Sun is in the Equinoctial, as it was when this direction was given) and in this re≈øpect the time of Sun-≈øet is often put for the We≈øt. See more in Chap. 2. in an≈øwer to Objection 3. And ≈øee Ain≈ø. in P≈øal. 113. 3. and this direction agrees to the fir≈øt direction, it is Behind, or it is due We≈øt.

On the contrary when Mo≈øes directed them to other places that lay Ea≈øt, he directed them thither by the Ri≈øing of the Sun, Numb. 21. 11. Numb. 34. 15. Deuter. 4. 41, 47. Jo≈øh. 12. 1. Jo≈øh. 19. 27, 34.

Secondly, Let Jo≈øhua al≈øo ≈øhew his judgement about the time
and place of Sun-≈øet, and he declares his judgement by another familiar example, for he directed the Jews how to finde out the We≈øt bounds of Canaan, not by the confu≈øed, and ob≈øcure mark of Twilight; but fir≈øt, by the per≈øpicuous mark of Sun-≈øet; and ≈øecondly by the hindmo≈øt Sea, Jo≈ø. 1. 4. he makes the hindmo≈øt Sea, and the going down of the Sun to be marks Synonima for the finding out of the We≈øt borders of Canaan; and he doth al≈øo explain this hindmo≈øt Sea to be the great Sea at Sun-≈øet, Jo≈ø. 23. 4. and Mo≈øes likewi≈øe doth call this Sea the Hindmo≈øt Sea, Deut. 11. 24. But the Greek and Chaldee call it the We≈øtern Sea. So then from the premi≈øes it follows, That ≈øeeing the places that lye due We≈øt, are marked out by the per≈øpicuous mark of the going down of the Sun, we mu≈øt thereby under≈øtand that the Sun-≈øet Evening doth begin as ≈øoon as ever the body of the Sun is gone out of ≈øight; and therefore hence it follows, that tho≈øe that make the time of Sun-≈øet, and the time of Twilight to be all one (for the begining of our Lords day) do build their opinion but on a ≈øandy foundation.

Thirdly, The Hebrew Text doth often expre≈øs the time of Sun-≈øet by the going in of the Sun, to lodge all night (as it were in its chamber) and it is ≈øaid to go in as ≈øoon as ever the body of the Sun is gone out of our Horizon. See Ain≈ø. in P≈øa. 50. 1. on the contrary, as ≈øoon as the body of the Sun is ri≈øen upon our Horizon in the morning, it is ≈øaid to come forth as a Bridegroom out of his chamber, P≈øal. 19. 5.

Fourthly, Experience will tell you, that the Sun is ≈øet as ≈øoon as ever the body of the Sun is gone out of ≈øight; or el≈øe if it be not ≈øet till the darkne≈ø≈øe in the skie is more than the light in the skie, then there is no Sun-≈øet at all in the North of England when the daies are at the longe≈øt, for experience doth te≈øtifie that the light is hardly out of the skie there, all the night long, except a little in the middle of the night, and yet experience doth witne≈ø≈øe that the Sun doth truly ≈øet there every day.

Fifthly, Let all A≈øtronomers ≈øhew their judgement when the Sun doth ≈øet, and they with one con≈øent do te≈øtifie that the Sun doth ≈øet as ≈øoon as ever the body of the Sun is gon out of ≈øight, for they de≈øcribe the time of Sun-≈øet, and the time of the Suns ri≈øing, by the fir≈øt appearing of the body of the Sun in the morning, and by the body of the Sun going out of ≈øight in the evening, as all their Almanacks do te≈øtifie.

Sixthly, Let the Evangeli≈øt Marke ≈øhew his judgement, for he de≈øcribes the Evening to begin at Sun-≈øet, Mark. 1. 32. but Luke ≈øpeaking of the ≈øame action ≈øaith, It was when the Sun was ≈øetting, Luke 440. put this together, and it implies that the time of the beginning of the Sun-≈øet Evening is as ≈øoon as ever the body of the Sun is gone out of ≈øight.

Seventhly, Jo≈øhua doth te≈øtifie that the Evening is come as ≈øoon as ever the body of the Sun is gone out of ≈øight, Jo≈ø. 10. 26, 27. and Daniel ≈øaith, That Darius did labour to deliver him till the going down of the Sun, Dan. 6. 14. But the Seventy ≈øay, till Evening; and Mo≈øes ≈øaith, The ≈øoul that toucheth a dead creeping thing ≈øhall be unclean untill the Evening, Lev. 22. 6. but ≈øaith he, in ver≈ø. 7. He ≈øhall bathe him≈øelf in water, and then he ≈øhall be clean when the Sun is gone down; from all the≈øe places it is evident, that the term Sun-≈øet, and the term Evening, are terms convertible for the Sun-≈øet Evening.

Eighthly, It is evident by this rea≈øon that the latter Evening doth begin as ≈øoon as ever the body of the Sun is gone out of ≈øight, becau≈øe there is no interim between the End of the fir≈øt Evening, and the Beginning of the latter Evening; and I have proved in Chap. 2. that the fir≈øt Evening doth end, as ≈øoon as ever the Sun doth leave off to make any more ≈øhadows upon the face of the Earth: For the whole time of the fir≈øt Evening is de≈øcribed by its ≈øhadows looking forth towards the place of its Re≈øt, or by the ≈øtretching out of its ≈øhadows upon the face of the Earth, as I have expounded, Jer. 6. 4. and therefore it follows by nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence, that the latter Evening mu≈øt begin at that in≈øtant time. This con≈øequence is ≈øo cleer, that none that loves plain truth can deny it.

But to prevent ra≈øh zeal, and unadvi≈øed ha≈øte in fea≈øting upon the holy fle≈øh, the Hebrew Doctors advi≈øed to ≈øtay a little time after Sun-≈øet, They begin their Religious Fe≈øtival Suppers after Sun-≈øet, as ≈øoon as three ≈øtars appeared in the skie. for the Sun mu≈øt go down upon the baptized per≈øon before his Purification was perfected, and then he began the date of his new day, and then he was made fit to eat of the holy fle≈øh; yet they advi≈øed to ≈øtay a little time after Sun-≈øet, namely till three ≈øtars appeared in the skie. Mamony ≈øaith, That the unclean may not eat of the Heave-offering untill their Sun be ≈øet, and three ≈øtars appear after the Sun is gone down. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 22. 9.

Thus have I ≈øhewed how God ordained the time of the two
Evenings for the effecting of two degrees of cleanne≈ø≈øe; and now I ≈øhall in the next Section ≈øhew, That all the latter Evening from Sun-≈øet till Mid-night, was appointed for the time of their Religious fea≈øting upon their Pa≈ø≈øeovers, and Peace-offerings; and that this part of the night was a true part of the former natural day.

div.head: SECT. 3.
div.p: FRom the date of the new Day to the per≈øon purified at the Sun-≈øet Evening, we may ≈øee the true Rea≈øon that did inforce the Jewes to begin all their Ceremonial Sabbaths at that time, and of all other dayes by occa≈øion thereof.

But this beginning of the day was no more to be accounted for the beginning of the natural Day, than the beginning of their yeer in Ni≈øhan was to be accounted for the fir≈øt month by Creation; for they began their yeer in Ni≈øhan upon the occa≈øion of their famous deliverance out of Egypt in that month; but from the Creation the yeer began in Tizri, which now is called the Seventh month, and this ≈øeventh month was afterwards made famous again by Jo≈øhua's Conque≈øt of Canaan, and by his divi≈øion of the land thereupon to the nine Tribes and a half, in this ≈øeventh month, Jo≈ø. 14. and in remembrance thereof they began all their yeers of Re≈øt, and all their Jubiles from that month. See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 12. 1, 2. Lev. 25. 8, 9, 10. Exod. 34. 22. Deut. 14. 22. and likewi≈øe the yeers of all Servants and Lea≈øes began at this time, Lev. 25.

And after this manner they ob≈øerved a double date according to the beginning of their double day. The Jews ob≈øerved both the date of their ceremonial day, and the date of their natural day for ≈øeveral purpo≈øes. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 20.
1 The per≈øon purified began the date of his day of cleanne≈ø≈øe from the Sun-≈øet Evening.

2 They dated the time of their Religious fea≈øting according to the natural day till midnight after; for by the Law they were expre≈øly commanded to eat the fle≈øh of their Peace-offerings in the ≈øame day, in which it was ≈øacrificed, Lev. 7. 15. now it was not po≈ø≈øible for them (at ≈øometimes at lea≈øt) to eat the holy fle≈øh of their Pa≈ø≈øeovers, and of their commanded Peace-offerings, in the ≈øame Ceremonial day, becau≈øe the time of ≈øacrificing their Pa≈ø≈øeovers and Peace-offerings did many times continue until it
was night, namely till Sun-≈øet; and ≈øo it fell out in the time of Jo≈øias Pa≈ø≈øeover, 2 Chron. 35. 14. Hence it follows by a nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence, That the command to eat the holy fle≈øh in the ≈øame day mu≈øt be under≈øtood (not of the ≈øame Ceremonial, but) of the ≈øame natural day; and in ca≈øe any of the holy fle≈øh had remained uneaten in the ≈øame day in which it was ≈øacrificed, it mu≈øt be burnt, and then ≈øometime it mu≈øt be all burnt, and none of it eaten, namely when it was ≈øacrificed at the point of Sun≈øet.

Secondly, If the date of their Ceremonial day had born all the ≈øway, then they mu≈øt not only have fini≈øhed the killing of all their Sacrifices, but of all their Religious fea≈øts al≈øo, before Sun-≈øet, and then our Saviour and his Apo≈øtles had ≈øinned, becau≈øe they kept their Religious Fea≈øt after Sun-≈øet, namely in the night wherein he was betrayed; for though they cau≈øed their Pa≈ø≈øeover to be ≈øacrificed on the fourteenth day, yet they deferred the time of their fea≈øting till after Sun-≈øet when the fifteenth day was begun, according to the date of the per≈øon purified. But if you will grant that our Saviour did not ≈øin again≈øt that Command of eating their Pa≈ø≈øeover in the ≈øame day, then you mu≈øt al≈øo grant that the ≈øame fourteenth day by Creation was not ended at Sun-≈øet, but continued ≈øtill till Mid-night after.

Thirdly, Hence it follows, that ≈øeeing all Ceremonial Cu≈øtomes are now aboli≈øhed by the death of Chri≈øt; that Gods people ought not to Judaize, in beginning the Lords day according to the Jews Ceremonial Cu≈øtomes, but according to the beginning and ending of the natural day from midnight to Mid-night.
Objection 3. How could the Jewes ob≈øerve a double date of a double day in one and the ≈øame naturall day without confu≈øion?

An≈øw. Their double date of their double day was not ≈øtrange to them, no more than their double date of their double yeer was to them; they could ≈øort out ≈øuch things, as belonged to the beginning of the yeer from the ≈øeventh month from the things that belonged to the beginning of the yeer in the fir≈øt month, without any confu≈øion at all; ≈øo in like manner they could ≈øort out all tho≈øe Religious duties that belonged to their Ceremonial date, from tho≈øe duties that belonged to the date of the naturall day.
They knew that the Bapti≈øed per≈øon mu≈øt begin his new day at Sun-≈øet, and that all Evening Sacrifices mu≈øt be fini≈øhed before Sun-≈øet; and yet in re≈øpect of the time of Fea≈øting, they knew that the ≈øame Natural day did ≈øtill continue till mid-night; Maymony ≈øaith, That the Prie≈øts mu≈øt eat the Peace-offerings of the Congregation in the ≈øame Day, and in half the Night. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 20. Hence you may ≈øee, that the Hebrew Doctors, whom Maymony follows, did hold that the ≈øame day (in the ca≈øe of Fea≈øting) did continue till mid-night; and indeed this time was ≈øufficient for the accompli≈øhment of all their religious Fea≈øts; in like ≈øort Solomon cals the Twilight evening of the night, the ≈øame day wherein the Sacrifice was ≈ølain, Prov. 7. 9. but it was not the ≈øame Ceremonial day, for at Sun ≈øet the Jews began their next day, or their morrow; but for a fuller an≈øwer, ≈øee my an≈øwer in Ch. 5. to Obj. 8. & 14. & 17.

div.head: CHAP. V. Proving that the Pa≈ø≈øeover did begin and end according to the Natural Evening, from mid-day to mid-night.
div.p: I Have ≈øhewed in Cha. 2. and Sect. 2. that the natural Evening was divided into two equal parts, and now I ≈øhall ≈øhew you, that the Pa≈ø≈øeover was ≈øolemnized in both the parts of that Evening.

Fir≈øt, All the Pa≈ø≈øeovers, and all the Peace-offerings that were annexed thereunto, were all ≈øacrificed in the time of the fir≈øt Evening, and it was utterly unlawful to ≈øacrifice any Pa≈ø≈øeover, either before this evening began, or after this evening was ended, which did ever begin at Mid-day, and end at Sun-≈øet.
Secondly, All the Pa≈ø≈øeovers of Canaan mu≈øt be fea≈øted on, with Religious ≈øolemnity, in the time of the latter evening.

But fir≈øt I will ≈øpeak of the time of Sacrificing all their Pa≈ø≈øeovers, and that was between the two evenings, namely, it was between the beginning of the fir≈øt, and the beginning of the latter evening; this was the preci≈øe limited time for this work.

list.item: 1 God commanded them to kill all their Pa≈ø≈øeovers in Aegypt between the two evenings, Exod. 12. 6.
2 God commanded them to kill all their Pa≈ø≈øeovers in the Wilderne≈ø≈øe between the two evenings, Numb. 9. 3. 5. 11.

div.p: This ≈øpace of time is called the appointed ≈øea≈øon thereof, Numb. 9. 2. Levit. 23. 4.

Solomon Jarchi expounds the two evenings thus; From the ≈øixth hour (which is at Mid-day) and forwards, it is called between the two Evenings, for that the Sun declineth towards his going down, &c. between the evening of the day, and the evening of the night; the evening of the Day is from the beginning of the ≈øeventh hour, and the evening of the Night is when the night begins. See Ain≈ø. in Numb. 9. 3.

2 Maymony ≈øaith thus; The killing of the Pa≈ø≈øeover is after Mid-day, and if they kill it before it is not allowable; and they kill it not but after the daily evening Sacrifice, and burning of Incen≈øe, and after they have trimmed the Lamps, then they begin to kill the Pa≈øchal Lamb, until the end of the day. See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 12. 6.
Till the end of the day was, till the Sun-≈øet evening, for after Sun-≈øet (≈øaith Maymony) the blood of all Sacrifices became unlawfull. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 1. 9. Lev. 6. 9. Lev. 7. 18.

Hence we ≈øee that the Hebrew Doctors held it as a Canon among them, that no Pa≈ø≈øeover was allowable, if it were killed either before Mid-day, or after Sun-≈øet; but all the time between was Gods appointed ≈øea≈øon, Num. 9. 2. Lev. 23. 4.

Ordinarily they began to kill their Pa≈ø≈øeovers at half an hour after two a Clock, but if the Pa≈ø≈øeover day fell out to be the Some think of no other Evening belonging to the Jews Sabbath, but the evening before the Sabbath; but they are gro≈øly mi≈øtaken, for that was no otherwi≈øe the evening of the Sabbath but in relation to the new day to the purified per≈øon, but the evening of the Sabbath if ≈øelf began and ended as the Pa≈ø≈øeover evening did from mid-day to mid-night. evening of the Sabbath (namely, that evening of the Sabbath which began at Mid-day) then they began to kill their Pa≈ø≈øeover ≈øonner; But (≈øtill this mu≈øt be remembred which Maymony often noteth, that) they never kild any Pa≈ø≈øeover till after the daily evening Sacrifice, and ≈øome other ≈øervices that did ever accompany it. See Ain≈ø. in Numb. 28. 4.

But (≈øay the Hebrew Doctors) God ≈øetteth no particular hour, neither for the killing of the daily evening Sacrifice, nor yet for the killing of the Pa≈ø≈øeover; but in general, he commanded them to be killed between the two evenings.

Hence it follows, That if they killed the daily evening Sacrifice, or the Pa≈ø≈øeover, or the Peace-offerings, in any part of the after-noon, between the time of Mid-day and the Sun-≈øet evening, they were allowable, and according to Gods own limited time.

But becau≈øe God requires that all his Wor≈øhip in all the Circum≈øtances of it ≈øhould be done decently, and in order, both in regard of time, place, and per≈øons; therefore the chief Rulers of the people, thought it their duty to ≈øuit all the particular bu≈øine≈ø≈øes about the Pa≈ø≈øeover, and the daily evening Sacrifice, to certain particular hours in the evening, ≈øo as all things might be done with the be≈øt conveniency, decency, and order, that one duty might not ≈øhoulder out another.

The Hebrew Doctors in the Babylonian Thalmud ≈øay thus; the daily evening Sacrifice was killed at the eighth hour and a half, and it was offered at the ninth hour and a half (that is to ≈øay, at half an hour after three a Clock) But in the evening of the Pa≈ø≈øover it was killed at the ≈øeventh hour and a half, and offered at the eighth hour and a half (that is to ≈øay, at half an hour after two a Clock) But if the evening of the Pa≈ø≈øeover did fall out to be upon the evening of the Sabbath, then it was killed at the ≈øixth hour and a half (that is to ≈øay, at half an hour after twelve a Clock) and it was offered at ≈øeven and a half. Buxtorfius al≈øo in his Hebrew Lexicon upon the word Gnarbaiim, doth from the Hebrew Doctors ≈øhew, that if the Pa≈ø≈øeover evening fell upon the Sabbath evening, that then they began to kill the daily evening Sacrifice at half an hour after twelve a Clock, becau≈øe of the manifold bu≈øine≈ø≈øes that belonged to the Sabbath, be≈øides the killing of their Pa≈ø≈øeovers; therefore that the doing of one duty might not thru≈øt out another, their Wi≈øe-men did ≈øet an order of time when they ≈øhould begin to kill the daily evening Sacrifice, which in all the days of the year was deferred to the la≈øt place, except on the Pa≈ø≈øeover evening, and then it was ever preferred to the fir≈øt place, and when ever the Pa≈ø≈øeover evening

Obj. 1. 3 They might not kill their Pa≈ø≈øeovers in Canaan in private hou≈øes as they did in Egypt; but all their Pa≈ø≈øeovers mu≈øt be brought to be ≈øacrificed at the place the Lord ≈øhould choo≈øe to place his bra≈øen Altar at, which at fir≈øt was at Shilo, and at la≈øt in Solomons Temple. If the Jewes had thought it as lawful for them to kill the Pa≈ø≈øeover in a private hou≈øe (ever ≈øince the de≈øtruction of the Temple) as they did at the fir≈øt Pa≈ø≈øeover in Egypt, then doubtle≈ø≈øe they would not have omitted to ≈øacrifice the Pa≈ø≈øeover now in all the places of their di≈øper≈øion; but ever ≈øince their Temple was de≈øtroyed, they have been without the Pa≈ø≈øeover, and without all other Sacrifices for the ≈øpace of ≈øixteen hundred yeers together; And thus ≈øpeaketh Mr. Broughton from the Hebrew Doctors: He that ≈øhall kill the Pa≈øcha, ever ≈øince Je≈øus Chri≈øt conquered Canaan, in a private hou≈øe, had been held an open enemy to the truth of God. Object. 3. Though the Jews might not kill their Pa≈ø≈øeovers in Canaan in their private hou≈øes as they did in Egypt, yet they might kill them at more Altars than one; for the Lord was plea≈øed to allow ≈øeveral Altars for Sacrifices in ≈øeveral places; and by this means all the Pa≈ø≈øeovers in Canaan might be killed, and the blood ≈øprinkled ju≈øt about the time of Sun-≈øet.

An≈ø. I grant that the Lord was plea≈øed to permit the u≈øe of many Altars and High-places in the dayes of Samuel; for there The Lord permitted many private Altars in the dayes of Samuel, but he allowed but one publick Altar for the general Fea≈øts of the twelve Tribes, and for the Pa≈ø≈øeover day, and for the daily Morning and Evening Sacrifice. was an Altar at Gilgal, 1 Sam. 10. 8. 1 Sam. 11. 15.
