Thus farre out of Doctor Leightfoot, which doth illu≈øtrate and ≈øtrengthen that which I have ≈øaid in ≈øundry places, about the beginning of the morning at mid-night.
Secondly, I come now to ≈øpeak of the ≈øecond Part of the Pa≈ø≈øeover Evening, which was for the u≈øe of their Religious Fea≈øting from Sun-≈øet to mid-night.

After my long digre≈ø≈øion to an≈øwer ≈øeveral Objections about the Iews cu≈øtoms, I come now to ≈øpeak of the ≈øecond part of the Pa≈ø≈øeover Evening, appointed for the time of their religious Fea≈øting on their Pa≈ø≈øeovers, and that was from Sun-≈øet to Mid-night, and this ≈øpace of time was all the latter evening.
And this is evident,

list.item: 1 By the appointment of Mo≈øes.
2 By the practi≈øe of our Saviour.

div.p: 1 Mo≈øes appointed all I≈ørael to eat the fle≈øh of the Pa≈øchal Lamb [In that Night] Exod. 12. 8, 42. namely in that part of the night that belonged to the fourteenth day by Creation.

2 It is evident that Chri≈øt did not ≈øit down to eat the Pa≈ø≈øeover with his twelve Apo≈øtles, until the latter evening was come; for Chri≈øt him≈øelf was in the fore-noon, or in the beginning of the after-noon at Bethany, when he ≈øent two of his Di≈øciples to Ieru≈øalem to prepare the Pa≈ø≈øeover, and to pre≈øent it to the Prie≈øts to be killed for them all between the two evenings, Mar. 14. 3. 12. 13. then after it was ≈øacrificed he bad them carry it to ≈øuch a hou≈øe, and make it ready again≈øt his coming, and in thus doing he did according to the Iews cu≈øtom, for their cu≈øtom was, that if thirteen or twenty did joyn together for one Pa≈ø≈øeover, they did ≈øend one or two of their company to pre≈øent it to the Prie≈øt, and ≈øo to make it ready for the re≈øt. See Ain≈ø. in Numb. 9. 12. then at Sun-≈øet they all met together, and began the fea≈øt at the hour appointed. This cu≈øtom our Saviour ob≈øerved, for he came not in per≈øon to Ieru≈øalem til the latter evening was come, Mat. 26 20. Mar. 14. 17. and when he was come he did not ≈øit down to eat until the appointed hour was come, Luk. 22. 14. this hour in general was the latter evening at Sun-≈øet, but the particular hour of their fea≈øting was not by the Hebrew Doctors Canons untill three Stars did appear after Sun-≈øet. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 22. 9.

2 It is evident that our Saviour did not begin to Fea≈øt on his Pa≈ø≈øeover untill the ≈øaid evening was come, and it is evident al≈øo, that he fini≈øhed all his religious exerci≈øes and ≈øolemnities within the ≈øpace of this latter evening, from ≈øun-≈øet till mid-night, as I have opened the matter more in my an≈øwer to the ≈øixteenth objection.

Object. 17. How can you prove that the Pa≈ø≈øeover-Supper was celebrated in the night of the fourteenth day, ≈øeeing you confe≈ø≈øe that the fifteenth day began that night at Sun-≈øet; and the Hebrew Doctors affirm, that the fle≈øh of the Pa≈øchal Lamb was eaten in the fifteenth night; how then can that night appertain both to the fourteenth, and to the fifteenth day?

An≈ø. It was the fifteenth night, according to the date of the per≈øon purified, as I have opened the matter in chap. 4. and otherwhere, but in regard of the Fea≈øt it did ≈øtill properly appertain to the fourteenth day. As for example, if a Iew were defiled on the Pa≈ø≈øeover day by any of the lighter ≈øorts of uncleane≈ø≈øes, what cour≈øe mu≈øt he take that he might not be deprived of the Pa≈ø≈øeover Fea≈øt? the an≈øwer is, he mu≈øt bathe or bapti≈øe him≈øelf in Water, at the looking forth of the evening, that is to ≈øay, in the after-noon; And what then? might hee then carry his Lamb to the Temple to be ≈øacrificed? No, he might not yet go him≈øelf to the Temple, becau≈øe his clen≈øing was not fully compleat; but yet he might joyn with others, and cau≈øe others to kill the Pa≈ø≈øeover for him, becau≈øe he was now in his fir≈øt degree of clean≈øing, and then as ≈øoon as the Sun was fully gone down upon him he was fully clean, and then he began the date of his day of cleanene≈ø≈øe, and then as ≈øoon as three Stars appeared after Sun-≈øet, he might ≈øit down with the re≈øt of that Society to eat the Pa≈ø≈øeover. See Ains. in Num. 9. 10.

And thus the Sun-≈øet evening was the fifteenth day to the Per≈øon purified, and yet it was properly the fourteenth day ≈øtill, in re≈øpect of fea≈øting on the Sacrifices; and thus the≈øe two actions of Fea≈øting and Purifying may wel bear the date of two ≈øeverall days thus enter-woven together, without any confu≈øion or di≈øorder.

1 It was nece≈ø≈øary that the Per≈øon purified ≈øhould begin the date of his new day as ≈øoon as his Ceremonial cleanene≈ø≈øe was perfected by the ≈øetting of the Sun upon him after his Bapti≈øing, as
I have opened the matter in chap. 4.

2 It was al≈øo as nece≈ø≈øary that the ≈øolemn act of fea≈øting upon the fle≈øh of their Sacrifices ≈øhould bear the date of the ≈øame day with the ≈øaid Sacrifices; 1 Becau≈øe the act of Fea≈øting received no new degree of cleanene≈ø≈øe at Sun-≈øet, as the per≈øon purified did. 2. Becau≈øe the act of fea≈øting in the latter evening after Sun-≈øet had a nece≈ø≈øary dependence upon the act of Sacrificing in the former evening, for the act of fea≈øting on the Holy fle≈øh in the latter evening was but to help on the Spiritual application of that document that was typified and exhibited by the ≈øacrifice in the former evening; therefore ≈øeeing the act of fea≈øting had ≈øuch a nece≈ø≈øary dependence upon the act of ≈øacrificing, I ≈øee no rea≈øon why this continued Sacramental Pa≈ø≈øeover ≈øhould bear the date of two ≈øeveral proper Natural days; I ≈øee no rea≈øon why the act of fea≈øting ≈øhould bear the date of the fifteenth day, except it be only in relation to the date of the per≈øon purified, and thus Maymony above cited mu≈øt be under≈øtood, that the fle≈øh of the Pa≈øchal Lamb was eaten on the fifteenth night, namely, according to the date of the per≈øon purified, though in regard of the Fea≈øt it ≈øelf it was but the fourteenth night ≈øtill, as in my next an≈øwer at fifthly I have cited his words.
Obj. 18. I de≈øire to ≈øee yet further, how you can prove that the latter evening at Sun-≈øet was a true part of the fourteenth day in the ca≈øe of their religious Fea≈øting upon the Pa≈ø≈øeover.

An≈ø. 1. I prove it by Exod. 12. 6, 8, & 14. ver≈øes compared together; the ≈øixth ver≈øe commanded them to kill all their Pa≈ø≈øeovers between the two evenings; this was the allowed ≈øea≈øon for the ≈øacrificing of all their Pa≈ø≈øeovers in Aegypt. 2. The eighth ver≈øe ≈øets out the allowed ≈øea≈øon for the time of fea≈øting; they ≈øhall eat the fle≈øh in that Night, namely, in that night that doth properly belong to the fourteenth day; and then 3. In ver≈øe fourteen, he doth unite the≈øe two ≈øolemn ‚Ä¢ actions together in the≈øe words; This day ≈øhall be to you for a memorial, yee ≈øhall fe≈øtivally keep it for a fea≈øt unto Jehovah; mark this phra≈øe, This day, and yee ≈øhall fe≈øtivally keep it; what day doth he mean el≈øe, but the fourteenth day afore ≈øpoken of? and yee ≈øhall fe≈øtivally k ‚Ä¢ ep i ‚Ä¢ , and yet the Fea≈øt was kept after Sun-≈øet. Hence it follows, that the time of fea≈øting on the Pa≈øchal Lamb after Sun-≈øet was a true part of the fourteenth day by Creation, though it was the beginning
of the fifteenth day to the per≈øon purified.

2 It is evident, that the Sun-≈øet evening is a true part of the ≈øame fourteenth day by Creation, by Numb. 9. 11. In the ≈øecond Month, in the fourteenth day of the Month, between the two evenings they ≈øhall do it, with unleavened Cakes, and bitter Herbs ≈øhall they eat it.

In this text Mo≈øes doth ≈øpeak of a Two-fold action to be done in the evening of the fourteenth day of the month; He ≈øpeaks of doing it, namely according to the Command, that is to ≈øay, of ≈øacrificing it between the two evenings; Secondly, He ≈øpeaks of the act of fea≈øting with unleavened Cakes, and bitter Herbs.
Mo≈øes doth not di≈øtribute the≈øe two Sacramental actions unto two ≈øeverall Natural days, but commands them both to bee done in the ≈øame fourteenth day of the month.

3 It is evident by Jo≈ø. 10. 3. that they kept the Fea≈øt of the Pa≈øchal Lamb on the fourteenth day of the Month at Even; Jo≈øhuae names only the time of Fea≈øting (though the time of Sacrificing mu≈øt be under≈øtood) he ≈øaith plainly, that it mu≈øt be fea≈øted on in the fourteenth day of the Month at even, I cannot ≈øee how any man that loves plain truth can deny the Sun-≈øet evening to be a true part of the former day.

4 It is evident that the latter evening was a true part of the fourteenth day, becau≈øe the ≈øeven days of unleavened Bread have ≈øeven latter evenings belonging to them, be≈øides the latter evening of the fourteenth day, ≈øo that they ob≈øerved eight fe≈øtival Evenings together, and ≈øo Jo≈øephus doth number them, in Antiq. lib. 2. ch. 5. and hence it follows, that the Fe≈øtival Supper which belonged to the la≈øt day of unleavened Bread, which was the one and twentieth day of the Month, did al≈øo bear the date of the two and twentieth day to the per≈øon purified, and this latter evening was the allowed ≈øea≈øon for all their Holy Fe≈øtival Suppers, and often-times it was little enough, for they mu≈øt boyl and ro≈øt all the fle≈øh of their Peace-offerings, which were of the greater kind, as ≈øheep and Oxen, (for no Fowls were allowed for Peace-offerings. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 3. 6.) this did much increa≈øe the quantity of their Provi≈øions, and therefore it required the longer time both to Cook it, and to fea≈øt on it; and all the≈øe days of Fea≈øting were commanded to be done with great ≈øolemnity, e≈øpecially the fir≈øt and the la≈øt, and with many relations of Gods goodne≈ø≈øe for
their deliverance out of Aegypt, and with Songs and P≈øalms of prai≈øe, Deut. 16. 15. Exod. 23. 15. Deut. 27. 7. See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 12. 8. and in this re≈øpect the latter evening was a competent time for the≈øe religious Solemnities, and to continue the time of fea≈øting longer, was a tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion: for it is expre≈øly commanded in Lev. 7. 15. that the holy fle≈øh mu≈øt be eaten in the ≈øame day in which it was ≈øacrificed; But if the Sun-≈øet evening had been the true beginning of the Natural day, then this Holy fle≈øh could not have been eaten the ≈øame day, as I have noted the rea≈øon thereof formerly, and then God by Mo≈øes had commanded us to do that which is not po≈ø≈øible to be done; therefore the Sun-≈øet evening is a true part of the ≈øame Natural day wherein the fle≈øh was ≈øacrificed.

Maymony ≈øaith (as I noted in objection ≈øixteen) that the Prie≈øts did eat the two Loaves which were pre≈øented to the Lord with the Meat-offering of the Congregation on the day of Pentico≈øt, in the ≈øame day, and in half the night, as the fle≈øh of the mo≈øt holy things were. See Ain≈ø. in Levit. 23. 20. ≈øo then, in the judgement of the ancient Hebrew Doctors (for Maymony doth but record their judgement) the latter evening till mid-night was a true part of the ≈øame Natural day, in which the Sacrifices were offered, though yet notwith≈øtanding the purified per≈øon began the date of his new day at the Sun-≈øet afore.

5 Thus (≈øaith Maymony) after he had related divers circum≈øtances about the Pa≈ø≈øeover, then is brought in a Table furni≈øhed with bitter Herbs, unleavened Bread, and the Body of the Pa≈øchal Lamb, and the fle≈øh Chagigah, which is (≈øaith he) for the fourteenth day of the Month, he doth not ≈øay which is for the fifteenth day of the Month (though otherwi≈øe he doth call this time the fifteenth day of the Month) both are true in a right ≈øen≈øe, namely in the ≈øen≈øe formerly given) and in another place Maymony ≈øaith thus, The evening of the fourteenth of N ‚Ä¢ ≈øhan is not like the evening of other Fe≈øtival days, becau≈øe in it are the Fea≈øt, and the killing of Sacrifices. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 5. He makes the time of fea≈øting to belong to the fourteenth day; and ≈øecondly, he preferres this evening to the evening of the Fe≈øtival Sabbaths, and therefore pre≈øcribes a greater puni≈øhment for ≈øervile work done on this evening, than for working in the evening before the Fe≈øtival Sabbaths, for ≈øo is the compari≈øon to be made, as I
have noted it el≈øewhere, becau≈øe in this evening was ≈øolemnized the proper Fea≈øt of the fourteenth day; but the evening before was but in way of preparation to the Sabbath it ≈øelf. Thirdly, Maymony ≈øaith thus, They ≈øearched out Leaven in the beginning of the night of the fourteenth day; Maymony calls the night before the Fea≈øt of the unleavened Bread the fourteenth night, and yet in another place he calleth it the fifteenth day.

Thus have I proved, not only by Scripture, but al≈øo by the con≈øent of the Hebrew Doctors, that the Sun-≈øet evening is a true part of the former day, though it be al≈øo the beginning of a new day to the per≈øon purified, by a Ceremonial in≈øtitution.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Proving that the Day of Reconciliation was an extraordinary long Sabbath, and an extraordinary long Fa≈øting-day, and therefore the beginning of this day ought not to be alleged as an exemplary Pattern, neither for the beginning of any other Fa≈øting-day, nor yet for the beginning of the Lords Day.
div.p: THe Law ≈øaith thus, in Lev. 23. 32. yee ≈øhall afflict your Souls in the ninth day of the Month, in the evening, from evening to evening you ≈øhal re≈øt your Sabbath.
This Sabbath was ≈øingular from other Sabbaths in two regards.

list.item: 1 No other Sabbath was like it, for the ≈øervices of it.
2 No other Sabbath was like it, for the length of it.

div.p: 1 No other Sabbath was like it, for the ≈øervices of it.
For 1. All the Sacrifices of this day were commanded to be done by the High Prie≈øt only, but on other Sabbaths they might be done by any other Prie≈øt as well as by the High Prie≈øt.
2 There were more Burnt-offerings commanded to be offered for the publick on this Sabbath, than on any other Sabbath.
3 More Incen≈øe mu≈øt be offered on this day, than on any other day.
4 There was more often ≈øprinkling of blood on this day, than on any other day.
5 The High Prie≈øt did oftener wa≈øh on this day, than on any other day.
6 He u≈øed more ≈øorts of Prie≈øtly garments on this day, than on any other day.
7 He did more often change his Garments on this day, than on any other day.
8 The High Prie≈øt did enter into the Holy of Holies on this day, and on no day el≈øe all the yeer long; and thus no day was like this Sabbath in the ≈øervices of it.
2 No day was like this day for the length of it, neither in re≈øpect of the fa≈øt, nor in re≈øpect of holy Re≈øt of it.
For though it was commanded to b ‚Ä¢ ob≈øerved in the tenth day of the ≈øeventh month, Lev. 23. 27. yet it was al≈øo commanded to begin in the Evening of the ninth day, Lev. 23. 32.
This Evening of the ninth day hath a double interpretation.
1 Some under≈øtand it of the ≈øacrifice-Evening of the ninth day.
2 Some under≈øtand it of the Evening at the end of the ninth day where the tenth day begins

1 In the fir≈øt ≈øen≈øe, Maymony ≈øaith, They began to afflict their ≈øouls in the Evening of the ninth day, next before the tenth day, and ≈øo they tarried in their affliction a little in the night after the tenth day.

In the≈øe words you ≈øee that Maymony doth not hold this fa≈øt to begin with the tenth day at the Sun-≈øet Evening, according to the date of the new day of the per≈øon purified; but in the evening of the ninth day, next before the tenth day: And Maymony ≈øaith moreover, That they mu≈øt abide in their affliction a little in the night after the tenth day.
This early beginning, and this late ending of this fa≈øting-day doth increa≈øe the length of this day, beyond the length of any other fa≈øting-day, or of any other Sabbath day.

2 This clau≈øe [In] the ninth day of the month, in the Evening, is thus read by the Greek Interpreters, From the ninth of the month, from the Evening; and thus they vary the Prepo≈øition from [In] to [From] and their Tran≈ølation agreeth fitly to
the next clau≈øe from Even unto Even you ≈øhall Re≈øt your Sabbath; and by this reading, we may ≈øee that the Seventy do make the latter Evening of the ninth day, to be a true part of the ninth day, though it were al≈øo the beginning of the tenth day according to the date of the per≈øon purified.

3 Hence it is al≈øo evident, that Mo≈øes did not hold the naturall beginning of the tenth day to begin at the Sun-≈øet evening of the ninth day, for then Mo≈øes words ≈øhould have run thus, From the tenth of the month from the Evening; but Mo≈øes doth not ≈øay ≈øo, but from the ninth of the month from the Evening, either he mu≈øt mean it to begin from the Sacrifice-Evening of the ninth day, as Maymony expounds it; or ≈øecondly, from the latter Evening of the ninth day (as a true part of the ninth day) as the Seventy under≈øtand it; or thirdly, from the Ceremonial beginning of the ninth day, which begins at the Sun-≈øet Evening before the ninth day. But then,

4 If you will take this phra≈øe from Even to Even to be from the Evening of the ninth day, according to the date of the per≈øon purified, then all the ninth day mu≈øt be a fa≈øting day as well as the tenth day, for the Evening of the ninth day is the beginning of the ninth day according to the date of the per≈øon purified; but if you de≈øire to avoid this gro≈ø≈øe ab≈øurdity, then you mu≈øt grant that the natural Evening of the ninth day did not begin, but end the ninth day, as the Seventy Interpreters do carry it.

5 They that do place the natural Evening at the beginning of the ninth day, and yet do allow the Sacrifice Evening to be placed at the end of the ninth day, they do thereby place the natural morning of the ninth day between the two Evenings of the ninth day, and ≈øo they do make the morning Sacrifice to be killed between the two Evenings; but when men will not receive the truth in the love of it, it is ju≈øt with God to let them run into ≈øuch ab≈øurd con≈øequences as the≈øe.

6 This fa≈øting-day was longer than any other fa≈øting-day; for No fa≈øting-day among the Jews was ≈øo long as the Fa≈øt on the day of Attonement was. all other publick fa≈øting dayes were left to the Elders of the Sanhedrim to be appointed when≈øoever they were in any di≈øtre≈øs, which were proclamed to be ob≈øerved in all the Synagogues of the Land, as well as at the Temple: But they did not injoyn them to begin tho≈øe fa≈øting dayes in the Evening before, with
≈øuch a ≈øtrict ab≈øtinence as they did the day of Reconciliation; for the Hebrew Doctors ≈øay, That it was lawfull for them to eat in the night, when the fea≈øt was on the morrow. See Ain≈ø. in Nu. 9. 10. By this te≈øtimony of Maymony, it is evident that they began all their other ≈øolemn fa≈øting-dayes in the morning, and not in the evening before, except the day of Reconciliation only; therfore no other publick fa≈øting-day was of ≈øuch a length as this yeerly fa≈øting-day was.

7 Neither was any other Sabbath of ≈øuch a length for ≈øtrict Re≈øt as this fa≈øting-Sabbath was, for they mu≈øt begin the ≈øtrict Re≈øt of this day, either in the Sacrifice Evening of the ninth day, or at the beginning of the latter Evening of the ninth: But they did not begin the ≈øtrict Re≈øt neither of their fe≈øtival Sabbaths, nor of the Sabbath or ≈øeventh day in the Evening before, as they did this yeerly fa≈øting-Sabbath; For Maymony ≈øaith, Such works as may be done on the Evening of a Fea≈øt-day, they do not upon a Fea≈øt-day, &c. See Ain. in 23. 7. By this te≈øtimony it is evident, that they did not hold the Evening before their fe≈øtival-Sabbaths to be as holy as the day it ≈øelf.

2 Maymony ≈øaith, It is unlawful to do works in the Evening of the fe≈øtival Sabbaths, from the time of the Evening Sacrifice, and forwards, Even as on the Evenings of the Sabbaths; and who ≈øo doth work in them ≈øhall never ≈øee a ≈øign of a Be≈ø≈øing, and he is to be rebuked, and to be made to leave off by force, though he is not for it to be ≈øcourged or excommunicated, except in the Evening of the Pa≈ø≈øeover after Mid-day who≈øo doth work therein after Mid-day, is to be ≈øcourged, or excommunicated with the Niddui; for the Evening of the fourteenth day of Ni≈øhan, is not like the Evening of other fe≈øtival dayes, becau≈øe in it are the Fea≈øt, and the killing of Sacrifices. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 5.
Two things are ob≈øervable from this Record of Maymony.
1 That the Jews did make ≈øome kind of preparation, both to their fe≈øtival-Sabbaths, and to their Sabbath or ≈øeventh day, from the time of the Evening Sacrifice, and forwards.

2 Hence it is evident, that the Hebrew Doctors did not e≈øteem any part of the Evening before their Sabbaths, to be as holy as the day following, becau≈øe they did neither ≈øcourge, nor excommunicate any man, for working in the Evening before their Sabbaths, as they did for working in the Pa≈ø≈øeover Evening; and the rea≈øon is plain, becau≈øe they e≈øteemed both the parts of the Pa≈ø≈øeover-Evening
to be the very day of the Pa≈ø≈øeover it ≈øelf; but it ≈øeems they did not e≈øteem the Evening before the Sabbath to be any true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, for doubtle≈ø≈øe, if they had e≈øteemed it as a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, they would not onely have ≈øcourged and excommunicated ≈øuch per≈øons, that did pre≈øume to work in the Evening, before the Sabbath, but al≈øo they would have ≈øtoned them to death, if they had pre≈øumptuou≈øly broken the re≈øt of the holy Sabbath, Numb. 15. 35. And as Maymony makes the Evening of the Pa≈ø≈øeover, not like the Evening that went before their fe≈øtival Sabbaths, nor like the Evening that went before their weekly Sabbath; So I may ≈øay of the Evening that went before the day of Attonement, that it was more ≈øtrict for holy re≈øt than the Evening that went before any of the other Sabbaths.

From all the Premi≈øes, I conclude, that no day in all the yeer was commanded to be of ≈øuch a length for ≈øtrict Re≈øt as this day was, for the ≈øtrict Re≈øt of this day, and the ≈øtrict Fa≈øt of this day began in the Sacrifice Evening, or el≈øe at the beginning of the latter Evening of the ninth day, and it continued not onely till a little after the Sun-≈øet Evening of the tenth day, as Maymony ≈øaith, But al≈øo it continued longer, for ≈øome of the holy duties of the tenth day, could not be fini≈øhed till Mid-night after; for

1 The Prie≈øts mu≈øt eat their part of the publick Sin-offering, Num. 29. 11. which mu≈øt be eaten in the ≈øame day in which it was offered, Lev. 6. 26. (as other Sacrifices were, Lev. 7. 15, 18.) and yet the Prie≈øts could not eat the holy fle≈øh of this publick Sin-offering till after Sun-≈øet; for the fa≈ø ‚Ä¢ of this day was not fully ended till after Sun-≈øet, and therefore al≈øo they might not begin to Cook that holy fle≈øh untill the Fa≈øt was fully ended. Hence it follows, that the ≈øame day did ≈øtill continue till after Sun-≈øet, yea untill it was Mid-night.

2 The Prie≈øts had another work to do within the limits of this tenth day, namely, they mu≈øt burn all the fats and peeces of all the publick Evening-≈øacrifices of this day (which were many) and ≈øome of their Evening-≈øacrifices were al≈øo offered neer unto Sun-≈øet, and therefore this work and duty of burning would require not only the more diligence, but al≈øo the more time, to fini≈øh this ≈øweet ≈øavor upon the Lords Altar in its own proper day, as I have noted the commanded ≈øea≈øon thereof more at large in Lev. 6. 9.

3 It appears, that ≈øome of the works which appertained to the morning-≈øacrifice of this tenth day, mu≈øt begin at Mid-night, and that ≈øome of the works which mu≈øt be done about the Evening-≈øacrifice were ≈øuch as could not be ended untill the Mid-night after.

For the fir≈øt work that mu≈øt be done on this day in preparation to the Morning-≈øacrifice was the taking away the a≈øhes from the Altar, and the≈øe a≈øhes they mu≈øt begin to take away at Mid-night, as Maymony ≈øaith. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 6. 10. And in an other place he ≈øaith, they took away the a≈øhes at Mid-night, and ordered the wood, &c. and at the break of day they began to kill the daily Morning-≈øacrifice. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 16. 4.

In like ≈øort they could not fini≈øh the burning of all the Evening-≈øacrifices of this day till Mid-night, as I have ≈øhewed above from Lev. 6. 9. and yet over and above this full day from Mid-night to Mid-night, they began their ≈øtrict Fa≈øt, and their ≈øtrict Re≈øt, in the Evening of the ninth day, which did increa≈øe the length of this day to be an extraordinary long Fa≈øting-Sabbath.

Hence I conclude, That the beginning of this day cannot be alleged as an exemplary pattern, neither for the beginning of any other Fa≈øting-day, nor yet for the beginning of our Lords day, as it is intended by tho≈øe that allege it for the beginning and ending of the Jews weekly Sabbath from Even to Even.

div.head: CHAP. VII. An≈øwering their Opinion more particularly that hold the Lords day to begin at Evening; And four Objections are An≈øwered.
div.p:
Object. 1. IT is objected, that our Lords day is come in the place of the Jewi≈øh Sabbath, which began at Evening; and for the proof of this they allege the Example of Nehemiah, he is ≈øaid to ≈øhut up the Gates of Jeru≈øalem when it began to be dark before the Sabbath, Neh. 13. 19. they expound the word Before, and the word Dark, in favour of their opinion thus; 1. The word Before the Sabbath, they ≈øay, doth mean ju≈øt
before the face or pre≈øent beginning of the Sabbath. 2. The word Dark they ≈øay doth mean when it was full Twilight, namely when the darkne≈ø≈øe in the Skie was ≈øomewhat more than the light in the Skie; for as long as the light in the Skie is more than darkne≈ø≈øe, they ≈øay the Sun is the cau≈øe of it; and hence they conclude that the Sun cannot be ≈øaid to be ≈øet till the darkne≈ø≈øe in the Skie be more in quantity than the light in the Skie, and this they make to be the punctual time of the Sun-≈øet evening, when the Jews Sabbath began, namely, when a Man could not ≈øee to read, or a Woman to ≈øew.

An≈ø. This expo≈øition of the beginning of the Sun-≈øet evening, and of the beginning of the Sabbath, is a new-found devi≈øe, I have already ≈øhewed the vanity of it in Chapter 4. in my an≈øwer to Obj. 2. That the Sun-≈øet evening is truly come as ≈øoon as ever the Body of the Sun is gone out of fight, and that Darkne≈ø≈øe is then begun, becau≈øe the ≈øhining of the Sun is gone from off the face of the earth, and Darkne≈ø≈øe is ≈øaid to begin at the going down of the Sun, in Gen. 15. 17. and then the Jews began to ≈øet their Night-watches, and then the purified per≈øon began the date of the day of his cleanene≈ø≈øe, and therefore if the Sabbath it ≈øelf did begin in the evening at all, it began then, namely according to the date of the day of the purified per≈øon, which began as ≈øoon as ever the Body of the Sun was gone out of ≈øight, as I have ≈øhewed in chap. 4. and then if Nehemiah did not ≈øet a Watch at the Gates of Jeru≈øalem till the darkne≈ø≈øe in the Skie was more than the light in the Skie, he did not that which was ≈øufficient to pre≈øerve the Holy re≈øt of the Holy Sabbath, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing they began to make ≈øome preparation to the ob≈øervation of the Sabbath, from the time of the Evening Sacrifice before, as I have ob≈øerved from the Hebrew Doctors.

But I perceive that ≈øuch as hold the Sabbath it ≈øelf to begin in Such as hold the Sabbath to begin ‚Ä¢ t the Sun‚ñ™≈øet evening can never prove that Chri≈øt lay three days in his Grave. the evening, are nece≈ø≈øitated to ≈øeek out ≈øuch odde expo≈øitions as this of the time of the Sun-≈øet evening, becau≈øe el≈øe they ≈øee that they can never prove that Chri≈øt lay three days inclo≈øed in the heart of the earth, Mat. 12. 40. and they know that Chri≈øt ro≈øe from the Dead on the fir≈øt day of the Week, Joh. 20. 19. Hence it follows, that he mu≈øt be inclo≈øed in the heart of the earth, in the very ≈øelf-≈øame Friday in which he was Crucified; for the fir≈øt day of the Week in which he aro≈øe from the Dead, is called the third Day after, 1 Cor. 15. 4. and in the≈øe re≈øpects it is of nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence
to de≈øcribe the preci≈øe time both of his Burial, and al≈øo of his Re≈øurrection, or el≈øe a doubting Con≈øcience cannot be rightly e≈øtabli≈øhed in the truth of his three days lying in the Grave.

But ≈øuch as hold the Sabbath to begin at the Sun-≈øet evening can never prove it, unle≈ø≈øe they can prove that Chri≈øt was inclo≈øed in the heart of the earth ≈øome di≈øtinct time before Sun-≈øet; but Luke ≈øaith, that the time of Chri≈øts Burial was, when it began to be Star-light, Luk. 23. 54. that is not po≈ø≈øible to be done, for Luke ≈øaith, that the Sabbath began to lighten (with Star-light) when he was inclo≈øed in his Grave, Luk. 23. 54.

Ma≈øter Broughton, Mr. Weames, and the Syriac do render the Tran≈ølation ≈øo, and the Seventy u≈øe the ≈øame Greek word in Job 25. 5. for the light of the Moon, and it may as well be u≈øed for the light of the Stars, for they are called Stars of light, Gen. 1. 14, 16. P≈øal. 148. 3.

Let all the circum≈øtances of time about the burial of Chri≈øt bee ca≈øt up, and laid together, and then it will put the matter out of doubt, that the burial of Chri≈øt could not be fini≈øhed till it was Sar-light.

1 Con≈øider the time when Jo≈øeph went to Pilate to begge the Body, and that was not till the Sun-≈øet evening was come, Mat. 27. 57. Mar. 15. 42. This evening that was now come cannot be under≈øtood of the fir≈øt evening, for that was come at Mid-day, and Chri≈øt was then alive, therefore it mu≈øt be under≈øtood of the latter evening which was not come till Sun-≈øet.

Obj. 2. But Mr. Norton objecteth again≈øt this Tran≈ølation, and In his Treati≈øe of Chri≈øts Sufferings. ≈øaith, that it is not true that Jo≈øeph came not to begge the Body of Chri≈øt untill Sun-≈øet; but Jo≈øeph (≈øaith he) came as the evening was coming, as the Greek hath it, therefore before it was actually come; and be≈øides, (≈øaith he) he could not otherwi≈øe have taken down the Body, and buried it the ≈øame day according to the Law, Deut. 21. 23. which John te≈øtifieth they were carefull and mindfull of, Joh. 19. 31.

An≈ø. As touching the tran≈ølation of the Greek in Matthew and Mark, I have ≈øearched into ≈øundry Tran≈ølations, and all that I can yet meet withall have it, When the evening was come; I have al≈øo conferred with ≈øome that are learned in the Tongues, and they ≈øay it is but a har≈øh tran≈ølation to render it, When the evening was coming; and Tindall doth both tran≈ølate and expound Mar 15. 42 thus, When night was come (becau≈øe it was the evening that goeth
before the Sabbath) But what if the Greek doth ≈øignifie no more but as Ma≈øter Norton ≈øaith, when the evening was coming? yet that tran≈ølation makes the difference of time ≈øo ≈ømall that it is not worth the ≈øpeaking of, for in the like ca≈øe Mark ≈øaith, That at the evening, when the Sun was ≈øet, the Jews brought their di≈øea≈øed per≈øons to Chri≈øt to be cured, Mark 1. 32. but Luke ≈øaith, It was when the Sun was ≈øetting, Luk. 4. 40. that is to ≈øay, when the evening was coming, for in proper ≈øpeech, the latter evening cannot be ≈øaid to be coming till the Sun be ≈øetting.

And ≈øecondly, It ≈øeems to me that Jo≈øeph of Arimathea dur≈øt not go to Pilate to beg the dead Body before Sun-≈øet, for fear of the di≈øplea≈øure of the High Prie≈øts, and therefore he delayed his going to Pilate untill the High Prie≈øts had fir≈øt gone and be≈øought Pilate that their leggs might be broken, and that they might bee taken down, becau≈øe it was the time of their preparation to their High Fe≈øtival Sabbath-Supper, for Jo≈øeph knew that the High Prie≈øts were de≈øirous that Chri≈øt ≈øhould hang upon the Cro≈ø≈øe for his greater ignominy, as long as other cur≈øed Malefactors u≈øed to do, and that was untill the Sun was ≈øet, and in this ≈øen≈øe Jo≈øhua did under≈øtand the Law to mean, namely, that they might Deut. 21. 23. hang upon the Tree after the night was begun (which was begun at Sun-≈øet) and therefore he did not command the dead Bodies of the cur≈øed Kings to be taken down from the Tree untill the Sun was down, Jo≈ø 8. 29.

I grant that formerly I have expounded this clau≈øe in Deut. 21. 23. Thou ≈øhalt not let his Carka≈ø≈øe hang all night upon the tree, to mean (not at all in the night) but ≈øince then I finde upon better examination that I was in an error, though Ma≈øter Norton takes it for a truth, and ≈øo in like ≈øort he takes ≈øome plain truths for great errors; but this ≈øentence, they ≈øhal not hang all night, implies, that they may hang ≈øome part of the night upon the tree, provided they were buried the ≈øame day, namely in the ≈øame Natural day, which la≈øted after Sun-≈øet untill Mid-night, as I have ≈øhewed in chap. 5. in my an≈øwer to Object. 16.

And in this re≈øpect Io≈øhua let the dead Bodies of the Kings hang ≈øtill upon the Tree untill the Sun was ≈øet; that is to ≈øay, untill the night was begun; but if this command of burying them in the ≈øame day had meant in the ≈øame Ceremonial day, then the dead Bodies might not continue hanging on the Tree untill the
Sun was ≈øet, except they had been buried ≈øome di≈øtinct time before Sun-≈øet; this clau≈øe therefore [in the ≈øame day] mu≈øt be under≈øtood not of the ≈øame Ceremonial day which ended at Sun-≈øet, but of the ≈øame Natural day which continued after Sun-≈øet till mid-night, as I have ≈øhewed more at large in Chapter five, in my an≈øwer to Objection ≈øixteen, and in chap. 4. ult. and in other places al≈øo.

The chief Prie≈øts were fir≈øt in their reque≈øt to Pilate, becau≈øe it was the time of their preparation to their ≈øolemn High Sabbath-Supper, for it was the fir≈øt day of unleavened bread, which was a high Sabbath, and their Fe≈øtival-Supper was to begin at Star-light, therefore they be≈øought Pilate that their leggs might be broken, and that they might be taken away, Joh. 19. 31. thus you ≈øee that the Prie≈øts in regard of their preparation to their Sabbath-Supper were fir≈øt in their reque≈øt unto Pilate, pre≈øently upon this Pilate commanded that their leggs ≈øhould be broken, and Jo≈øeph perceiving their reque≈øt, fir≈øt did wi≈øely e≈øpy the advantage of time, and without delay he went boldly unto Pilate, and be≈øought him, that he might take away the Body of Je≈øus, and Pilate gave him leave; he came therefore and took the Body of Je≈øus, Joh. 19. 38. this was all done in the neck of one another, and this time is recorded by Matthew and Mark, to be when the Sun-≈øet evening was done.

From the Premi≈øes I rea≈øon thus; If the Sun-≈øet evening was come before Io≈øeph went to Pilate to begge the Body of Chri≈øt, then the Sabbath Star might well be ri≈øen before the Body of Chri≈øt could be inclo≈øed in the heart of the earth, for Io≈øeph had many things to do after he had the grant of the dead Body, before it could be inclo≈øed in his Grave; Fir≈øt, he went to the Shops to buy ≈øeverall peeces of Linnen to wrap the dead Body in, according to the Iews manner, Ioh. 20. 6, 7. (as we may ≈øee the manner in Lazarus burial, Ioh. 11. 44.) and Nicodemus al≈øo did take up ≈øome time to imbalm his Body, which al≈øo was done with many circum≈øtances according to the Iews cu≈øtome, Ioh. 19. 40. (as it is ≈øet down by Mr. Ain≈øworth in Gen. 46. 4. and in Gen. 50. 2.) and then (though the place of burial were near, yet) it would require both hands and time to carry him thither, and to rowl the ≈øtone upon the mouth of his Grave, before hee could be ≈øaid to be inclo≈øed in the heart of the earth; I grant al≈øo
that all this was done with as much ha≈øte as might be, becau≈øe of the Iews preparation to their Fe≈øtival Supper, and yet as ≈øoon as this was done, or could be done, their High Fe≈øtival-Sabbath began to lighten, namely, with the Evening Star at lea≈øt, if not with more Stars, for it was a Canon among them, not to begin their Fe≈øtival-Suppers till three Stars did appear, and doubtle≈ø≈øe Lukes phra≈øe doth allude to that cu≈øtom. This Sabbath that did now begin to lighten was not the Sabbath it ≈øelf, for if the Sabbath it ≈øelf had been begun at the ri≈øing of the Evening Starre, then doubtle≈ø≈øe the holy Women had broken the holy re≈øt of the Sabbath day, becau≈øe after all this they went to the ≈øhops and bought Odors, and Oyntments, Luke 23. 56. compared with Mark 16. 1. yea and after they had bought the≈øe Odors and Oyntments they went home and prepared them in a readine≈ø≈øe to perfume the Body of Chri≈øt with them as ≈øoon as ever the Sabbath was pa≈øt, Mat. 28. 1. If they had bought them before his burial they would have perfumed his Body before his burial, as Nicodemus did.

Therefore ≈øeeing the≈øe holy Women did all this work after the burial, and after the Sabbath began to lighten, it is an evident proof that the Sabbath it ≈øelf did not begin neither at the Sun-≈øet evening, when the per≈øon purified began the date of his new day, nor yet at the ri≈øing of the evening ≈øtarre, for if the Sabbath it ≈øelf had been begun at either of the≈øe times, then the holy Women had mo≈øt gro≈øly broken the holy re≈øt of the Sabbath; But the Holy Text doth witne≈ø≈øe on their ≈øide that they re≈øted the Sabbath, according to the Commandment, Luk. 23. 56.

Hence I conclude from this practi≈øe of the holy Women, that though the evening before the Sabbath doth bear the date of the day following to the per≈øon purified, yet in proper ≈øpeaking it is no part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, it is only to be e≈øteemed the Sabbath but by way of preparation, and no more.

Secondly I an≈øwer, That your expo≈øition of the word before may better carry this ≈øen≈øe, namely that this latter evening was indeed before the Sabbath it ≈øelf, and I have ≈øhewed in chap. 5. that the evening of the Sabbath is put by the Hebrew Doctors, ≈øometimes for the evening before the Sabbath, and ≈øometimes for the la≈øt half of the Sabbath it ≈øelf; but ≈øee more in this Chapter in the an≈øwer to the next objection.

Object. 2. It ≈øeems to me that the Sabbath it ≈øelf did begin and end at the Sun-≈øet Evening by the Jews practi≈øe, for they held it unlawful before the Sun-≈øet Evening was come for our Saviour to heal di≈øea≈øed per≈øons; But after the Sun-≈øet Evening was come, all manner of di≈øea≈øed per≈øons came flocking to him for cure, Mar. 1. 32. Hence it appears that the Jews held the Sabbath to be fully ended as ≈øoon as the Sun-≈øet Evening was come.

An≈ø. It is but the bare conjecture that they forbore to bring their ≈øick per≈øons till the Sabbath was ended: I deny it to be the very rea≈øon, I beleeve the onely rea≈øon why they came no ≈øooner, was becau≈øe they had no ≈øooner intelligence of his miraculous power to heal; you do barely affirm that the Jews in general held it unlawful for our Saviour to heal di≈øea≈øed per≈øons upon the Sabbath day, but you are deceived. Tremelius doth te≈øtifie from the ancient Hebrew Doctors that they held the contrary: They held that the perill of life did drive away the Sabbath; that is to ≈øay, they held it lawful to u≈øe any means to prevent the danger of death upon the Sabbath day. See Tremelius his Annot. in Mat. 12. 8. in the Syriack Te≈øtament; Mr. Ain≈øworth al≈øo doth affirm from the Hebrew Doctors, that they held it to be a Sabbath days work to vi≈øit the ≈øick; for they held that perill of life did drive away the Sabbath. See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 20. 10. See al≈øo my former Treati≈øe.

2 I do al≈øo apprehend by the circum≈øtances of the ≈øtory, that the Jews of Capernaum were not offended with our Saviour for his miraculous cure, which he did upon that Sabbath day (as the malignant Scribes and Phari≈øees ≈øometimes were) in healing one in the Synagogue that had an unclean ≈øpirit, Mark. 1. 27.

3 They took no offence at him for the curing of Peters wives mother of her Feavor, pre≈øently after he had left the ≈øaid Synagogue, v 31. Therefore ≈øeeing they found no fault with Chri≈øt for neither of the≈øe miraculous cures before the Sabbath was ended, doubtle≈øs they did not forbear to bring their di≈øea≈øed per≈øons in re≈øpect of the Sabbath (for they admired the power of God in the≈øe miracles) and therefore as ≈øoon as the publick exerci≈øe was ended, they ≈øpread his fame, ver≈øe 28. and thereupon a multitude of the di≈øea≈øed per≈øons of Capernaum came to him for cure with all the po≈ø≈øible ≈øpeed they could, as it appears by their earne≈øt pre≈ø≈øing
after ≈øo ≈øhort a warning, for I conceive by the circum≈øtances of the ≈øtory, that it was but a little afore Sun-≈øet when Chri≈øt left the Synagogue, and then as ≈øoon as he had left the Synagogue he healed Peters wives mother, which was another procuring cau≈øe that made the greater flocking to him; but if his miraculous cures had been done ≈øooner, doubtle≈ø≈øe the fame thereof would have made the ≈øick per≈øons to have flocked ≈øooner after him.

I grant that ≈øome of the malignant Scribes and Phari≈øees did ≈øometimes take offence at Chri≈øt for his miraculous healing upon the Sabbath day; But the people in general rejoyced at all the excellent things that were done by him upon the Sabbath day, Luke 13. 17. for Chri≈øt did now heal a poor crooked woman upon that Sabbath day, ver≈øe 11. And when the Ruler of the Synagogue took offence at it, Chri≈øt (by rea≈øons) put him to ≈øilence; and the people rejoyced that Chri≈øt had put him to ≈øilence.

Therefore though ≈øome of the malignant Jews held erroniou≈øly that Chri≈øt ought not to heal upon the Sabbath day, yet that is no good argument to prove that the≈øe Jews of Capernaum did purpo≈øely detain their ≈øick per≈øons till the Sabbath was ended, I deny it to be the Rea≈øon; I do apprehend rather that they did ha≈øtily flock to him, rather than deliberately forbear till the Sabbath might be ended.
4 Mr. Pemble on this place ≈øaith, That this Evening was the Evening of the ≈øame day wherein Chri≈øt had done ≈øo much before, as the inference ≈øhews plainly.

5 It is evident to me from ≈øeveral te≈øtimonies of the Hebrew Doctors, that they held the Sun-≈øet Evening after the Sabbath to be a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, becau≈øe they held it lawful to The Hebrew Doctors held the Sun-≈øet Evening after the Sabbath, to be a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf. do many things in the Sun-≈øet Evening before the Sabbath, which they did not hold lawfull to be done in the Sun-≈øet Evening after the Sabbath.

1 Maymony ≈øaith thus, The two Loaves of New Corn for the Wave-offering (on the day of Pentico≈øt) were not Baked on the day of Penteco≈øt, becau≈øe it was a Sabbath; nor in the Evening before, if it were a Sabbath. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 17.
Two things are evident from this Te≈øtimony.

1 That in the judgement of the Hebrew Doctors the Sun-≈øet
Evening after the Sabbath, was a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, becau≈øe they held it unlawfull to bake the ≈øaid two Loaves of new corn in the Evening before the day of Pentico≈øt, if it were a Sabbath: But they might without ≈øcruple have baked the ≈øaid two Loaves in the ≈øaid Evening before Pentico≈øt, as well as on any other Evening, if they had held that the Sabbath had then been fully ended. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 6, 7.
2 Hence it is evident, that the Hebrew Doctors did not hold the Evening before the Sabbath to be a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, no otherwi≈øe than by way of preparation.

3 Mamony gives another in≈øtance from the time of baking the twelve Loaves of Shew-bread; he ≈øaith, That the twelve Loaves of the Shew-bread might not be baked on the Sabbath, nor on a Fea≈øt-day, but in the Evening of the Sabbath they baked it, and ≈øet it in order on the morrow. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 24. 5.

Hence this is remarable in this Hebrew Record; That he makes a manife≈øt difference between the Evening that goes before the Sabbath, and the Sabbath it ≈øelf, he calls the Evening before, [the Evening of the Sabbath] by cu≈øtome peculiar to the Jews, from the date of the new day to the per≈øon purified (as I have formerly ≈øhewed) he allows the≈øe twelve Loaves to be baked in the Evening of the Sabbath all the yeer long, except it fell out to be in the latter Evening of a Fe≈øtival-Sabbath; and therefore it doth hence follow, that not the Evening before, but the Evening after their Fe≈øtival-Sabbaths, was a true part of their Fe≈øtival-Sabbaths; And ≈øo likewi≈øe Tremelius a Chri≈øtian Jew, doth make the Evening after the Sabbath to be a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, in his Tran≈ølation and note on the Syriak Te≈øtament in Matth. 28. 1.

Therefore by the judgement of the Hebrew Doctors, the Fe≈øtival-Sabbath was not ended at Sun-≈øet; and thence it follows, that if their fe≈øtival-Sabbaths were not ended at Sun-≈øet, then their weekly Sabbaths were not ended at Sun-≈øet.
4 Maymony ≈øaith thus, Who ≈øo laboureth in the Evening of the Sabbath, he ≈øhall eat in the Sabbath, See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 16. 26.

Hence it follows, that in the judgement of the Hebrew Canons, the Evening before the Sabbath was no part of the Sabbath no otherwi≈øe but by way of preparation to the Sabbath; for they ≈øay, That he that will eat in the Sabbath, mu≈øt labour in the Evening of
the Sabbath, namely in the Evening before the Sabbath; This they ≈øpeak, as I conceive, of their laborious preparing of their Manna (according to every ones palat) in a readine≈øs again≈øt the Sabbath; for though the Manna was a ready food of it ≈øelf, without preparing to ≈øome ≈øtomacks, yet not to al, til it were cooked to their palat; and it could not be prepared in this ≈øort without great labor, for it was ground in Mills, and beaten in Mortars, Num. 11. 8 And in that re≈øpect the Hebrew Doctors ≈øay, Who ≈øo laboureth in the Evening of the Sabbath, ≈øhall eat in the Sabbath; but in ca≈øe they neglected this work in the Evening of the Sabbath, they might not do it on the Sabbath day, but they mu≈øt rather fa≈øt and endure hunger for their negligence ≈øake.

Hence it follows, that the Evening before, was called the Evening of the Sabbath, no otherwi≈øe but by way of preparation, and it is called the Evening of the Sabbath from their new date to the per≈øon purified; his new day did ever begin at the Sun-≈øet Evenning.

5 Maymony ≈øaith thus, Such works as may be done in the Evening before a Fea≈øt-day they do not upon a Fea≈øt-day; they may not reap, nor thre≈øh, nor winnow, nor grinde corn, nor the like upon a Sabbath day, for all the≈øe things may be done in the Evening of a Sabbath, killing of Bea≈øts, baking of bread, kneading of dough, and the like, may be done in the Evening of a Sabbath. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 7. in like ≈øort their laborious preparation of their Manna mu≈øt be done in the Evening of the weekly Sabbath.

Object. 4. By the Evening of the Sabbath the Jews do not mean onely the Sun-≈øet Evening, but they accounted the Sabbath Evening to begin at three a clock in the afternoon before; and in this re≈øpect Maymony ≈øaith thus, It is unlawful to do works in the Evenings of the Fe≈øtival-Sabbaths from the time of the Evening ≈øacrifice, and forward (even as upon the Evening of the weekly Sabbaths) and who ≈øo doth work in them ≈øhall never ≈øee a ≈øign of ble≈ø≈øing, and he is to be rebuked, and to be made to leave off by force, Though he is not for it to be ≈øcourged or excommunicated, except in the Evening of the Pa≈ø≈øeover after Mid-day; who ≈øo doth work therein after Midday, he is to be ≈øcourged or excommunicated with the Niddui, for the fourteenth of Ni≈øhan is not like the Evening of other Fe≈øtival dayes, becau≈øe in it are the Fea≈øt, and the killing of Sacrifices. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 23. 5.

An≈ø. I grant that the Jews did make ≈øome kind of preparation
both to their Fe≈øtival-Sabbaths, and to their weekly Sabbaths al≈øo, from the time of the Evening-≈øacrifice, and forwards, till Bed-time; for though they did not begin their day of cleanne≈ø≈øe till Sun-≈øet, yet in regard of the many works that were to be done again≈øt their Fea≈øt-dayes (which I have immediately named) and in regard of preparing their Manna, &c. again≈øt the Sabbath, their wi≈øe men held it convenient to forbear, and leave off the ordinary works of their calling from the time of the Evening-≈øacrifice, and forwards, till bed-time; and in that re≈øpect the Magi≈øtrates them≈øelves did forbear to ≈øit in their Courts of Judicature after the time of the Evening-≈øacrifice. See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 18. 22. But this degree of preparation had no other command from God, but the general rule of conveniency.

2 It is evident from the ≈øaid Te≈øtimony, that they did not e≈øteem any part of the Evening, neither before, nor after Sun-≈øet, to be as a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, becau≈øe they did neither ≈øcourge nor excommunicate any man that did any ≈øervile work in this Evening, as they did for working in any part of the Pa≈ø≈øeover Evening from Mid-day till Mid-night; but if they had in their judgement e≈øteemed any part of the Evening before the Sabbath to be a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, doubtle≈ø≈øe they would have puni≈øhed ≈øuch Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors more ≈øeverely than for working upon the Pa≈ø≈øeover Evening, for by Mo≈øes Law, ≈øuch per≈øons ought to be ≈øtoned to death, Numb. 15. 34, 35.

Hence it follows fir≈øt, That the Evening before the Sabbath (though it be called the Evening of the Sabbath according to their ceremonial cu≈øtome, yet it) was no true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, but in way of preparation onely.
Secondly, That the Sun-≈øet Evening after the Sabbath was indeed a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf.

5 It is evident that the Evening after the Sabbath was e≈øteemed to be a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, by the te≈øtimony of the Evangeli≈øt John, in Chap. 20. 19. the Text runs thus, The ≈øame day at Evening, being the fir≈øt day of the week; John calls this Evening not the ≈øecond, but the fir≈øt day of the week, and yet it mu≈øt needs be now a good ≈øpace after Sun-≈øet, for there were two Di≈øciples now pre≈øent that came from Emaus, and it was towards Evening before they came from Emaus, and they could not well come from thence to Jeru≈øalem in le≈ø≈øe than three hours ≈øpace, for
it was ≈øixty Furlongs from Emaus to Jeru≈øalem, Luke 24. 13. 29. 36.

Mr. Goodwin, and others, allow eight Furlongs to an Engli≈øh or Italian mile; but the Hebrew Doctors allow but ≈øeven Furlongs and a half to an Engli≈øh mile. See Ain≈ø. in Lev. 16. 21. The New Te≈øtament doth not follow the Italian Furlong, but the Greek Furlong (or ≈øtadium Olympicum) which contains ≈øix thou≈øand feet; and the Hebrew Doctors ≈øay that two thou≈øand Cubits make a mile. See Ain≈ø. in Exod. 16. 29. The New Te≈øtament doth follow the Greek Cu≈øtomes as frequently as they followed the Greek Tongue; Therefore in rea≈øon as the New Te≈øtament was written in Greek, ≈øo it ≈øhould follow the Greek ≈øtadium rather than the Italian; be≈øides, I conceive that the Italian stadium came not into common u≈øe untill after the New Te≈øtament was written. So then by the Hebrew Doctors account, it was eight miles from Emaus to Jeru≈øalem; that is to ≈øay, it was Eight Engli≈øh miles: Now if you will allow but three hours time for the going of the≈øe eight miles, it mu≈øt needs be after Sun-≈øet when they came to the Apo≈øtles; and after they were come, they ≈øpent ≈øome time in relating unto the Apo≈øtles what had happened to them the ≈øame day as they went to Emaus, and as they were making this Relation Je≈øus came and ≈øtood in the mid≈øt of them, Luke 24. 36.

The≈øe circum≈øtances con≈øidered, it mu≈øt needs be after the date of the Jews Ceremonial day before Chri≈øt came in among them, and yet the Evangeli≈øt calls this time of the Evening, the ≈øame day in which Chri≈øt ro≈øe from the dead; and ≈øecondly, he calls it the fir≈øt day of the week. So then, by the≈øe two expre≈ø≈øions the Evangeli≈øt puts the matter out of doubt to ≈øuch as will be ≈øatisfied by plain con≈øequences of Scripture, that this latter Evening when Chri≈øt came into the hou≈øe to the Apo≈øtles, was a true part of the former day, and yet it was after Sun-≈øet, and therefore it was after their Ceremonial day was begun.

6 And la≈øtly, I may well bring hither all tho≈øe five Arguments which I alleged in Chap. 5. to prove the latter Evening of the fourteenth day of Ni≈øhan to be a true part of the fourteenth day, and therefore it follows by good con≈øequence, hat the latter Evening of the Sabbath was a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf.

Obj. It appears to me that the Natural day begins at the Sun-≈øet evening, for the Lord telleth Ezekiel in the ninth year of Jeconiahs captivity,
that he ≈øhould be dumb untill the day that Jeru≈øalem ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed, and untill a Me≈ø≈øenger ≈øhould come to Ezekiel to tell the news thereof, Ezek. 24. 26, 27. this is the Prediction, now the accompli≈øhment of this Prophecy is ≈øet down in Eze. 33. 21, 22. In the twelfth year of our captivity, in the tenth Month, and in the fifth day of the Month, then one that had e≈øcaped out of Jeru≈øalem came unto Ezekiel, and ≈øaid, The City is ≈ømitten; now ≈øaith Ezekiel, The hand of the Lord had been upon me in the evening before he that had e≈øcaped came, and had opened my mouth untill he came to me in the morning, and when he had opened my mouth I was no more dumb. From the≈øe two Scriptures compared it is evident, that the evening before the Me≈ø≈øenger came, and the morning after he was come, are termed the ≈øame day; therefore it follows by good con≈øequence that the ≈øame day began in the evening.

An≈ø. This is a ≈øtrange collection to prove the evening to be the beginning of the Natural day; the vanity of this collection will appear by the opening of two words in this Prophecy, which mu≈øt not be taken as you do, in ≈øtrict propriety of ≈øpeech, but in a figurative ≈øen≈øe, I mean the word Day, and the word Dumb.

1 I ≈øay the word Day mu≈øt not be taken in a ≈øtrict ≈øen≈øe for a proper Natural day of twenty four hours, but it mu≈øt be taken Figuratively for a time to come, as it appears by the computation of time; for Ezekiel is ≈øaid to be dumb in the ninth year of Jeconiahs captivity, in the tenth Month, and in the tenth day of the Month, Eze. 24. 1, 2. in which day Ezekiels wi≈øe dyed, ver≈ø. 18. which was the plea≈øure of his eyes, ver≈ø. 16. and her death was for a ≈øign unto the Iews, that the Temple which was the plea≈øure of their eyes, ver≈ø. 21. ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed) and then in that day (namely when the Temple ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed, he that e≈øcapeth in that day ≈øhould come to Ezekiel and tell him; And in [that day] viz. in time to come, Ezekiels mouth ≈øhould be opened unto him which e≈øcaped to tell him, and then he ≈øhould ≈øpeak and be no more dumb, ver. 26, 27.

This is the Prediction; now compare the ≈øtory of events, and that lyes thus, The Temple was burnt on the tenth day of the fifth Month, in the eleventh year of Zedekiah, Jer. 52. 12, 13. and there is no record to be found that any Me≈ø≈øenger came to Ezekiel to tell him in the ≈øame day, neither is it po≈ø≈øible for any man to come from Jeru≈øalem to Chaldea in one Natural day of
twenty four hours, therefore the Me≈ø≈øenger that came to him in (that day) came to him in that day which is Figuratively put for the time to come, for the Me≈ø≈øenger came not to Ezekiel until ≈øeventeen Months after that the Temple was de≈øtroyed, for hee came not till the fifth day of the tenth Month, and in the twelfth year of Jeconias captivity, Ezek. 33. 21. therefore this phra≈øe the ≈øame day mu≈øt not be under≈øtood of the ≈øame Natural day, but of day at large, for the term day is often put for a large time to come, as in Ezek. 23. 38, 39. & Ezek. 33. 12. and in Deut. 27. 2 See Ain≈ø.

2 Ezekiel is ≈øaid to be dumb in the ninth year, Ezek. 24. 12. 27. till the Me≈ø≈øenger came to him in the twelfth year of Ieconiahs captivity, in all which ≈øpace Ezekiel was not dumb from ordinary ≈øpeech (as Zachary was, Luk. 1. 20.) neither yet was he dumb from Prophecying again≈øt other Nations, as it appears by Eze. 26. 1. and Eze. 29. 1. and Eze. 31. but he was dumb or ≈øilent from Prophecying any more again≈øt the unbeleeving Iews, as chap. 3. 26. untill this Me≈ø≈øenger came with ≈øpecial tidings, to certifie him how all things were accompli≈øhed as he had fore-told, and now at the coming of this ≈øpecial Me≈ø≈øenger Ezekiels mouth was opened again, to utter another Prophecy of the utter ruine of the remnant of the Iews that were left, Ezek. 33. 2, 3. and from this time forth he was no more dumb; that is to ≈øay, he was no more re≈øtrained from Prophecying to them of their utter ruine: So then, this Me≈ø≈øenger was ≈øent to Ezekiel on purpo≈øe, to tell him the pre≈øent ≈øtate of things, and to inquire of him what ≈øhould be the future event of the remnant that were left.

Ezekiel could not chu≈øe but hear of the burning of the Temple long before this Me≈ø≈øenger came to him, partly by the poor Captives, and partly by the Souldiers, and al≈øo he could not chu≈øe but hear of the death of Gedaliah before this ≈øpecial Me≈ø≈øenger came; but ≈øuch accidental tidings did not an≈øwer to the ≈øign that was given for the time of his new Prophecying, for the ≈øign was this, That a ≈øpecial Me≈ø≈øenger ≈øhould be ≈øent unto him from Ieru≈øalem to Chaldea (in a day) that is to ≈øay in a time to come, and then Ezekiels mouth ≈øhould be opened unto him, to utter ≈øome new Prophecy to him, though it was not according to their expectation; for he fore-tels, that the remnant that were left ≈øhould likewi≈øe come to de≈øtruction.

Be≈øides ‚Ä¢ he hand of Prophecie that came upon Ezekiel in the
Evening before the Me≈ø≈øenger came, may be taken as well for the fir≈øt, as for the latter Evening; for God did often give Vi≈øions to his Prophets in the fir≈øt Evening, at the time of the Evening Sacrifice, Act. 3. 1. Dan. 9. 21. Act. 10. 3, 9. Therefore unle≈ø≈øe it can be proved that this Evening was the Sun-≈øet Evening, no concluding argument can be drawn from this Text to prove the Natural day to begin at the Sun-≈øet Evening; no, though the term Day, and the term Dumb had been ≈øpoken properly.

So then from all the premi≈øes, I conclude, that not the Evening before, but the Evening after the Sabbath was a true part of the Sabbath it ≈øelf, and therefore they that take liberty to bu≈øie them≈øelves about worldly matters in the Sun-≈øet Evening after the Sabbath, do prophane that holy time that God hath ≈øanctified to his own u≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Proving that the punctual time of Chri≈øts Re≈øurrection was in the morning, ju≈øt at Sun-ri≈øing.
div.p: DOubtle≈ø≈øe it is a matter of nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence, not onely to prove cleerly the punctual time of Chri≈øts burial, but of his Re≈øurrection al≈øo; for if the time of his Re≈øurrection be uncertain, how can a doubting con≈øcience be ≈øatisfied that Chri≈øt lay three dayes in the heart of the earth, according to the Prediction? Therefore as I have proved the time of Chri≈øts burial to be fini≈øhed when their Fe≈øtival-Sabbath began to lighten by the Evening-≈øtar, ≈øo I ≈øay al≈øo that the time of his Re≈øurrection was ju≈øt about the time of Sun-ri≈øing on the fir≈øt day of the week.

Chri≈øt did not ri≈øe from his grave before day-break, as ≈øome would have it, nor at day-break, as others would have it, by uncertain gue≈ø≈øes. Matthew ≈øaith, that Mary Magdalen went out of the door of her hou≈øe in the fir≈øt day of the week when it began to dawn, intending to perfume his burial with the ≈øweet Odors that ≈øhe had prepared in the Evening before the Sabbath, Matth. 28. 1. But Mark ≈øaith, That the Sun was
ju≈øt ri≈øen when ≈øhe came to the Sepulchre, Mark. 16. 1. ≈øhe ≈øpent all that ≈øpace of time between day-break and Sun-ri≈øing, partly in calling upon other holy women to go with her, Luke 24. 10. and partly in going ≈øo much ground as was from her lodging to the Sepulchre, and then when ≈øhe was come to the Sepulchre, there was a mighty Earthquake, Mat. 28. 2. and then his grave was opened; ≈øuch a like Earthquake there was at the death of Chri≈øt, which opened divers of the graves of the Saints, and after the Re≈øurrection of Chri≈øt, they did ri≈øe al≈øo out of their graves, and came into the holy City, and appeared unto many, Mat. 27. 52, 53. By this Earthquake at Sun-ri≈øing when Mary Magdalen came to the Sepulchre, it is evident that Chri≈øt did not ri≈øe out of his grave untill the≈øe holy women came to be witne≈ø≈øes of the time of his Re≈øurrection. I confe≈ø≈øe that many Interpreters do think that Chri≈øt was ri≈øen before the≈øe holy Witne≈ø≈øes came to the Sepulchre, but ≈øuch conjectures may not be admitted, for it is a point of nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence to be proved, That Chri≈øt lay three dayes in the heart of the Earth; but if you ≈øay, That Chri≈øt was ri≈øen before the≈øe holy Witne≈ø≈øes came, then you cannot cleerly prove that Chri≈øt lay three dayes in the heart of earth; for it may be demanded how long was he ri≈øen before they came? If you ≈øay it was but one hour before, I may as well ≈øay it was ≈øeven or eight hours before, and then how can you ≈øatisfie a doubting con≈øcience that Chri≈øt lay three dayes, and three nights in the heart of the earth? I cannot think that Chri≈øt would ≈øuffer his own Prediction to remain ≈øo ob≈øcure without manife≈øt proof of the full accompli≈øhment of it: Therefore I conclude, that Chri≈øt ro≈øe not out of his grave till the holy women came to be Witne≈ø≈øes of the ≈øame, which was al≈øo evidently declared unto them by this Earth-quake at their coming to the Sepulchre, ju≈øt at Sun-ri≈øing, though they could not make that u≈øe of it till afterwards.
Object. 1. This Earthquake might be pa≈øt before the holy women came to the Sepulchre, and they might know it afterward only by the Souldiers relation.

An≈ø. Chri≈øt did never ≈øhew him≈øelf to any wicked man after his Re≈øurrection, Joh. 14. 19. Joh. 16. 20, 22. Act. 10. 41. Therefore it is not like that he would make the Roman Souldiers to be the only Witne≈ø≈øes of this Earthquake which did evidence the time
of his Re≈øurrection. I conceive the holy women would not give much credit to the te≈øtimony of the Roman Souldiers, except this Earthquake had been general to all the parts of the City, as wel as to that particular place, but it ≈øeems to me that this Earthquake was not generally ≈øpread over the City, but it was limited only to that particular place where Chri≈øts Sepulchre „Äà‚óä„Äâ , as a ≈øpecial te≈øtimony of the time of his Re≈øurrection: In like „Äà‚óä„Äâ that place only where the Apo≈øtles were (when they were threatned by the Hgh Prie≈øts) was ≈øhaken as a te≈øtimony of encouragement to them, not to be afraid of Tyrants, Act. 4. 31. Act. 2. 2. Act. 12. 7. and ≈øo there was an Earthquake that opened the particular place where Paul was impri≈øoned, Act. 16. 26. the bare te≈øtimony of the Souldiers would have been but of ≈ømall credit to prove ≈øo weighty a matter as the time of Chri≈øts Re≈øurrection was: Therefore I conclude, that Chri≈øt aro≈øe not from his Grave till the≈øe holy women came to te≈øtifie the time of his Re≈øurrection by an Earthquake, which happened at their fir≈øt coming to his Sepulchre, and that was ju≈øt at Sun-ri≈øing: I conceive that the holy women at fir≈øt were amazed, and did not know what u≈øe to make of this Earthquake, Joh. 20. 9. but afterwards they did plainly perceive that it was a manife≈øt demon≈øtration of the time of his Re≈øurrection; and after this Earthquake, Mary Magdalen went to the Apo≈øtles, and told them that Chri≈øt was ri≈øen from the dead, and ≈øhe followed the Apo≈øtles back again to the Sepulchre; And 3. when they ≈øaw no body in the Sepulchre, they returned home. 4 But Mary Magdalen ≈øtaid ≈øtill behind; and then Chri≈øt him≈øelf did appear unto her as John doth te≈øtifie.

From all the premi≈øes it is evident, that Chri≈øt lay in the heart of the earth about four hours of the ≈øixth day, and the whole Sabbath, and about five hours of the fir≈øt day of the week, namely, from Mid-night till Sun-ri≈øing; and after this ≈øort Chri≈øt lay three dayes, and three nights, in the heart of the Earth.

But tho≈øe that begin the Sabbath at the Sun-≈øet-Evening can never prove that Chri≈øt lay three dayes in the heart of the Earth: Therefore that opinion mu≈øt needs be of evill con≈øequence: Fir≈øt, Becau≈øe it fal≈øifies the ≈øaid Prediction. And ≈øecondly, Becau≈øe it leads men to do ≈øervile works in the latter Evening
of the Lords day, as manyfold experience of mens worldly practi≈øes doth te≈øtifie in New England as ≈øoon as the Sun-≈øet Evening of the Lords day is come.

It this Treati≈øe may be of any u≈øe to ≈øatisfie a doubting con≈øcience touching the time of Chri≈øts Burial and Re≈øurrection, and touching th ‚Ä¢ limits of the Lords day, Give glory to God, who gi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gifts to men for that purpo≈øe. Even ≈øo AMEN.
